Even Amory’s reading paled during this period; he delved further into the misty side streets of literature: Huysmans, Walter Pater, Theophile Gautier, and the racier sections of Rabelais, Boccaccio, Petronius, and Suetonius. One week, through general curiosity, he inspected the private libraries of his classmates and found Sloane’s as typical as any: sets of Kipling, O. Henry, John Fox, Jr., and Richard Harding Davis; “What Every Middle-Aged Woman Ought to Know,” “The Spell of the Yukon”; a “gift” copy of James Whitcomb Riley, an assortment of battered, annotated schoolbooks, and, finally, to his surprise, one of his own late discoveries, the collected poems of Rupert Brooke.
就连艾默里的阅读能力在这一时期也黯然失色。他进一步深入研究了文学的迷雾小巷：于斯曼、沃尔特·佩特、泰奥菲尔·戈蒂埃，以及拉伯雷、薄伽丘、佩特罗尼乌斯和苏托尼乌斯的活泼部分。一周，出于普遍的好奇心，他检查了同学的私人图书馆，发现斯隆的私人图书馆和其他图书馆一样典型：吉卜林、欧·亨利、小约翰·福克斯和理查德·哈丁·戴维斯的一套； 《每个中年妇女都应该知道的事》、《育空地区的咒语》；一本詹姆斯·惠特科姆·莱利的“礼物”副本，一套破旧的、带注释的教科书，最后，令他惊讶的是，他自己的最新发现之一是鲁珀特·布鲁克的诗集。

Together with Tom D’Invilliers, he sought among the lights of Princeton for some one who might found the Great American Poetic Tradition.
他与汤姆·丹维利尔斯 (Tom D’Invilliers) 一起，在普林斯顿大学的灯光下寻找可能发现伟大的美国诗歌传统的人。

The undergraduate body itself was rather more interesting that year than had been the entirely Philistine Princeton of two years before. Things had livened surprisingly, though at the sacrifice of much of the spontaneous charm of freshman year. In the old Princeton they would never have discovered Tanaduke Wylie. Tanaduke was a sophomore, with tremendous ears and a way of saying, “The earth swirls down through the ominous moons of preconsidered generations!” that made them vaguely wonder why it did not sound quite clear, but never question that it was the utterance of a supersoul. At least so Tom and Amory took him. They told him in all earnestness that he had a mind like Shelley’s, and featured his ultrafree free verse and prose poetry in the Nassau Literary Magazine. But Tanaduke’s genius absorbed the many colors of the age, and he took to the Bohemian life, to their great disappointment. He talked of Greenwich Village now instead of “noon-swirled moons,” and met winter muses, unacademic, and cloistered by Forty-second Street and Broadway, instead of the Shelleyan dream-children with whom he had regaled their expectant appreciation. So they surrendered Tanaduke to the futurists, deciding that he and his flaming ties would do better there. Tom gave him the final advice that he should stop writing for two years and read the complete works of Alexander Pope four times, but on Amory’s suggestion that Pope for Tanaduke was like foot-ease for stomach trouble, they withdrew in laughter, and called it a coin’s toss whether this genius was too big or too petty for them.
那一年的本科生团体本身比两年前完全庸俗的普林斯顿大学更有趣。事情出人意料地活跃，尽管牺牲了大一时自发的魅力。在老普林斯顿，他们永远不会发现塔纳杜克·怀利。塔纳杜克是一名大二学生，有着巨大的耳朵，并且会说：“地球在预想的几代人的不祥卫星中旋转而下！”这让他们隐隐约约地想知道为什么这听起来不太清楚，但从不怀疑这是超灵的话语。至少汤姆和艾默里是这么对待他的。他们真诚地告诉他，他有雪莱的头脑，并在《拿骚文学杂志》上刊登了他的超自由的自由诗和散文诗。但塔纳杜克的天才吸收了时代的多种色彩，他过上了放荡不羁的生活，这让他们大失所望。他现在谈论的是格林威治村，而不是“正午旋转的月亮”，他遇到了冬天的缪斯，非学术性的，在四十二街和百老汇与世隔绝，而不是雪莱的梦想儿童，他曾与他们期待着欣赏。因此，他们将塔纳杜克交给了未来主义者，认为他和他的火焰领带在那里会做得更好。汤姆给了他最后的建议，让他两年内停止写作，读四遍亚历山大·波普的全集，但艾默里建议波普之于塔纳杜克就像胃病的脚部放松一样，他们笑着退出了，并称之为这个天才对于他们来说是太大还是太小，只是抛硬币而已。

Amory rather scornfully avoided the popular professors who dispensed easy epigrams and thimblefuls of Chartreuse to groups of admirers every night. He was disappointed, too, at the air of general uncertainty on every subject that seemed linked with the pedantic temperament; his opinions took shape in a miniature satire called “In a Lecture-Room,” which he persuaded Tom to print in the Nassau Lit.
艾默里相当轻蔑地避开那些每晚向一群崇拜者分发简单警句和少量查特勒酒的受欢迎的教授。他也对每一个似乎与迂腐气质有关的话题普遍存在的不确定性感到失望。他的观点在一部名为《在演讲室里》的微型讽刺作品中得到了体现，他说服汤姆将其发表在《拿骚文学》上。

   “Good-morning, Fool...
                       Three times a week
    You hold us helpless while you speak,
    Teasing our thirsty souls with the
    Sleek ‘yeas’ of your philosophy...
    Well, here we are, your hundred sheep,
    Tune up, play on, pour forth... we sleep...
    You are a student, so they say;
    You hammered out the other day
    A syllabus, from what we know
    Of some forgotten folio;
    You’d sniffled through an era’s must,
    Filling your nostrils up with dust,
    And then, arising from your knees,
    Published, in one gigantic sneeze...
    But here’s a neighbor on my right,
    An Eager Ass, considered bright;
    Asker of questions....  How he’ll stand,
    With earnest air and fidgy hand,
    After this hour, telling you
    He sat all night and burrowed through
    Your book....  Oh, you’ll be coy and he
    Will simulate precosity,
    And pedants both, you’ll smile and smirk,
    And leer, and hasten back to work....

    ’Twas this day week, sir, you returned
    A theme of mine, from which I learned
    (Through various comment on the side
    Which you had scrawled) that I defied
    The highest rules of criticism
    For cheap and careless witticism....
      ‘Are you quite sure that this could be?’
    And
      ‘Shaw is no authority!’
    But Eager Ass, with what he’s sent,
    Plays havoc with your best per cent.

    Still—still I meet you here and there...
    When Shakespeare’s played you hold a chair,
    And some defunct, moth-eaten star
    Enchants the mental prig you are...
    A radical comes down and shocks
    The atheistic orthodox?
    You’re representing Common Sense,
    Mouth open, in the audience.
    And, sometimes, even chapel lures
    That conscious tolerance of yours,
    That broad and beaming view of truth
    (Including Kant and General Booth...)
    And so from shock to shock you live,
    A hollow, pale affirmative...

    The hour’s up... and roused from rest
    One hundred children of the blest
    Cheat you a word or two with feet
    That down the noisy aisle-ways beat...
    Forget on narrow-minded earth
    The Mighty Yawn that gave you birth.”

In April, Kerry Holiday left college and sailed for France to enroll in the Lafayette Esquadrille. Amory’s envy and admiration of this step was drowned in an experience of his own to which he never succeeded in giving an appropriate value, but which, nevertheless, haunted him for three years afterward.
四月，克里·霍勒迪离开大学，启航前往法国，加入拉斐特足球队。艾默里对这一步的羡慕和钦佩淹没在他自己的一次经历中，他从未成功地给予这种经历适当的价值，但尽管如此，这件事在三年后仍然困扰着他。

THE DEVIL
恶魔

Healy’s they left at twelve and taxied to Bistolary’s. There were Axia Marlowe and Phoebe Column, from the Summer Garden show, Fred Sloane and Amory. The evening was so very young that they felt ridiculous with surplus energy, and burst into the cafe like Dionysian revellers.
他们十二点离开希利店，打车去比斯托拉里店。其中有《夏日花园》节目中的阿克西娅·马洛和菲比·科伦，还有弗雷德·斯隆和艾默里。傍晚时分，他们觉得精力过剩很可笑，像酒神狂欢者一样冲进咖啡馆。

“Table for four in the middle of the floor,” yelled Phoebe. “Hurry, old dear, tell ’em we’re here!”
“四人桌在地板中间，”菲比喊道。 “快点，亲爱的，告诉他们我们到了！”

“Tell ’em to play ‘Admiration’!” shouted Sloane. “You two order; Phoebe and I are going to shake a wicked calf,” and they sailed off in the muddled crowd. Axia and Amory, acquaintances of an hour, jostled behind a waiter to a table at a point of vantage; there they took seats and watched.
“告诉他们玩‘钦佩’！”斯隆喊道。 “你们两个吩咐；菲比和我要去摇一头邪恶的牛犊。”然后他们在混乱的人群中扬帆离去。阿克西娅和艾默里是一个小时的熟人，他们在服务员身后挤到一张有利位置的桌子旁。他们在那里坐下来观看。

“There’s Findle Margotson, from New Haven!” she cried above the uproar. “’Lo, Findle! Whoo-ee!”
“这是来自纽黑文的芬德尔·玛戈森！”她在喧嚣声中哭了。 “‘瞧，芬德尔！呜呜！”

“Oh, Axia!” he shouted in salutation. “C’mon over to our table.” “No!” Amory whispered.
“哦，阿克夏！”他高声敬礼。 “到我们桌来吧。” “不！”艾默里低声说道。

“Can’t do it, Findle; I’m with somebody else! Call me up to-morrow about one o’clock!”
“做不到，芬德尔；我和别人在一起了！明天一点左右给我打电话！”

Findle, a nondescript man-about-Bisty’s, answered incoherently and turned back to the brilliant blonde whom he was endeavoring to steer around the room.
芬德尔，一个与比斯蒂有关的不起眼的人，语无伦次地回答，然后转向他正努力带着她在房间里转来转去的那个漂亮的金发女郎。

“There’s a natural damn fool,” commented Amory.
“这是一个天生的傻瓜，”艾默里评论道。

“Oh, he’s all right. Here’s the old jitney waiter. If you ask me, I want a double Daiquiri.”
“噢，他没事。这是老吉尼服务员。如果你问我，我想要一杯双份代基里酒。”

“Make it four.”
“做四个吧。”

The crowd whirled and changed and shifted. They were mostly from the colleges, with a scattering of the male refuse of Broadway, and women of two types, the higher of which was the chorus girl. On the whole it was a typical crowd, and their party as typical as any. About three-fourths of the whole business was for effect and therefore harmless, ended at the door of the cafe, soon enough for the five-o’clock train back to Yale or Princeton; about one-fourth continued on into the dimmer hours and gathered strange dust from strange places. Their party was scheduled to be one of the harmless kind. Fred Sloane and Phoebe Column were old friends; Axia and Amory new ones. But strange things are prepared even in the dead of night, and the unusual, which lurks least in the cafe, home of the prosaic and inevitable, was preparing to spoil for him the waning romance of Broadway. The way it took was so inexpressibly terrible, so unbelievable, that afterward he never thought of it as experience; but it was a scene from a misty tragedy, played far behind the veil, and that it meant something definite he knew.
人群旋转、变幻、移动。他们大多来自大学，其中有零星的百老汇男性垃圾，还有两种类型的女性，其中较高级的是合唱团女孩。总的来说，这是一群典型的人群，他们的聚会也很典型。整个生意大约有四分之三是为了效果，因此无害，在咖啡馆门口结束，很快就赶上了五点钟的火车返回耶鲁大学或普林斯顿大学；大约四分之一的人一直持续到天色较暗的时候，并从陌生的地方收集了奇怪的灰尘。他们的聚会原本是一场无害的聚会。弗雷德·斯隆 (Fred Sloane) 和菲比·科伦 (Phoebe Column) 是老朋友了。阿克西亚和艾默里是新的。但即使是在夜深人静的时候，奇怪的事情也在准备着，而那些在咖啡馆里最不潜伏的不寻常的东西，这个平淡而不可避免的家，正准备破坏他百老汇日渐式微的浪漫。事情的经过是如此难以言喻的可怕，如此令人难以置信，以至于后来他再也没有把这视为经历。但这是一场朦胧的悲剧中的一幕，在幕布后面上演，这意味着他知道一些明确的事情。

About one o’clock they moved to Maxim’s, and two found them in Deviniere’s. Sloane had been drinking consecutively and was in a state of unsteady exhilaration, but Amory was quite tiresomely sober; they had run across none of those ancient, corrupt buyers of champagne who usually assisted their New York parties. They were just through dancing and were making their way back to their chairs when Amory became aware that some one at a near-by table was looking at him. He turned and glanced casually... a middle-aged man dressed in a brown sack suit, it was, sitting a little apart at a table by himself and watching their party intently. At Amory’s glance he smiled faintly. Amory turned to Fred, who was just sitting down.
大约一点钟，他们搬到马克西姆店，两人在德维尼埃店找到了他们。斯隆一直在喝酒，处于一种不稳定的兴奋状态，但艾默里却非常清醒。他们没有遇到过那些通常为纽约聚会提供帮助的古老而腐败的香槟买家。他们刚刚跳完舞，正要回到椅子上时，艾默里意识到附近一张桌子上有人正在看着他。他转头漫不经心地看了一眼……是一个身穿棕色麻袋服的中年男子，独自坐在一张桌子旁，目光稍稍有些远，专注地看着他们一行人。艾默里看了一眼，他淡淡一笑。艾默里转向刚刚坐下的弗雷德。

“Who’s that pale fool watching us?” he complained indignantly.
“那个看着我们的脸色苍白的傻瓜是谁？”他愤怒地抱怨道。

“Where?” cried Sloane. “We’ll have him thrown out!” He rose to his feet and swayed back and forth, clinging to his chair. “Where is he?”
“在哪里？”斯隆叫道。 “我们要把他赶出去！”他站起来，紧紧抓住椅子，前后摇晃着。 “他在哪里？”

Axia and Phoebe suddenly leaned and whispered to each other across the table, and before Amory realized it they found themselves on their way to the door.
阿克西亚和菲比突然靠在桌子对面窃窃私语，在艾默里意识到之前，他们发现自己正朝门口走去。

“Where now?”
“现在在哪里？”

“Up to the flat,” suggested Phoebe. “We’ve got brandy and fizz—and everything’s slow down here to-night.”
“到公寓去，”菲比建议道。 “我们喝了白兰地和汽水——今晚一切都变慢了。”

Amory considered quickly. He hadn’t been drinking, and decided that if he took no more, it would be reasonably discreet for him to trot along in the party. In fact, it would be, perhaps, the thing to do in order to keep an eye on Sloane, who was not in a state to do his own thinking. So he took Axia’s arm and, piling intimately into a taxicab, they drove out over the hundreds and drew up at a tall, white-stone apartment-house. ... Never would he forget that street.... It was a broad street, lined on both sides with just such tall, white-stone buildings, dotted with dark windows; they stretched along as far as the eye could see, flooded with a bright moonlight that gave them a calcium pallor. He imagined each one to have an elevator and a colored hall-boy and a key-rack; each one to be eight stories high and full of three and four room suites. He was rather glad to walk into the cheeriness of Phoebe’s living-room and sink onto a sofa, while the girls went rummaging for food.
艾默里飞快地思考着。他没有喝酒，并且决定如果不再喝酒，他在聚会上小跑就相当谨慎了。事实上，这也许是为了监视斯隆而要做的事情，因为斯隆无法自己思考。于是他拉着阿克西娅的手臂，亲密地挤进一辆出租车，他们越过数百人开出去，在一栋高大的白石公寓前停了下来。 ……他永远不会忘记那条街……那是一条宽阔的街道，两边都是高大的白石建筑，点缀着黑色的窗户；它们一直延伸到目力所及之处，明亮的月光洒满了它们，使它们呈现出钙白色。他想象每个人都有一部电梯、一个彩色的门童和一个钥匙架；每栋楼高八层，设有三间和四间套房。他很高兴走进菲比欢快的客厅，坐在沙发上，而女孩们则在翻找食物。

“Phoebe’s great stuff,” confided Sloane, sotto voce.
“菲比真是太棒了，”斯隆低声说道。

“I’m only going to stay half an hour,” Amory said sternly. He wondered if it sounded priggish.
“我只会待半个小时。”艾默里严肃地说。他想知道这听起来是否有些自负。

“Hell y’ say,” protested Sloane. “We’re here now—don’t le’s rush.”
“见鬼，”斯隆抗议道。 “我们现在就到了——别着急。”

“I don’t like this place,” Amory said sulkily, “and I don’t want any food.”
“我不喜欢这个地方，”艾默里闷闷不乐地说，“而且我不想要任何食物。”

Phoebe reappeared with sandwiches, brandy bottle, siphon, and four glasses.
菲比带着三明治、白兰地瓶、虹吸管和四个玻璃杯再次出现。

“Amory, pour ’em out,” she said, “and we’ll drink to Fred Sloane, who has a rare, distinguished edge.”
“艾默里，把它们倒出来，”她说，“我们要为弗雷德·斯隆干杯，他有着罕见的、杰出的优势。”

“Yes,” said Axia, coming in, “and Amory. I like Amory.” She sat down beside him and laid her yellow head on his shoulder.
“是的，”阿克西娅走进来说道，“还有艾默里。我喜欢艾默里。”她在他身边坐下，把黄色的头靠在他的肩上。

“I’ll pour,” said Sloane; “you use siphon, Phoebe.”
“我来倒，”斯隆说。 “你用的是虹吸管，菲比。”

They filled the tray with glasses.
他们在托盘上装满了玻璃杯。

“Ready, here she goes!”
“准备好了，她来了！”

Amory hesitated, glass in hand.
艾默里手里拿着玻璃杯，犹豫了一下。

There was a minute while temptation crept over him like a warm wind, and his imagination turned to fire, and he took the glass from Phoebe’s hand. That was all; for at the second that his decision came, he looked up and saw, ten yards from him, the man who had been in the cafe, and with his jump of astonishment the glass fell from his uplifted hand. There the man half sat, half leaned against a pile of pillows on the corner divan. His face was cast in the same yellow wax as in the cafe, neither the dull, pasty color of a dead man—rather a sort of virile pallor—nor unhealthy, you’d have called it; but like a strong man who’d worked in a mine or done night shifts in a damp climate. Amory looked him over carefully and later he could have drawn him after a fashion, down to the merest details. His mouth was the kind that is called frank, and he had steady gray eyes that moved slowly from one to the other of their group, with just the shade of a questioning expression. Amory noticed his hands; they weren’t fine at all, but they had versatility and a tenuous strength... they were nervous hands that sat lightly along the cushions and moved constantly with little jerky openings and closings. Then, suddenly, Amory perceived the feet, and with a rush of blood to the head he realized he was afraid. The feet were all wrong ... with a sort of wrongness that he felt rather than knew.... It was like weakness in a good woman, or blood on satin; one of those terrible incongruities that shake little things in the back of the brain. He wore no shoes, but, instead, a sort of half moccasin, pointed, though, like the shoes they wore in the fourteenth century, and with the little ends curling up. They were a darkish brown and his toes seemed to fill them to the end.... They were unutterably terrible....
有一瞬间，诱惑像一阵暖风一样向他袭来，他的想象力开始燃烧，他从菲比手中接过杯子。就这些;因为就在他做出决定的那一刻，他抬起头，看到了距离他十码远的那个曾在咖啡馆里的人，他惊讶地跳了起来，玻璃杯从他举起的手中掉了下来。那个人半坐着，半靠在角落沙发上的一堆枕头上。他的脸和咖啡馆里的一样，是用黄蜡铸造的，既不是死人的暗淡、苍白的颜色——而是一种阳刚的苍白——也不是不健康的，你会称之为；；但就像一个在矿井工作或在潮湿气候下上夜班的强壮男人。艾默里仔细地打量了他，然后他就可以按照某种方式把他画下来，连最简单的细节都画出来。他的嘴就是那种所谓坦率的，他那双灰色的眼睛沉稳地慢慢地从他们中的一只移到另一只，带着一丝疑问的表情。艾默里注意到他的双手。它们一点也不好，但它们具有多才多艺和微弱的力量……它们是紧张的手，轻轻地沿着垫子坐着，不断地移动，伴随着小而生涩的打开和关闭。然后，突然，艾默里察觉到了双脚，血液涌上头部，他意识到自己很害怕。脚完全不对劲……有一种他感觉而不是知道的不对劲……这就像一个好女人的弱点，或者缎子上的血;这是那些可怕的不协调之一，会动摇大脑深处的一些小东西。他没有穿鞋子，而是穿着一种半软皮鞋，尖头的，就像十四世纪人们穿的鞋子一样，而且小端卷曲起来。它们是深棕色的，他的脚趾似乎一直填满它们……它们可怕得无法形容……

He must have said something, or looked something, for Axia’s voice came out of the void with a strange goodness.
他肯定说了些什么，或者看上去有些什么，因为阿克夏的声音从虚空中传出，带着一种奇异的善意。

“Well, look at Amory! Poor old Amory’s sick—old head going ’round?”
“好吧，看看艾默里！可怜的老艾默里病了——老头昏昏沉沉的？”

“Look at that man!” cried Amory, pointing toward the corner divan.
“看看那个男人！”艾默里指着角落里的沙发喊道。

“You mean that purple zebra!” shrieked Axia facetiously. “Ooo-ee! Amory’s got a purple zebra watching him!”
“你是说那只紫色斑马！”阿克娅滑稽地尖叫道。 “噢噢噢！艾默里有一只紫色斑马在看着他！”

Sloane laughed vacantly.
斯隆茫然地笑了笑。

“Ole zebra gotcha, Amory?”
“斑马明白了吗，艾默里？”

There was a silence.... The man regarded Amory quizzically.... Then the human voices fell faintly on his ear:
一阵沉默……男人疑惑地看着艾默里……然后，人声微弱地落在他耳边：

“Thought you weren’t drinking,” remarked Axia sardonically, but her voice was good to hear; the whole divan that held the man was alive; alive like heat waves over asphalt, like wriggling worms....
“我以为你没喝酒。”阿霞讽刺地说，但她的声音很好听。那个男人的整个沙发都还活着。像沥青上的热浪一样活着，像蠕动的蠕虫一样......

“Come back! Come back!” Axia’s arm fell on his. “Amory, dear, you aren’t going, Amory!” He was half-way to the door.
“回来！回来！”阿克夏的手臂落在了他的身上。 “艾默里，亲爱的，你不能走，艾默里！”他已经走到门口了。

“Come on, Amory, stick ’th us!”
“来吧，艾默里，坚持我们！”

“Sick, are you?”
“你生病了吗？”

“Sit down a second!”
“请坐一下！”

“Take some water.”
“拿点水来。”

“Take a little brandy....”
“喝一点白兰地……”

The elevator was close, and the colored boy was half asleep, paled to a livid bronze... Axia’s beseeching voice floated down the shaft. Those feet... those feet...
电梯已经很近了，黑人男孩正处于半睡半醒的状态，脸色苍白成青铜色……阿霞哀求的声音从电梯井里传来。那脚……那脚……

As they settled to the lower floor the feet came into view in the sickly electric light of the paved hall.
当他们落座到下层时，在铺砌的大厅里病态的电光下，他们的脚映入眼帘。

IN THE ALLEY
在巷子里

Down the long street came the moon, and Amory turned his back on it and walked. Ten, fifteen steps away sounded the footsteps. They were like a slow dripping, with just the slightest insistence in their fall. Amory’s shadow lay, perhaps, ten feet ahead of him, and soft shoes was presumably that far behind. With the instinct of a child Amory edged in under the blue darkness of the white buildings, cleaving the moonlight for haggard seconds, once bursting into a slow run with clumsy stumblings. After that he stopped suddenly; he must keep hold, he thought. His lips were dry and he licked them.
月亮沿着长长的街道升起，艾默里背对月亮，继续前行。十、十五步外，响起了脚步声。它们就像是缓缓的滴落，落下时带着一丝丝的坚持。艾默里的影子大概就在他前面十英尺处，而软鞋大概就在他后面那么远的地方。艾默里怀着孩子般的本能，在白色建筑的蓝色黑暗下慢慢走近，在月光下度过了憔悴的几秒钟，一度笨拙地跌跌撞撞地缓慢奔跑。说完，他突然停了下来。他必须坚持下去，他想。他的嘴唇干燥，他舔了舔它们。

If he met any one good—were there any good people left in the world or did they all live in white apartment-houses now? Was every one followed in the moonlight? But if he met some one good who’d know what he meant and hear this damned scuffle... then the scuffling grew suddenly nearer, and a black cloud settled over the moon. When again the pale sheen skimmed the cornices, it was almost beside him, and Amory thought he heard a quiet breathing. Suddenly he realized that the footsteps were not behind, had never been behind, they were ahead and he was not eluding but following... following. He began to run, blindly, his heart knocking heavily, his hands clinched. Far ahead a black dot showed itself, resolved slowly into a human shape. But Amory was beyond that now; he turned off the street and darted into an alley, narrow and dark and smelling of old rottenness. He twisted down a long, sinuous blackness, where the moonlight was shut away except for tiny glints and patches... then suddenly sank panting into a corner by a fence, exhausted. The steps ahead stopped, and he could hear them shift slightly with a continuous motion, like waves around a dock.
如果他遇到了什么好人的话——世界上还有好人吗？还是他们现在都住在白色的公寓里了？月光下每个人都被跟踪了吗？但如果他遇到了一个知道他的意思的好人，并听到了这场该死的混战……那么混战会突然变得更近，一朵黑云落在月亮上。当苍白的光芒再次掠过飞檐时，它几乎就在他身边，艾默里觉得他听到了安静的呼吸声。突然他发现脚步声不是在后面，从来没有在后面，而是在前面，他不是在躲避，而是在追……追。他开始盲目地奔跑，心脏重重地跳动，双手紧握。前方远处出现了一个黑点，慢慢地变成了人形。但艾默里现在已经超越了这个范围。他转身离开街道，冲进一条小巷，巷子又窄又黑，散发着旧腐烂的味道。他扭过一条长长的、蜿蜒的黑暗，那里的月光被遮住了，只剩下微小的闪光和斑点……然后突然气喘吁吁地倒在栅栏旁的一个角落里，筋疲力尽。前面的脚步停了下来，他能听见脚步声在不断地轻微移动，就像码头周围的波浪一样。

He put his face in his hands and covered eyes and ears as well as he could. During all this time it never occurred to him that he was delirious or drunk. He had a sense of reality such as material things could never give him. His intellectual content seemed to submit passively to it, and it fitted like a glove everything that had ever preceded it in his life. It did not muddle him. It was like a problem whose answer he knew on paper, yet whose solution he was unable to grasp. He was far beyond horror. He had sunk through the thin surface of that, now moved in a region where the feet and the fear of white walls were real, living things, things he must accept. Only far inside his soul a little fire leaped and cried that something was pulling him down, trying to get him inside a door and slam it behind him. After that door was slammed there would be only footfalls and white buildings in the moonlight, and perhaps he would be one of the footfalls.
他用手捂住脸，尽可能地遮住眼睛和耳朵。在这段时间里，他从未想到自己是神志不清或喝醉了。他有一种物质永远无法给他的真实感。他的知识内容似乎被动地屈服于它，它就像手套一样适合他生命中之前的一切。这并没有让他感到困惑。这就像一个问题，他在纸上知道答案，但他无法掌握其解决方案。他已经远远超出了恐惧的范围。他已经沉入了那薄薄的表面，现在进入了一个区域，在那里，脚和对白墙的恐惧是真实的、有生命的东西，他必须接受的东西。只是在他灵魂的深处，有一团小火在跳跃，叫喊着有什么东西把他拉下来，试图把他带进一扇门，然后把门关在身后。那扇门关上之后，只剩下脚步声和月光下的白色建筑，也许他就是其中之一。

During the five or ten minutes he waited in the shadow of the fence, there was somehow this fire... that was as near as he could name it afterward. He remembered calling aloud:
在他在栅栏阴影下等待的五到十分钟里，不知怎的，发生了这场火灾……那是他事后所能形容的最接近的火灾。他记得大声喊道：

“I want some one stupid. Oh, send some one stupid!” This to the black fence opposite him, in whose shadows the footsteps shuffled ... shuffled. He supposed “stupid” and “good” had become somehow intermingled through previous association. When he called thus it was not an act of will at all—will had turned him away from the moving figure in the street; it was almost instinct that called, just the pile on pile of inherent tradition or some wild prayer from way over the night. Then something clanged like a low gong struck at a distance, and before his eyes a face flashed over the two feet, a face pale and distorted with a sort of infinite evil that twisted it like flame in the wind; but he knew, for the half instant that the gong tanged and hummed, that it was the face of Dick Humbird.
“我想要一个傻瓜。噢，派一个傻瓜来吧！”这是他对面的黑色栅栏，脚步声在栅栏的阴影中拖着……拖着脚步。他认为“愚蠢”和“好”已经通过之前的联想以某种方式混合在一起了。当他这样叫的时候，这根本不是一种意志的行为——意志让他远离了街上移动的人影；他的意志已经使他远离了街上那个移动的人影。这几乎是本能的召唤，只是一堆堆固有的传统或一夜之间的疯狂祈祷。然后远处有什么东西像低沉的锣声一样叮当作响，他的眼前闪现出一张脸在他的两只脚上闪现，这张脸苍白而扭曲，被一种无限的邪恶扭曲着，就像风中的火焰一样。但在锣声响起并嗡嗡作响的那一瞬间，他知道那是迪克·亨伯德的脸。

Minutes later he sprang to his feet, realizing dimly that there was no more sound, and that he was alone in the graying alley. It was cold, and he started on a steady run for the light that showed the street at the other end.
几分钟后，他跳了起来，模模糊糊地意识到再也没有声音了，灰暗的小巷里只剩下他一个人了。天气很冷，他开始稳步跑向另一端街道的灯光。

AT THE WINDOW
在窗口

It was late morning when he woke and found the telephone beside his bed in the hotel tolling frantically, and remembered that he had left word to be called at eleven. Sloane was snoring heavily, his clothes in a pile by his bed. They dressed and ate breakfast in silence, and then sauntered out to get some air. Amory’s mind was working slowly, trying to assimilate what had happened and separate from the chaotic imagery that stacked his memory the bare shreds of truth. If the morning had been cold and gray he could have grasped the reins of the past in an instant, but it was one of those days that New York gets sometimes in May, when the air on Fifth Avenue is a soft, light wine. How much or how little Sloane remembered Amory did not care to know; he apparently had none of the nervous tension that was gripping Amory and forcing his mind back and forth like a shrieking saw.
当他醒来时，已经是凌晨了，发现酒店床边的电话在疯狂地响着，他记起自己已经留了言，要在十一点打电话。斯隆鼾声如雷，衣服堆在床边。他们默默地穿好衣服、吃早餐，然后漫步出去呼吸新鲜空气。艾默里的大脑正在缓慢地运转，试图吸收所发生的事情，并从那些堆积在他记忆中的混乱意象中分离出赤裸裸的真相碎片。如果早晨是寒冷而灰暗的，他可能会立刻抓住过去的缰绳，但这是纽约五月有时会遇到的日子之一，此时第五大道的空气是一种柔和的淡酒味。斯隆并不想知道艾默里还记得多少。显然，他没有那种像一把尖叫的锯子一样紧紧抓住艾默里、强迫他的思绪来回转动的紧张情绪。

Then Broadway broke upon them, and with the babel of noise and the painted faces a sudden sickness rushed over Amory.
然后百老汇向他们袭来，伴随着喧嚣的喧嚣和涂满油漆的面孔，艾默里突然感到一阵恶心。

“For God’s sake, let’s go back! Let’s get off of this—this place!”
“看在上帝的份上，我们还是回去吧！我们离开这个——这个地方吧！”

Sloane looked at him in amazement.
斯隆惊讶地看着他。

“What do you mean?”
“你是什么意思？”

“This street, it’s ghastly! Come on! let’s get back to the Avenue!”
“这条街，太阴森了！快点！我们回大道吧！”

“Do you mean to say,” said Sloane stolidly, “that ’cause you had some sort of indigestion that made you act like a maniac last night, you’re never coming on Broadway again?”
“你的意思是说，”斯隆冷漠地说，“因为你昨晚得了某种消化不良，表现得像个疯子，所以你再也不会来百老汇了？”

Simultaneously Amory classed him with the crowd, and he seemed no longer Sloane of the debonair humor and the happy personality, but only one of the evil faces that whirled along the turbid stream.
与此同时，艾默里把他归为人群，他似乎不再是斯隆那样的温文尔雅的幽默和快乐的性格，而只是沿着浑浊的溪流旋转的邪恶面孔之一。

“Man!” he shouted so loud that the people on the corner turned and followed them with their eyes, “it’s filthy, and if you can’t see it, you’re filthy, too!”
“男人！”他喊得那么大声，街角的人都转过头来，眼睛跟着他们：“肮脏，如果你看不到它，你也肮脏！”

“I can’t help it,” said Sloane doggedly. “What’s the matter with you? Old remorse getting you? You’d be in a fine state if you’d gone through with our little party.”
“我无能为力，”斯隆固执地说。 “你怎么了？旧日的悔恨让你伤心吗？如果你参加了我们的小聚会，你的状态就会很好。”

“I’m going, Fred,” said Amory slowly. His knees were shaking under him, and he knew that if he stayed another minute on this street he would keel over where he stood. “I’ll be at the Vanderbilt for lunch.” And he strode rapidly off and turned over to Fifth Avenue. Back at the hotel he felt better, but as he walked into the barber-shop, intending to get a head massage, the smell of the powders and tonics brought back Axia’s sidelong, suggestive smile, and he left hurriedly. In the doorway of his room a sudden blackness flowed around him like a divided river.
“我要走了，弗雷德。”艾默里慢慢地说。他的膝盖在他身下颤抖，他知道如果他在这条街上再多待一分钟，他就会在原地倒下。 “我会去范德比尔特吃午饭。”他大步走开，转向第五大道。回到酒店，他感觉好多了，但当他走进理发店，打算做个头部按摩时，扑鼻的药粉和滋补品的味道又勾起了阿霞那斜视的暗示性微笑，他匆匆离开了。房间门口突然一片黑暗，像一条分流的河流一样在他周围流动。

When he came to himself he knew that several hours had passed. He pitched onto the bed and rolled over on his face with a deadly fear that he was going mad. He wanted people, people, some one sane and stupid and good. He lay for he knew not how long without moving. He could feel the little hot veins on his forehead standing out, and his terror had hardened on him like plaster. He felt he was passing up again through the thin crust of horror, and now only could he distinguish the shadowy twilight he was leaving. He must have fallen asleep again, for when he next recollected himself he had paid the hotel bill and was stepping into a taxi at the door. It was raining torrents.
当他清醒过来时，他知道已经过去了几个小时。他倒在床上，翻了个身，生出一种极度的恐惧，生怕自己要疯了。他想要人，人，一些理智、愚蠢、善良的人。他不知道躺了多久，一动不动。他能感觉到额头上的细小滚烫的青筋突出，他的恐惧像石膏一样凝固在他身上。他感觉自己再次穿过薄薄的恐怖外壳，现在他只能分辨出他正在离开的阴暗暮色。他肯定又睡着了，因为当他再次回过神来时，他已经付了酒店账单，正踏上门口的一辆出租车。当时正下着倾盆大雨。

On the train for Princeton he saw no one he knew, only a crowd of fagged-looking Philadelphians. The presence of a painted woman across the aisle filled him with a fresh burst of sickness and he changed to another car, tried to concentrate on an article in a popular magazine. He found himself reading the same paragraphs over and over, so he abandoned this attempt and leaning over wearily pressed his hot forehead against the damp window-pane. The car, a smoker, was hot and stuffy with most of the smells of the state’s alien population; he opened a window and shivered against the cloud of fog that drifted in over him. The two hours’ ride were like days, and he nearly cried aloud with joy when the towers of Princeton loomed up beside him and the yellow squares of light filtered through the blue rain.
在开往普林斯顿的火车上，他没有看到任何认识的人，只有一群看上去疲惫不堪的费城人。过道对面出现了一位彩绘女人，这让他感到一阵恶心，于是他换上另一辆车，试图集中精力阅读一本流行杂志上的一篇文章。他发现自己一遍又一遍地读着同样的段落，所以他放弃了这个尝试，疲倦地将滚烫的额头靠在潮湿的窗玻璃上。车里冒着烟，又热又闷，充满了该州外来人口的大部分气味。他打开一扇窗户，在笼罩在他头顶的雾气中瑟瑟发抖。两个小时的车程就像过了几天，当普林斯顿的塔楼在他身边隐约可见，黄色的光透过蓝色的雨滴时，他几乎高兴得哭了。

Tom was standing in the centre of the room, pensively relighting a cigar-stub. Amory fancied he looked rather relieved on seeing him.
汤姆站在房间中央，若有所思地重新点燃雪茄头。艾默里觉得他一看到他就显得松了口气。

“Had a hell of a dream about you last night,” came in the cracked voice through the cigar smoke. “I had an idea you were in some trouble.”
“昨晚做了一个关于你的噩梦。”雪茄烟雾中传来沙哑的声音。 “我知道你遇到麻烦了。”

“Don’t tell me about it!” Amory almost shrieked. “Don’t say a word; I’m tired and pepped out.”
“别告诉我这件事！”艾默里几乎尖叫起来。 “别说话；我很累，而且精力充沛。”

Tom looked at him queerly and then sank into a chair and opened his Italian note-book. Amory threw his coat and hat on the floor, loosened his collar, and took a Wells novel at random from the shelf. “Wells is sane,” he thought, “and if he won’t do I’ll read Rupert Brooke.”
汤姆奇怪地看着他，然后坐到椅子上，打开意大利笔记本。艾默里把外套和帽子扔在地上，松开衣领，从书架上随意拿出一本威尔斯的小说。 “威尔斯是理智的，”他想，“如果他不这样做，我就读鲁珀特·布鲁克的书。”

Half an hour passed. Outside the wind came up, and Amory started as the wet branches moved and clawed with their finger-nails at the window-pane. Tom was deep in his work, and inside the room only the occasional scratch of a match or the rustle of leather as they shifted in their chairs broke the stillness. Then like a zigzag of lightning came the change. Amory sat bolt upright, frozen cold in his chair. Tom was looking at him with his mouth drooping, eyes fixed.
半个小时过去了。外面起风了，潮湿的树枝移动着，指甲刮着窗玻璃，艾默里吃了一惊。汤姆正在埋头工作，房间里只有偶尔划过的火柴声或他们在椅子上移动时皮革发出的沙沙声打破了寂静。然后，变化就像锯齿状的闪电一样发生了。艾默里笔直地坐在椅子上，浑身冰冷。汤姆低垂着嘴，眼睛盯着他。

“God help us!” Amory cried.
“上帝帮助我们！”艾默里哭了。

“Oh, my heavens!” shouted Tom, “look behind!” Quick as a flash Amory whirled around. He saw nothing but the dark window-pane. “It’s gone now,” came Tom’s voice after a second in a still terror. “Something was looking at you.”
“哦，天哪！”汤姆喊道：“看后面！”艾默里快速旋转。除了黑暗的窗玻璃之外，他什么也没看见。 “现在它不见了。”过了一会儿，汤姆的声音仍然充满恐惧。 “有东西在看着你。”

Trembling violently, Amory dropped into his chair again.
艾默里剧烈地颤抖着，再次跌坐在椅子上。

“I’ve got to tell you,” he said. “I’ve had one hell of an experience. I think I’ve—I’ve seen the devil or—something like him. What face did you just see?—or no,” he added quickly, “don’t tell me!”
“我必须告诉你，”他说。 “我有过一次地狱般的经历。我想我——我见过魔鬼或者——像他一样的东西。你刚刚看到了什么脸？——或者没有，”他很快补充道，“别告诉我！”

And he gave Tom the story. It was midnight when he finished, and after that, with all lights burning, two sleepy, shivering boys read to each other from “The New Machiavelli,” until dawn came up out of Witherspoon Hall, and the Princetonian fell against the door, and the May birds hailed the sun on last night’s rain.
他把这个故事告诉了汤姆。当他完成时已是午夜，之后，所有的灯都亮了，两个昏昏欲睡、瑟瑟发抖的男孩互相朗读《新马基雅维利》，直到黎明从威瑟斯彭大厅出来，普林斯顿大学的学生倒在门上，然后五月的鸟儿在昨晚的雨中欢呼太阳。





CHAPTER 4. Narcissus Off Duty
第 4 章 水仙下班

During Princeton’s transition period, that is, during Amory’s last two years there, while he saw it change and broaden and live up to its Gothic beauty by better means than night parades, certain individuals arrived who stirred it to its plethoric depths. Some of them had been freshmen, and wild freshmen, with Amory; some were in the class below; and it was in the beginning of his last year and around small tables at the Nassau Inn that they began questioning aloud the institutions that Amory and countless others before him had questioned so long in secret. First, and partly by accident, they struck on certain books, a definite type of biographical novel that Amory christened “quest” books. In the “quest” book the hero set off in life armed with the best weapons and avowedly intending to use them as such weapons are usually used, to push their possessors ahead as selfishly and blindly as possible, but the heroes of the “quest” books discovered that there might be a more magnificent use for them. “None Other Gods,” “Sinister Street,” and “The Research Magnificent” were examples of such books; it was the latter of these three that gripped Burne Holiday and made him wonder in the beginning of senior year how much it was worth while being a diplomatic autocrat around his club on Prospect Avenue and basking in the high lights of class office. It was distinctly through the channels of aristocracy that Burne found his way. Amory, through Kerry, had had a vague drifting acquaintance with him, but not until January of senior year did their friendship commence.
在普林斯顿的过渡时期，即艾默里在那里的最后两年，当他看到普林斯顿以比夜间游行更好的方式改变和扩大并实现其哥特式美丽时，某些人的到来将其搅动到了过度的深度。他们中有些人是艾默里的新生，而且是狂野的新生。有些人在下面的班级；正是在他的最后一年年初，他们围坐在拿骚旅馆的小桌子旁，开始大声质疑艾默里和他之前无数其他人长期以来秘密质疑的机构。首先，部分出于偶然，他们偶然发现了某些书籍，一种特定类型的传记小说，艾默里将其命名为“探索”书籍。在《探索》一书中，英雄带着最好的武器出发了，并公开地打算使用这些武器，就像通常使用的那样，以尽可能自私和盲目地推动拥有者前进，但《探索》的英雄书籍发现它们可能有更伟大的用途。 《没有其他的神》、《险恶的街道》和《伟大的研究》就是此类书籍的例子；正是这三者中的后者吸引了伯恩·霍勒迪，让他在高四开始时想知道，在展望大道的俱乐部里当一名外交独裁者，享受班级办公室的光鲜亮丽，到底值多少钱。伯恩显然是通过贵族渠道找到了自己的道路。艾默里通过凯瑞与他有了一些模糊的认识，但直到高年级一月他们的友谊才开始。

“Heard the latest?” said Tom, coming in late one drizzly evening with that triumphant air he always wore after a successful conversational bout.
“听说最新消息了吗？”汤姆说，他在一个下着毛毛细雨的傍晚回来时，带着他在一场成功的谈话后总是表现出的胜利神情。

“No. Somebody flunked out? Or another ship sunk?”
“不。有人被淘汰了？还是另一艘船沉没了？”

“Worse than that. About one-third of the junior class are going to resign from their clubs.”
“比那更糟糕。大约三分之一的少年班将退出俱乐部。”

“What!”
“什么！”

“Actual fact!”
“事实真相！”

“Why!”
“为什么！”

“Spirit of reform and all that. Burne Holiday is behind it. The club presidents are holding a meeting to-night to see if they can find a joint means of combating it.”
“改革精神等等。伯恩假期就在背后。俱乐部主席今晚将召开会议，看看是否能找到共同应对这一问题的方法。”

“Well, what’s the idea of the thing?”
“嗯，这件事的想法是什么？”

“Oh, clubs injurious to Princeton democracy; cost a lot; draw social lines, take time; the regular line you get sometimes from disappointed sophomores. Woodrow thought they should be abolished and all that.”
“哦，俱乐部损害了普林斯顿的民主；花费很多；划定社交界限，需要时间；有时你会从失望的二年级学生那里接到这样的电话。伍德罗认为它们应该被废除等等。”

“But this is the real thing?”
“但这就是真的吗？”

“Absolutely. I think it’ll go through.”
“绝对地。我想事情会过去的。”

“For Pete’s sake, tell me more about it.”
“看在皮特的份上，告诉我更多有关这件事的信息。”

“Well,” began Tom, “it seems that the idea developed simultaneously in several heads. I was talking to Burne awhile ago, and he claims that it’s a logical result if an intelligent person thinks long enough about the social system. They had a ‘discussion crowd’ and the point of abolishing the clubs was brought up by some one—everybody there leaped at it—it had been in each one’s mind, more or less, and it just needed a spark to bring it out.”
“嗯，”汤姆开始说道，“看来这个想法是同时在几个头脑中产生的。不久前我和伯恩交谈过，他声称如果一个聪明的人对社会制度思考足够长的时间，这是一个合乎逻辑的结果。他们有一群“讨论人群”，废除俱乐部的观点是由某人提出的——每个人都欣喜若狂——每个人或多或少都有这个想法，只需要一个火花就能把它带出来。 ”

“Fine! I swear I think it’ll be most entertaining. How do they feel up at Cap and Gown?”
“美好的！我发誓我认为这将是最有趣的。他们在 Cap and Gown 感觉如何？”

“Wild, of course. Every one’s been sitting and arguing and swearing and getting mad and getting sentimental and getting brutal. It’s the same at all the clubs; I’ve been the rounds. They get one of the radicals in the corner and fire questions at him.”
“当然是狂野的。每个人都坐着争论、咒骂、生气、变得多愁善感、变得残酷。所有俱乐部都一样；我一直在巡视。他们把一名激进分子带到角落里并向他提出问题。”

“How do the radicals stand up?”
“激进分子如何站起来？”

“Oh, moderately well. Burne’s a damn good talker, and so obviously sincere that you can’t get anywhere with him. It’s so evident that resigning from his club means so much more to him than preventing it does to us that I felt futile when I argued; finally took a position that was brilliantly neutral. In fact, I believe Burne thought for a while that he’d converted me.”
“哦，还算不错。伯恩是一个非常健谈的人，而且显然很真诚，你和他在一起不会有任何进展。很明显，从他的俱乐部辞职对他来说比阻止它对我们来说意义重大，所以当我争论时我感到徒劳；最终采取了非常中立的立场。事实上，我相信伯恩一度认为他已经改变了我。”

“And you say almost a third of the junior class are going to resign?”
“你说几乎三分之一的初中生都会辞职？”

“Call it a fourth and be safe.”
“称之为第四，注意安全。”

“Lord—who’d have thought it possible!”
“主啊——谁会想到这可能！”

There was a brisk knock at the door, and Burne himself came in. “Hello, Amory—hello, Tom.”
一阵轻快的敲门声响起，伯恩本人走了进来。“你好，艾默里——你好，汤姆。”

Amory rose.
艾默里站了起来。

“’Evening, Burne. Don’t mind if I seem to rush; I’m going to Renwick’s.”
“‘晚上好，伯恩。如果我看起来很匆忙，请不要介意；我要去伦威克。”

Burne turned to him quickly.
伯恩迅速转向他。

“You probably know what I want to talk to Tom about, and it isn’t a bit private. I wish you’d stay.”
“你可能知道我想和汤姆谈论什么，而且这不是私人的。我希望你留下来。”

“I’d be glad to.” Amory sat down again, and as Burne perched on a table and launched into argument with Tom, he looked at this revolutionary more carefully than he ever had before. Broad-browed and strong-chinned, with a fineness in the honest gray eyes that were like Kerry’s, Burne was a man who gave an immediate impression of bigness and security—stubborn, that was evident, but his stubbornness wore no stolidity, and when he had talked for five minutes Amory knew that this keen enthusiasm had in it no quality of dilettantism.
“我非常乐意。”艾默里再次坐下，当伯恩坐在桌子上与汤姆争论时，他比以往任何时候都更加仔细地观察这位革命者。伯恩有着宽阔的眉毛和坚挺的下巴，诚实的灰色眼睛里有一种优雅，就像凯里的一样，伯恩是一个给人一种高大和安全感的人——固执，这是显而易见的，但他的固执并不显得冷漠，当他已经讲了五分钟了。艾默里知道，这种强烈的热情并不带有业余性质。

The intense power Amory felt later in Burne Holiday differed from the admiration he had had for Humbird. This time it began as purely a mental interest. With other men of whom he had thought as primarily first-class, he had been attracted first by their personalities, and in Burne he missed that immediate magnetism to which he usually swore allegiance. But that night Amory was struck by Burne’s intense earnestness, a quality he was accustomed to associate only with the dread stupidity, and by the great enthusiasm that struck dead chords in his heart. Burne stood vaguely for a land Amory hoped he was drifting toward—and it was almost time that land was in sight. Tom and Amory and Alec had reached an impasse; never did they seem to have new experiences in common, for Tom and Alec had been as blindly busy with their committees and boards as Amory had been blindly idling, and the things they had for dissection—college, contemporary personality and the like—they had hashed and rehashed for many a frugal conversational meal.
艾默里后来在伯恩假日感受到的强烈力量与他对亨伯德的钦佩不同。这次一开始纯粹是出于精神兴趣。和其他他认为主要是一流的人在一起时，他首先被他们的个性所吸引，而在伯恩，他错过了他通常宣誓效忠的那种直接的吸引力。但那天晚上，艾默里对伯恩的强烈真诚感到震惊，他习惯于将这种品质与可怕的愚蠢联系在一起，并且对他内心深处的巨大热情感到震惊。伯恩模糊地代表着艾默里希望他漂向的那片土地——而那片土地快要出现在眼前了。汤姆、艾默里和亚历克陷入了僵局。他们似乎从未有过新的共同经历，因为汤姆和亚历克一直盲目地忙于他们的委员会和董事会，就像艾默里盲目地无所事事一样，而他们所拥有的可供剖析的东西——大学、当代人物等等——他们都有为许多节俭的谈话餐而反复讨论。

That night they discussed the clubs until twelve, and, in the main, they agreed with Burne. To the roommates it did not seem such a vital subject as it had in the two years before, but the logic of Burne’s objections to the social system dovetailed so completely with everything they had thought, that they questioned rather than argued, and envied the sanity that enabled this man to stand out so against all traditions.
那天晚上，他们讨论了俱乐部的事，直到十二点，大体上，他们同意伯恩的观点。对于室友来说，这似乎不像两年前那样是一个重要的话题，但伯恩反对社会制度的逻辑与他们所想的一切如此吻合，他们质疑而不是争论，并羡慕理智的理智。这使得这个人能够在所有传统中脱颖而出。

Then Amory branched off and found that Burne was deep in other things as well. Economics had interested him and he was turning socialist. Pacifism played in the back of his mind, and he read The Masses and Lyoff Tolstoi faithfully.
然后艾默里又发现伯恩也对其他事情很着迷。他对经济学感兴趣，并且正在转向社会主义。和平主义在他的脑海中盘旋，他忠实地阅读了《群众》和利夫·托尔斯泰。

“How about religion?” Amory asked him.
“那么宗教呢？”艾默里问他。

“Don’t know. I’m in a muddle about a lot of things—I’ve just discovered that I’ve a mind, and I’m starting to read.”
“不知道。我对很多事情都一头雾水——我刚刚发现我有头脑，而且我开始读书了。”

“Read what?”
“读什么？”

“Everything. I have to pick and choose, of course, but mostly things to make me think. I’m reading the four gospels now, and the ‘Varieties of Religious Experience.’”
“一切。当然，我必须做出选择，但主要是让我思考的事情。我现在正在读四本福音书，还有《宗教体验的多样性》。”

“What chiefly started you?”
“主要是什么让你开始的？”

“Wells, I guess, and Tolstoi, and a man named Edward Carpenter. I’ve been reading for over a year now—on a few lines, on what I consider the essential lines.”
“我猜是威尔斯，还有托尔斯泰，还有一个名叫爱德华·卡彭特的人。我已经读了一年多了——读了几行，读了我认为最重要的几行。”

“Poetry?”
“诗歌？”

“Well, frankly, not what you call poetry, or for your reasons—you two write, of course, and look at things differently. Whitman is the man that attracts me.”
“好吧，坦率地说，这不是你们所谓的诗歌，也不是出于你们的原因——当然，你们两个都在写作，对事物的看法也不同。惠特曼是一个吸引我的人。”

“Whitman?”

“Yes; he’s a definite ethical force.”
“是的;他是一股绝对的道德力量。”

“Well, I’m ashamed to say that I’m a blank on the subject of Whitman. How about you, Tom?”
“好吧，我很惭愧地说我对惠特曼这个话题一无所知。你呢，汤姆？”

Tom nodded sheepishly.
汤姆不好意思地点点头。

“Well,” continued Burne, “you may strike a few poems that are tiresome, but I mean the mass of his work. He’s tremendous—like Tolstoi. They both look things in the face, and, somehow, different as they are, stand for somewhat the same things.”
“好吧，”伯恩继续说道，“你可能会读到一些令人厌烦的诗，但我指的是他的大量作品。他很伟大——就像托尔斯泰一样。他们都直面事物，而且，不知何故，尽管它们有所不同，但代表的东西有些相同。”

“You have me stumped, Burne,” Amory admitted. “I’ve read ‘Anna Karenina’ and the ‘Kreutzer Sonata’ of course, but Tolstoi is mostly in the original Russian as far as I’m concerned.”
“你把我难住了，伯恩，”艾默里承认。 “我当然读过《安娜·卡列尼娜》和《克莱采奏鸣曲》，但就我而言，托尔斯泰主要是俄语原著。”

“He’s the greatest man in hundreds of years,” cried Burne enthusiastically. “Did you ever see a picture of that shaggy old head of his?”
“他是数百年来最伟大的人，”伯恩热情地喊道。 “你见过他那张毛茸茸的老脑袋的照片吗？”

They talked until three, from biology to organized religion, and when Amory crept shivering into bed it was with his mind aglow with ideas and a sense of shock that some one else had discovered the path he might have followed. Burne Holiday was so evidently developing—and Amory had considered that he was doing the same. He had fallen into a deep cynicism over what had crossed his path, plotted the imperfectability of man and read Shaw and Chesterton enough to keep his mind from the edges of decadence—now suddenly all his mental processes of the last year and a half seemed stale and futile—a petty consummation of himself... and like a sombre background lay that incident of the spring before, that filled half his nights with a dreary terror and made him unable to pray. He was not even a Catholic, yet that was the only ghost of a code that he had, the gaudy, ritualistic, paradoxical Catholicism whose prophet was Chesterton, whose claqueurs were such reformed rakes of literature as Huysmans and Bourget, whose American sponsor was Ralph Adams Cram, with his adulation of thirteenth-century cathedrals—a Catholicism which Amory found convenient and ready-made, without priest or sacraments or sacrifice.
他们一直聊到三点，从生物学到有组织的宗教，当艾默里瑟瑟发抖地爬上床时，他的脑子里充满了想法，并感到震惊，因为有人发现了他可能会走的道路。伯恩假日的发展如此明显——艾默里认为他也在做同样的事情。他对自己所经历的事情陷入了深深的愤世嫉俗，描绘了人的不完美，并阅读了肖和切斯特顿的作品，足以让他的思想远离颓废的边缘——现在突然之间，他过去一年半的所有心理过程似乎都变得陈旧了。毫无意义——他自己的小小成就……而春天的那件事就像一个阴暗的背景，让他半个夜晚都充满了沉闷的恐惧，让他无法祈祷。他甚至不是天主教徒，但这却是他所拥有的唯一的准则幽灵，俗气、仪式化、自相矛盾的天主教，它的先知是切斯特顿，它的鼓吹者是于斯曼斯和布尔热这样改革过的文学流氓，它的美国赞助者是拉尔夫。亚当斯·克拉姆（Adams Cram）对十三世纪的大教堂表示崇拜——艾默里认为这是一种方便且现成的天主教，不需要牧师、圣礼或祭祀。

He could not sleep, so he turned on his reading-lamp and, taking down the “Kreutzer Sonata,” searched it carefully for the germs of Burne’s enthusiasm. Being Burne was suddenly so much realler than being clever. Yet he sighed... here were other possible clay feet.
他睡不着，于是打开台灯，取下《克莱采奏鸣曲》，仔细地寻找伯恩热情的萌芽。成为伯恩突然变得比聪明更真实了。然而他叹了口气……这里还有其他可能的粘土脚。

He thought back through two years, of Burne as a hurried, nervous freshman, quite submerged in his brother’s personality. Then he remembered an incident of sophomore year, in which Burne had been suspected of the leading role.
他回想起两年前的情景，伯恩是一个匆忙、紧张的新生，完全沉浸在他哥哥的性格中。然后他想起了大二时的一件事，伯恩被怀疑是主角。

Dean Hollister had been heard by a large group arguing with a taxi-driver, who had driven him from the junction. In the course of the altercation the dean remarked that he “might as well buy the taxicab.” He paid and walked off, but next morning he entered his private office to find the taxicab itself in the space usually occupied by his desk, bearing a sign which read “Property of Dean Hollister. Bought and Paid for.”... It took two expert mechanics half a day to dissemble it into its minutest parts and remove it, which only goes to prove the rare energy of sophomore humor under efficient leadership.
一大群人听到迪恩·霍利斯特（Dean Hollister）与一名出租车司机发生争执，出租车司机将他从路口载了出来。在争吵过程中，院长说他“还不如买出租车”。他付了钱就走开了，但第二天早上，他进入自己的私人办公室，发现出租车就停在他办公桌通常占据的地方，上面写着“迪恩·霍利斯特的财产”。买了，付了钱。”……两位专业机械师花了半天的时间才把它拆成最细小的部分，然后把它拆下来，这只能证明大二学生在高效的领导下所具有的罕见的幽默能量。

Then again, that very fall, Burne had caused a sensation. A certain Phyllis Styles, an intercollegiate prom-trotter, had failed to get her yearly invitation to the Harvard-Princeton game.
然而，就在那个秋天，伯恩再次引起了轰动。菲利斯·斯泰尔斯（Phyllis Styles）是一名校际舞会运动员，她未能获得每年一度的哈佛-普林斯顿比赛邀请。

Jesse Ferrenby had brought her to a smaller game a few weeks before, and had pressed Burne into service—to the ruination of the latter’s misogyny.
几周前，杰西·费伦比（Jesse Ferrenby）带她参加了一场较小的比赛，并迫使伯恩（Burne）加入，从而破坏了后者的厌女症。

“Are you coming to the Harvard game?” Burne had asked indiscreetly, merely to make conversation.
“你会去看哈佛的比赛吗？”伯恩轻率地问道，只是为了聊聊。

“If you ask me,” cried Phyllis quickly.
“如果你问我的话，”菲利斯迅速喊道。

“Of course I do,” said Burne feebly. He was unversed in the arts of Phyllis, and was sure that this was merely a vapid form of kidding. Before an hour had passed he knew that he was indeed involved. Phyllis had pinned him down and served him up, informed him the train she was arriving by, and depressed him thoroughly. Aside from loathing Phyllis, he had particularly wanted to stag that game and entertain some Harvard friends.
“我当然知道，”伯恩有气无力地说。他不熟悉菲利斯的艺术，并且确信这只是一个无聊的玩笑。不到一个小时，他就知道自己确实参与其中了。菲利斯把他按倒在地，招待他，告诉他她要乘坐的火车，让他彻底沮丧。除了讨厌菲利斯之外，他还特别想玩这场游戏，招待一些哈佛的朋友。

“She’ll see,” he informed a delegation who arrived in his room to josh him. “This will be the last game she ever persuades any young innocent to take her to!”
“她会看到的，”他告诉一个来到他房间取笑他的代表团。 “这将是她说服无辜的年轻人带她参加的最后一场比赛！”

“But, Burne—why did you invite her if you didn’t want her?”
“但是，伯恩——如果你不想要她，为什么还要邀请她呢？”

“Burne, you know you’re secretly mad about her—that’s the real trouble.”
“伯恩，你知道你暗地里对她很生气——这才是真正的麻烦。”

“What can you do, Burne? What can you do against Phyllis?”
“你能做什么，伯恩？你能对菲丽丝做什么？

But Burne only shook his head and muttered threats which consisted largely of the phrase: “She’ll see, she’ll see!”
但伯恩只是摇摇头，低声威胁道：“她会看到的，她会看到的！”

The blithesome Phyllis bore her twenty-five summers gayly from the train, but on the platform a ghastly sight met her eyes. There were Burne and Fred Sloane arrayed to the last dot like the lurid figures on college posters. They had bought flaring suits with huge peg-top trousers and gigantic padded shoulders. On their heads were rakish college hats, pinned up in front and sporting bright orange-and-black bands, while from their celluloid collars blossomed flaming orange ties. They wore black arm-bands with orange “P’s,” and carried canes flying Princeton pennants, the effect completed by socks and peeping handkerchiefs in the same color motifs. On a clanking chain they led a large, angry tom-cat, painted to represent a tiger.
快乐的菲利斯在火车上快乐地度过了二十五个夏天，但在站台上，她的眼前看到了可怕的景象。伯恩和弗雷德·斯隆排到了最后一个点，就像大学海报上那些可怕的人物一样。他们买了喇叭形的西装，搭配大号的阔腿裤和巨大的垫肩。他们头上戴着时髦的大学帽，别在前面，上面有明亮的橙色和黑色带子，赛璐珞领子上挂着火红的橙色领带。他们戴着带有橙色“P”字样的黑色臂章，手握飘扬着普林斯顿三角旗的手杖，袜子和带有相同颜色图案的窥视手帕也达到了这一效果。他们牵着一条叮当响的链子，牵着一只巨大的、愤怒的公猫，上面画着一只老虎。

A good half of the station crowd was already staring at them, torn between horrified pity and riotous mirth, and as Phyllis, with her svelte jaw dropping, approached, the pair bent over and emitted a college cheer in loud, far-carrying voices, thoughtfully adding the name “Phyllis” to the end. She was vociferously greeted and escorted enthusiastically across the campus, followed by half a hundred village urchins—to the stifled laughter of hundreds of alumni and visitors, half of whom had no idea that this was a practical joke, but thought that Burne and Fred were two varsity sports showing their girl a collegiate time.
车站里的一大半人已经盯着他们，在恐惧的怜悯和狂欢的欢笑之间左右为难，当菲利斯，她那苗条的下巴掉下来走近时，两人弯下腰，用响亮而遥远的声音发出大学的欢呼声，深思熟虑地将“菲利斯”这个名字添加到最后。她受到了热烈的欢迎和热情的护送穿过校园，身后跟着半百个村顽童——引来数百名校友和访客的压抑笑声，其中一半人不知道这是一个恶作剧，但认为伯恩和弗雷德是两所大学运动队向他们的女儿展示了大学时光。

Phyllis’s feelings as she was paraded by the Harvard and Princeton stands, where sat dozens of her former devotees, can be imagined. She tried to walk a little ahead, she tried to walk a little behind—but they stayed close, that there should be no doubt whom she was with, talking in loud voices of their friends on the football team, until she could almost hear her acquaintances whispering:
当菲利斯在哈佛和普林斯顿的看台上游行时，那里坐着数十名她以前的信徒，她的感受是可以想象的。她试着往前走一点，她试着往后走一点——但他们离得很近，毫无疑问她和谁在一起，大声地谈论着足球队的朋友们，直到她几乎能听到她的声音。熟人窃窃私语：

“Phyllis Styles must be awfully hard up to have to come with those two.”
“菲利斯·斯泰尔斯一定很辛苦才不得不和这两个人一起去。”

That had been Burne, dynamically humorous, fundamentally serious. From that root had blossomed the energy that he was now trying to orient with progress....
这就是伯恩，充满幽默感，本质上是严肃的。从这个根源中绽放出能量，他现在正试图引导进步......

So the weeks passed and March came and the clay feet that Amory looked for failed to appear. About a hundred juniors and seniors resigned from their clubs in a final fury of righteousness, and the clubs in helplessness turned upon Burne their finest weapon: ridicule. Every one who knew him liked him—but what he stood for (and he began to stand for more all the time) came under the lash of many tongues, until a frailer man than he would have been snowed under.
几周过去了，三月到来了，艾默里寻找的泥脚却没有出现。大约有一百名青少年和老年人在正义的最后愤怒中退出了俱乐部，俱乐部在无助中向伯恩转向了他们最好的武器：嘲笑。每个认识他的人都喜欢他，但他所代表的东西（而且他开始一直代表更多）受到了许多人的批评，直到一个比他更脆弱的人被雪淹没。

“Don’t you mind losing prestige?” asked Amory one night. They had taken to exchanging calls several times a week.
“你不介意失去威望吗？”一天晚上，艾默里问道。他们每周都会通几次电话。

“Of course I don’t. What’s prestige, at best?”
“我当然不知道。威望充其量是什么？”

“Some people say that you’re just a rather original politician.”
“有人说你只是一个很有创意的政治家。”

He roared with laughter.
他哈哈大笑。

“That’s what Fred Sloane told me to-day. I suppose I have it coming.”
“这就是弗雷德·斯隆今天告诉我的。我想我一定会来的。”

One afternoon they dipped into a subject that had interested Amory for a long time—the matter of the bearing of physical attributes on a man’s make-up. Burne had gone into the biology of this, and then:
一天下午，他们深入探讨了艾默里长期以来感兴趣的一个话题——身体特征对男人化妆的影响。伯恩深入研究了这方面的生物学，然后：

“Of course health counts—a healthy man has twice the chance of being good,” he said.
“当然，健康很重要——一个健康的人有双倍的机会成为优秀的人，”他说。

“I don’t agree with you—I don’t believe in ‘muscular Christianity.’”
“我不同意你的观点——我不相信‘强健的基督教’。”

“I do—I believe Christ had great physical vigor.”
“我相信——我相信基督有很强的体力。”

“Oh, no,” Amory protested. “He worked too hard for that. I imagine that when he died he was a broken-down man—and the great saints haven’t been strong.”
“哦，不，”艾默里抗议道。 “他为此付出了太多努力。我想，当他去世时，他是一个崩溃的人——而伟大的圣人也并不坚强。”

“Half of them have.”
“其中一半有。”

“Well, even granting that, I don’t think health has anything to do with goodness; of course, it’s valuable to a great saint to be able to stand enormous strains, but this fad of popular preachers rising on their toes in simulated virility, bellowing that calisthenics will save the world—no, Burne, I can’t go that.”
“好吧，即使承认这一点，我也不认为健康与善良有任何关系。当然，对于一个伟大的圣人来说，能够承受巨大的压力是很有价值的，但是流行的传教士们假装男子气概地站起来，大声喊道健美操将拯救世界——不，伯恩，我不能那样做。 ”

“Well, let’s waive it—we won’t get anywhere, and besides I haven’t quite made up my mind about it myself. Now, here’s something I do know—personal appearance has a lot to do with it.”
“好吧，我们还是放弃吧——我们不会有任何进展，而且我自己也还没有完全下定决心。现在，我确实知道一件事——个人外表与此有很大关系。”

“Coloring?” Amory asked eagerly.
“染色？”艾默里急切地问道。

“Yes.”
“是的。”

“That’s what Tom and I figured,” Amory agreed. “We took the year-books for the last ten years and looked at the pictures of the senior council. I know you don’t think much of that august body, but it does represent success here in a general way. Well, I suppose only about thirty-five per cent of every class here are blonds, are really light—yet two-thirds of every senior council are light. We looked at pictures of ten years of them, mind you; that means that out of every fifteen light-haired men in the senior class one is on the senior council, and of the dark-haired men it’s only one in fifty.”
“汤姆和我就是这么想的，”艾默里同意道。 “我们拿了过去十年的年鉴，还看了高级委员会的照片。我知道你不太看重这个庄严的机构，但它确实代表了总体上的成功。嗯，我想这里每个班级中只有大约百分之三十五是金发碧眼的人，确实是浅色的——但每个高级委员会的三分之二都是浅色的。请注意，我们看了他们十年来的照片；这意味着高级班中每十五名浅发男子中就有一名是高级理事会成员，而黑发男子中只有五十分之一。”

“It’s true,” Burne agreed. “The light-haired man is a higher type, generally speaking. I worked the thing out with the Presidents of the United States once, and found that way over half of them were light-haired—yet think of the preponderant number of brunettes in the race.”
“确实如此，”伯恩同意道。 “一般来说，浅色头发的男人属于高等类型。我曾经和美国总统一起研究过这个问题，发现其中一半以上都是浅色头发——但想想竞选中黑发头发的人占绝大多数。”

“People unconsciously admit it,” said Amory. “You’ll notice a blond person is expected to talk. If a blond girl doesn’t talk we call her a ‘doll’; if a light-haired man is silent he’s considered stupid. Yet the world is full of ‘dark silent men’ and ‘languorous brunettes’ who haven’t a brain in their heads, but somehow are never accused of the dearth.”
“人们无意识地承认这一点，”艾默里说。 “你会注意到一个金发碧眼的人应该说话。如果一个金发女孩不说话，我们就叫她“洋娃娃”；如果一个浅色头发的男人保持沉默，他就会被认为是愚蠢的。然而，世界上充满了‘黑暗沉默的男人’和‘慵懒的黑发女人’，他们的脑子里没有大脑，但不知何故却从未被指责为匮乏。”

“And the large mouth and broad chin and rather big nose undoubtedly make the superior face.”
“而大嘴、宽下巴和相当大的鼻子无疑构成了优越的脸型。”

“I’m not so sure.” Amory was all for classical features.
“我不确定。”艾默里非常喜欢古典特色。

“Oh, yes—I’ll show you,” and Burne pulled out of his desk a photographic collection of heavily bearded, shaggy celebrities—Tolstoi, Whitman, Carpenter, and others.
“哦，是的——我给你看，”伯恩从办公桌上拿出一本留着大胡子、头发蓬乱的名人的摄影集——托尔斯泰、惠特曼、卡彭特等人。

“Aren’t they wonderful?”
“他们不是很棒吗？”

Amory tried politely to appreciate them, and gave up laughingly.
艾默里试图礼貌地感谢他们，但笑着放弃了。

“Burne, I think they’re the ugliest-looking crowd I ever came across. They look like an old man’s home.”
“伯恩，我认为他们是我见过的最丑陋的人群。它们看起来就像一个老人的家。”

“Oh, Amory, look at that forehead on Emerson; look at Tolstoi’s eyes.” His tone was reproachful.
“哦，艾默里，看看艾默生的额头；看看托尔斯泰的眼睛。”他的语气充满责备。

Amory shook his head.
艾默里摇摇头。

“No! Call them remarkable-looking or anything you want—but ugly they certainly are.”
“不！你可以称它们为长相非凡或任何你喜欢的名字——但它们确实很丑。”

Unabashed, Burne ran his hand lovingly across the spacious foreheads, and piling up the pictures put them back in his desk.
伯恩毫不掩饰地用手抚摸着他宽阔的额头，然后把照片堆起来放回办公桌上。

Walking at night was one of his favorite pursuits, and one night he persuaded Amory to accompany him.
夜间散步是他最喜欢的活动之一，有一天晚上，他说服艾默里陪他一起走。

“I hate the dark,” Amory objected. “I didn’t use to—except when I was particularly imaginative, but now, I really do—I’m a regular fool about it.”
“我讨厌黑暗，”艾默里反对道。 “我以前不这样做——除非我特别有想象力，但现在，我真的这样做了——我经常在这方面犯傻。”

“That’s useless, you know.”
“那是没用的，你知道的。”

“Quite possibly.”
“很有可能。”

“We’ll go east,” Burne suggested, “and down that string of roads through the woods.”
“我们会向东走，”伯恩建议，“沿着那条路穿过树林。”

“Doesn’t sound very appealing to me,” admitted Amory reluctantly, “but let’s go.”
“听起来对我来说不太有吸引力，”艾默里不情愿地承认，“但我们走吧。”

They set off at a good gait, and for an hour swung along in a brisk argument until the lights of Princeton were luminous white blots behind them.
他们以良好的步态出发，在激烈的争论中摇摆了一个小时，直到普林斯顿的灯光在他们身后变成了发光的白色斑点。

“Any person with any imagination is bound to be afraid,” said Burne earnestly. “And this very walking at night is one of the things I was afraid about. I’m going to tell you why I can walk anywhere now and not be afraid.”
“任何有想象力的人都一定会感到害怕。”伯恩语重心长地说。 “晚上走路就是我担心的事情之一。我要告诉你为什么我现在可以走到任何地方而不会害怕。”

“Go on,” Amory urged eagerly. They were striding toward the woods, Burne’s nervous, enthusiastic voice warming to his subject.
“继续吧，”艾默里急切地催促道。他们大步走向树林，伯恩紧张而热情的声音让他的话题变得温暖起来。

“I used to come out here alone at night, oh, three months ago, and I always stopped at that cross-road we just passed. There were the woods looming up ahead, just as they do now, there were dogs howling and the shadows and no human sound. Of course, I peopled the woods with everything ghastly, just like you do; don’t you?”
“三个月前，我经常晚上一个人来这里，哦，我总是在我们刚刚经过的那个十字路口停下来。前方树林若隐若现，就像现在一样，有狗在嚎叫，只有阴影，没有人声。当然，我在树林里到处都是可怕的东西，就像你一样；你不是吗？

“I do,” Amory admitted.
“我愿意，”艾默里承认。

“Well, I began analyzing it—my imagination persisted in sticking horrors into the dark—so I stuck my imagination into the dark instead, and let it look out at me—I let it play stray dog or escaped convict or ghost, and then saw myself coming along the road. That made it all right—as it always makes everything all right to project yourself completely into another’s place. I knew that if I were the dog or the convict or the ghost I wouldn’t be a menace to Burne Holiday any more than he was a menace to me. Then I thought of my watch. I’d better go back and leave it and then essay the woods. No; I decided, it’s better on the whole that I should lose a watch than that I should turn back—and I did go into them—not only followed the road through them, but walked into them until I wasn’t frightened any more—did it until one night I sat down and dozed off in there; then I knew I was through being afraid of the dark.”
“好吧，我开始分析它——我的想象力坚持把恐怖留在黑暗中——所以我把我的想象力放进黑暗中，让它看着我——我让它扮演流浪狗或逃犯或鬼魂，然后看到自己沿着路走来。这一切都好起来了——因为把自己完全投射到别人的位置上总是让一切都好起来。我知道，如果我是狗、罪犯或鬼魂，我不会对伯恩霍勒迪构成威胁，就像他不会对我构成威胁一样。然后我想到了我的手表。我最好回去把它留下，然后再去树林里探险。不;我决定，总的来说，我丢了一块手表比我回头要好——我确实走进了它们——不仅沿着穿过它们的路，而且走进了它们，直到我不再害怕——是的直到有一天晚上我坐下来打瞌睡；然后我就知道我已经不再害怕黑暗了。”

“Lordy,” Amory breathed. “I couldn’t have done that. I’d have come out half-way, and the first time an automobile passed and made the dark thicker when its lamps disappeared, I’d have come in.”
“天啊，”艾默里喘着气。 “我不可能那样做。我会在半路上出来，当第一次有汽车经过并在车灯消失时让黑暗变得更浓时，我就会进去。”

“Well,” Burne said suddenly, after a few moments’ silence, “we’re half-way through, let’s turn back.”
“好吧，”伯恩沉默了一会儿，突然说道，“我们已经走了一半，我们回去吧。”

On the return he launched into a discussion of will.
返回后，他开始讨论意志。

“It’s the whole thing,” he asserted. “It’s the one dividing line between good and evil. I’ve never met a man who led a rotten life and didn’t have a weak will.”
“这就是整个事情，”他断言。 “这是善与恶的唯一分界线。我从来没有遇到过一个生活腐朽、意志不坚强的人。”

“How about great criminals?”
“那大罪犯呢？”

“They’re usually insane. If not, they’re weak. There is no such thing as a strong, sane criminal.”
“他们通常都很疯狂。如果没有，他们就很弱。世界上不存在坚强、理智的罪犯。”

“Burne, I disagree with you altogether; how about the superman?”
“伯恩，我完全不同意你的观点；超人呢？”

“Well?”
“出色地？”

“He’s evil, I think, yet he’s strong and sane.”
“我认为他很邪恶，但他很坚强而且理智。”

“I’ve never met him. I’ll bet, though, that he’s stupid or insane.”
“我从没见过他。不过，我敢打赌，他一定是愚蠢或者疯了。”

“I’ve met him over and over and he’s neither. That’s why I think you’re wrong.”
“我见过他一次又一次，但他都不是。这就是为什么我认为你错了。”

“I’m sure I’m not—and so I don’t believe in imprisonment except for the insane.”
“我确信我没有——所以我不相信监禁，除非是疯子。”

On this point Amory could not agree. It seemed to him that life and history were rife with the strong criminal, keen, but often self-deluding; in politics and business one found him and among the old statesmen and kings and generals; but Burne never agreed and their courses began to split on that point.
在这一点上艾默里无法同意。在他看来，生活和历史中充满了坚强的罪犯，他们很敏锐，但常常自欺欺人。在政治和商业领域，人们可以在老政治家、国王和将军中找到他。但伯恩从未同意，他们的课程在这一点上开始出现分歧。

Burne was drawing farther and farther away from the world about him. He resigned the vice-presidency of the senior class and took to reading and walking as almost his only pursuits. He voluntarily attended graduate lectures in philosophy and biology, and sat in all of them with a rather pathetically intent look in his eyes, as if waiting for something the lecturer would never quite come to. Sometimes Amory would see him squirm in his seat; and his face would light up; he was on fire to debate a point.
伯恩与他周围的世界越来越远。他辞去了高年级副主席的职务，把阅读和散步几乎作为他唯一的爱好。他自愿参加哲学和生物学的研究生讲座，并且坐在所有讲座中，眼神中带着一种相当可悲的专注，仿佛在等待讲师永远不会明白的事情。有时艾默里会看到他在座位上蠕动。他的脸就会发光；他热衷于辩论一个观点。

He grew more abstracted on the street and was even accused of becoming a snob, but Amory knew it was nothing of the sort, and once when Burne passed him four feet off, absolutely unseeingly, his mind a thousand miles away, Amory almost choked with the romantic joy of watching him. Burne seemed to be climbing heights where others would be forever unable to get a foothold.
他在街上变得更加心不在焉，甚至被指责成为势利小人，但艾默里知道事实并非如此，有一次，当伯恩从四英尺外经过他时，完全看不见，他的思想在一千英里之外，艾默里几乎窒息了看着他的浪漫喜悦。伯恩似乎正在攀登其他人永远无法立足的高度。

“I tell you,” Amory declared to Tom, “he’s the first contemporary I’ve ever met whom I’ll admit is my superior in mental capacity.”
“我告诉你，”艾默里对汤姆宣称，“他是我见过的第一个同时代的人，我承认他的智力比我高。”

“It’s a bad time to admit it—people are beginning to think he’s odd.”
“现在不是承认这一点的时候——人们开始认为他很奇怪。”

“He’s way over their heads—you know you think so yourself when you talk to him—Good Lord, Tom, you used to stand out against ‘people.’ Success has completely conventionalized you.”
“他完全超出了他们的理解范围——你知道当你和他交谈时你自己也是这么想的——上帝啊，汤姆，你过去常常在‘人’面前脱颖而出。成功已经完全把你传统化了。”

Tom grew rather annoyed.
汤姆变得相当恼火。

“What’s he trying to do—be excessively holy?”
“他想做什么——变得过于圣洁？”

“No! not like anybody you’ve ever seen. Never enters the Philadelphian Society. He has no faith in that rot. He doesn’t believe that public swimming-pools and a kind word in time will right the wrongs of the world; moreover, he takes a drink whenever he feels like it.”
“不！不像你见过的任何人。从未进入费城协会。他对这种腐烂不抱任何信心。他不相信公共游泳池和及时的善意话语能够纠正世界的错误；而且，只要他想喝，他就会喝。”

“He certainly is getting in wrong.”
“他肯定是错了。”

“Have you talked to him lately?”
“你最近和他谈过吗？”

“No.”

“Then you haven’t any conception of him.”
“那你对他没有任何概念。”

The argument ended nowhere, but Amory noticed more than ever how the sentiment toward Burne had changed on the campus.
争论毫无结果，但艾默里比以往任何时候都更注意到校园里对伯恩的情绪发生了怎样的变化。

“It’s odd,” Amory said to Tom one night when they had grown more amicable on the subject, “that the people who violently disapprove of Burne’s radicalism are distinctly the Pharisee class—I mean they’re the best-educated men in college—the editors of the papers, like yourself and Ferrenby, the younger professors.... The illiterate athletes like Langueduc think he’s getting eccentric, but they just say, ‘Good old Burne has got some queer ideas in his head,’ and pass on—the Pharisee class—Gee! they ridicule him unmercifully.”
“这很奇怪，”有一天晚上，当他们在这个问题上变得更加友好时，艾默里对汤姆说，“那些强烈反对伯恩激进主义的人显然是法利赛阶层——我的意思是他们是大学里受过最好教育的人——报纸的编辑，比如你自己和费伦比，年轻的教授们……像朗格杜克这样的文盲运动员认为他变得古怪，但他们只是说，“好老伯恩的脑子里有一些奇怪的想法，”然后传递下去——法利赛人阶级——哎呀！他们无情地嘲笑他。”

The next morning he met Burne hurrying along McCosh walk after a recitation.
第二天早上，他在一场朗诵会后遇见了正在麦考什步道上匆匆行走的伯恩。

“Whither bound, Tsar?”
“去哪里，沙皇？”

“Over to the Prince office to see Ferrenby,” he waved a copy of the morning’s Princetonian at Amory. “He wrote this editorial.”
“去普林斯办公室见费伦比，”他挥舞着一份早上在艾默里的普林斯顿大学的报纸。 “他写了这篇社论。”

“Going to flay him alive?”
“要活剥他的皮吗？”

“No—but he’s got me all balled up. Either I’ve misjudged him or he’s suddenly become the world’s worst radical.”
“不——但他让我兴奋不已。要么我误判了他，要么他突然变成了世界上最糟糕的激进分子。”

Burne hurried on, and it was several days before Amory heard an account of the ensuing conversation. Burne had come into the editor’s sanctum displaying the paper cheerfully.
伯恩赶紧继续说下去，几天后艾默里才听到有关接下来谈话的叙述。伯恩走进编辑的密室，兴高采烈地展示着这篇论文。

“Hello, Jesse.”
“你好，杰西。”

“Hello there, Savonarola.”
“你好，萨沃纳罗拉。”

“I just read your editorial.”
“我刚刚读了你的社论。”

“Good boy—didn’t know you stooped that low.”
“好孩子——没想到你竟然弯得这么低。”

“Jesse, you startled me.”
“杰西，你吓到我了。”

“How so?”
“为何如此？”

“Aren’t you afraid the faculty’ll get after you if you pull this irreligious stuff?”
“你就不怕如果你做出这种不合宗教的事情，老师们会追究你吗？”

“What?”
“什么？”

“Like this morning.”
“就像今天早上一样。”

“What the devil—that editorial was on the coaching system.”
“天哪——那篇社论是关于教练系统的。”

“Yes, but that quotation—”
“是的，但是那句话——”

Jesse sat up.
杰西坐了起来。

“What quotation?”
“什么报价？”

“You know: ‘He who is not with me is against me.’”
“你知道：‘不与我同在的人就是反对我的。’”

“Well—what about it?”
“嗯——那又怎样呢？”

Jesse was puzzled but not alarmed.
杰西很困惑，但并不惊慌。

“Well, you say here—let me see.” Burne opened the paper and read: “‘He who is not with me is against me, as that gentleman said who was notoriously capable of only coarse distinctions and puerile generalities.’”
“好吧，你在这里说——让我看看。”伯恩打开报纸，读到：“‘不同意我的人就是反对我的，正如那位先生所说，他以只能进行粗略的区分和幼稚的概括而闻名。’”

“What of it?” Ferrenby began to look alarmed. “Oliver Cromwell said it, didn’t he? or was it Washington, or one of the saints? Good Lord, I’ve forgotten.”
“那又怎样？”费伦比开始显得惊慌起来。 “奥利弗·克伦威尔说过，不是吗？或者是华盛顿，还是圣人之一？天哪，我忘了。”

Burne roared with laughter.
伯恩大笑起来。

“Oh, Jesse, oh, good, kind Jesse.”
“哦，杰西，哦，好，善良的杰西。”

“Who said it, for Pete’s sake?”
“看在皮特的份上，谁说的？”

“Well,” said Burne, recovering his voice, “St. Matthew attributes it to Christ.”
“好吧，”伯恩恢复了声音说道，“圣约翰。”马太将其归因于基督。”

“My God!” cried Jesse, and collapsed backward into the waste-basket.
“我的上帝！”杰西喊道，向后倒进废纸篓里。

AMORY WRITES A POEM
艾默里写诗

The weeks tore by. Amory wandered occasionally to New York on the chance of finding a new shining green auto-bus, that its stick-of-candy glamour might penetrate his disposition. One day he ventured into a stock-company revival of a play whose name was faintly familiar. The curtain rose—he watched casually as a girl entered. A few phrases rang in his ear and touched a faint chord of memory. Where—? When—?
几个星期过去了。艾默里偶尔会到纽约闲逛，希望能找到一辆闪亮的绿色新巴士，这样它的糖果棒魅力就能渗透到他的性情中。有一天，他冒险参与了一家股份公司翻拍的一部剧，这部剧的名字有点耳熟。幕布升起——他漫不经心地看着一个女孩走了进来。耳边响起几句话，触动了淡淡的记忆心弦。在哪里-？什么时候-？

Then he seemed to hear a voice whispering beside him, a very soft, vibrant voice: “Oh, I’m such a poor little fool; do tell me when I do wrong.”
然后他似乎听到一个声音在他身边低语，一个非常柔和、充满活力的声音：“哦，我真是一个可怜的小傻瓜；当我做错事时请告诉我。”

The solution came in a flash and he had a quick, glad memory of Isabelle.
解决方案一闪而过，他很快就对伊莎贝尔产生了愉快的回忆。

He found a blank space on his programme, and began to scribble rapidly:
他在程序上找到了一块空白，开始飞快地写着：

   “Here in the figured dark I watch once more,
      There, with the curtain, roll the years away;
      Two years of years—there was an idle day
    Of ours, when happy endings didn’t bore
    Our unfermented souls; I could adore
      Your eager face beside me, wide-eyed, gay,
      Smiling a repertoire while the poor play
    Reached me as a faint ripple reaches shore.

   “Yawning and wondering an evening through,
      I watch alone... and chatterings, of course,
      Spoil the one scene which, somehow, did have charms;
    You wept a bit, and I grew sad for you
      Right here!  Where Mr. X defends divorce
      And What’s-Her-Name falls fainting in his arms.”

STILL CALM
依然平静

“Ghosts are such dumb things,” said Alec, “they’re slow-witted. I can always outguess a ghost.”
“鬼魂真是愚蠢的东西，”亚历克说，“他们的头脑很迟钝。我总能猜出鬼魂。”

“How?” asked Tom.
“如何？”汤姆问道。

“Well, it depends where. Take a bedroom, for example. If you use any discretion a ghost can never get you in a bedroom.”
“嗯，这要看在哪里。以卧室为例。如果你谨慎行事，鬼魂永远无法让你进入卧室。”

“Go on, s’pose you think there’s maybe a ghost in your bedroom—what measures do you take on getting home at night?” demanded Amory, interested.
“继续说吧，假设你认为你的卧室里可能有鬼——你晚上回家会采取什么措施？”艾默里感兴趣地问道。

“Take a stick” answered Alec, with ponderous reverence, “one about the length of a broom-handle. Now, the first thing to do is to get the room cleared—to do this you rush with your eyes closed into your study and turn on the lights—next, approaching the closet, carefully run the stick in the door three or four times. Then, if nothing happens, you can look in. Always, always run the stick in viciously first—never look first!”
“拿一根棍子，”亚历克带着沉重的敬意回答，“一根大约有扫帚柄那么长的棍子。现在，要做的第一件事就是清理房间——要做到这一点，你要闭上眼睛冲进书房，打开灯——接下来，靠近壁橱，小心地用棍子在门上敲三四次。然后，如果没有发生任何事情，你就可以往里面看。总是，总是先恶意地把棍子插进去——永远不要先看！”

“Of course, that’s the ancient Celtic school,” said Tom gravely.
“当然，那是古老的凯尔特学派。”汤姆严肃地说。

“Yes—but they usually pray first. Anyway, you use this method to clear the closets and also for behind all doors—”
“是的——但他们通常会先祈祷。不管怎样，你用这个方法来清理壁橱和所有门后——”

“And the bed,” Amory suggested.
“还有床，”艾默里建议道。

“Oh, Amory, no!” cried Alec in horror. “That isn’t the way—the bed requires different tactics—let the bed alone, as you value your reason—if there is a ghost in the room and that’s only about a third of the time, it is almost always under the bed.”
“哦，艾默里，不！”亚历克惊恐地叫道。 “不是这样的——床需要不同的策略——别管床，因为你重视你的理性——如果房间里有鬼，而且只有大约三分之一的时间，它几乎总是在床底下”。

“Well” Amory began.
“好吧，”艾默里开始说道。

Alec waved him into silence.
亚历克挥手示意他安静。

“Of course you never look. You stand in the middle of the floor and before he knows what you’re going to do make a sudden leap for the bed—never walk near the bed; to a ghost your ankle is your most vulnerable part—once in bed, you’re safe; he may lie around under the bed all night, but you’re safe as daylight. If you still have doubts pull the blanket over your head.”
“当然，你从来不看。你站在地板中央，在他知道你要做什么之前，你突然跳向床——永远不要走近床；对鬼魂来说，你的脚踝是你最脆弱的部分——一旦上床，你就安全了；一旦上床，你就安全了。他可能整晚都躺在床底下，但你却像白天一样安全。如果你还有疑问，就把毯子拉到头上。”

“All that’s very interesting, Tom.”
“这一切都非常有趣，汤姆。”

“Isn’t it?” Alec beamed proudly. “All my own, too—the Sir Oliver Lodge of the new world.”
“不是吗？”亚历克自豪地微笑着。 “也是我自己的——新世界的奥利弗·洛奇爵士。”

Amory was enjoying college immensely again. The sense of going forward in a direct, determined line had come back; youth was stirring and shaking out a few new feathers. He had even stored enough surplus energy to sally into a new pose.
艾默里又开始享受大学生活了。那种直线前进、坚定不移的感觉又回来了。青春正在蠢蠢欲动，抖出几根新的羽毛。他甚至还储存了足够的剩余能量来摆出新的姿势。

“What’s the idea of all this ‘distracted’ stuff, Amory?” asked Alec one day, and then as Amory pretended to be cramped over his book in a daze: “Oh, don’t try to act Burne, the mystic, to me.”
“艾默里，这些‘分散注意力’的东西到底是怎么回事？”有一天，亚历克问，然后艾默里假装局促地看着他的书，茫然地说道：“哦，别试图在我面前扮演神秘主义者伯恩。”

Amory looked up innocently.
艾默里无辜地抬起头。

“What?”
“什么？”

“What?” mimicked Alec. “Are you trying to read yourself into a rhapsody with—let’s see the book.”
“什么？”模仿亚历克。 “你想把自己读成一首狂想曲吗——让我们看看这本书。”

He snatched it; regarded it derisively.
他抢走了它；嘲笑地看待它。

“Well?” said Amory a little stiffly.
“出色地？”艾默里有些生硬地说。

“‘The Life of St. Teresa,’” read Alec aloud. “Oh, my gosh!”
“‘圣特蕾莎的一生’，”亚历克大声朗读。 “天啊！”

“Say, Alec.”
“说吧，亚历克。”

“What?”
“什么？”

“Does it bother you?”
“它妨碍到你了吗？”

“Does what bother me?”
“有什么事让我烦恼吗？”

“My acting dazed and all that?”
“我的表演让人眼花缭乱之类的？”

“Why, no—of course it doesn’t bother me.”
“为什么，不——我当然不介意。”

“Well, then, don’t spoil it. If I enjoy going around telling people guilelessly that I think I’m a genius, let me do it.”
“好吧，那就别破坏了。如果我喜欢坦诚地告诉人们我认为我是个天才，那就让我这么做吧。”

“You’re getting a reputation for being eccentric,” said Alec, laughing, “if that’s what you mean.”
“你会因为古怪而出名，”亚历克笑着说，“如果你是这个意思的话。”

Amory finally prevailed, and Alec agreed to accept his face value in the presence of others if he was allowed rest periods when they were alone; so Amory “ran it out” at a great rate, bringing the most eccentric characters to dinner, wild-eyed grad students, preceptors with strange theories of God and government, to the cynical amazement of the supercilious Cottage Club.
艾默里最终占了上风，亚历克同意接受他在其他人面前的面子，如果允许他在他们独处时休息一段时间。因此，艾默里以极快的速度“耗尽了一切”，邀请了最古怪的人物来参加晚宴，他们是睁大眼睛的研究生，对上帝和政府有着奇怪理论的导师，让傲慢的乡村俱乐部感到愤世嫉俗的惊讶。

As February became slashed by sun and moved cheerfully into March, Amory went several times to spend week-ends with Monsignor; once he took Burne, with great success, for he took equal pride and delight in displaying them to each other. Monsignor took him several times to see Thornton Hancock, and once or twice to the house of a Mrs. Lawrence, a type of Rome-haunting American whom Amory liked immediately.
随着二月的阳光明媚，愉快地进入三月，艾默里好几次去和主教一起度周末。有一次他抓住了伯恩，取得了巨大的成功，因为他对彼此展示他们感到同样的自豪和高兴。主教带他几次去见桑顿·汉考克，有一两次去了劳伦斯夫人的家，劳伦斯夫人是一位常去罗马的美国人，艾默里立刻就喜欢上了她。

Then one day came a letter from Monsignor, which appended an interesting P. S.:
有一天，主教收到一封信，其中附有一段有趣的附注：

  “Do you know,” it ran, “that your third cousin, Clara Page,
  widowed six months and very poor, is living in Philadelphia?
  I don’t think you’ve ever met her, but I wish, as a favor to me,
  you’d go to see her.  To my mind, she’s rather a remarkable woman,
  and just about your age.”

Amory sighed and decided to go, as a favor....
艾默里叹了口气，决定去，算是帮个忙……

CLARA
克拉拉

She was immemorial.... Amory wasn’t good enough for Clara, Clara of ripply golden hair, but then no man was. Her goodness was above the prosy morals of the husband-seeker, apart from the dull literature of female virtue.
她是远古的……艾默里配不上克拉拉，克拉拉有着一头波浪般的金色头发，但没有男人能配得上。除了乏味的女性美德文学之外，她的善良超越了求婚者的乏味道德。

Sorrow lay lightly around her, and when Amory found her in Philadelphia he thought her steely blue eyes held only happiness; a latent strength, a realism, was brought to its fullest development by the facts that she was compelled to face. She was alone in the world, with two small children, little money, and, worst of all, a host of friends. He saw her that winter in Philadelphia entertaining a houseful of men for an evening, when he knew she had not a servant in the house except the little colored girl guarding the babies overhead. He saw one of the greatest libertines in that city, a man who was habitually drunk and notorious at home and abroad, sitting opposite her for an evening, discussing girls’ boarding-schools with a sort of innocent excitement. What a twist Clara had to her mind! She could make fascinating and almost brilliant conversation out of the thinnest air that ever floated through a drawing-room.
悲伤轻轻地笼罩着她，当艾默里在费城找到她时，他认为她钢铁般的蓝眼睛里只有幸福；但她的眼睛却充满了幸福。她被迫面对的事实使一种潜在的力量、一种现实主义得到了最充分的发展。她独自一人在这个世界上，带着两个小孩，没什么钱，最糟糕的是，还有一群朋友。那年冬天，他看到她在费城招待一屋子男人一个晚上，当时他知道除了头顶上看守婴儿的黑人小女孩外，家里没有仆人。他看到了这座城市里最大的浪荡子之一，一个习惯酗酒、在国内外声名狼藉的男人，在她对面坐了一个晚上，带着一种天真的兴奋讨论着女子寄宿学校。克拉拉的思想多么扭曲啊！她可以用客厅里最稀薄的空气进行令人着迷、几乎精彩的谈话。

The idea that the girl was poverty-stricken had appealed to Amory’s sense of situation. He arrived in Philadelphia expecting to be told that 921 Ark Street was in a miserable lane of hovels. He was even disappointed when it proved to be nothing of the sort. It was an old house that had been in her husband’s family for years. An elderly aunt, who objected to having it sold, had put ten years’ taxes with a lawyer and pranced off to Honolulu, leaving Clara to struggle with the heating-problem as best she could. So no wild-haired woman with a hungry baby at her breast and a sad Amelia-like look greeted him. Instead, Amory would have thought from his reception that she had not a care in the world.
这个女孩陷入贫困的想法引起了艾默里的处境感。他抵达费城，期待被告知方舟街 921 号位于一条简陋的茅屋小巷中。当事实证明并非如此时，他甚至感到失望。那是一栋老房子，已经属于她丈夫的家很多年了。一位年老的阿姨反对卖掉这栋房子，她把十年的税交给了律师，然后兴高采烈地去了檀香山，留下克拉拉尽力解决供暖问题。因此，没有一个满头乱发、怀着饥饿的婴儿、脸上带着阿米莉亚般悲伤表情的女人迎接他。相反，艾默里会从他的接待中认为她在这个世界上无忧无虑。

A calm virility and a dreamy humor, marked contrasts to her level-headedness—into these moods she slipped sometimes as a refuge. She could do the most prosy things (though she was wise enough never to stultify herself with such “household arts” as knitting and embroidery), yet immediately afterward pick up a book and let her imagination rove as a formless cloud with the wind. Deepest of all in her personality was the golden radiance that she diffused around her. As an open fire in a dark room throws romance and pathos into the quiet faces at its edge, so she cast her lights and shadows around the rooms that held her, until she made of her prosy old uncle a man of quaint and meditative charm, metamorphosed the stray telegraph boy into a Puck-like creature of delightful originality. At first this quality of hers somehow irritated Amory. He considered his own uniqueness sufficient, and it rather embarrassed him when she tried to read new interests into him for the benefit of what other adorers were present. He felt as if a polite but insistent stage-manager were attempting to make him give a new interpretation of a part he had conned for years.
冷静的男子气概和梦幻般的幽默，与她的冷静头脑形成鲜明对比——她有时会陷入这些情绪，作为避难所。她可以做最乏味的事情（尽管她很聪明，从来不会用编织和刺绣之类的“家庭艺术”来愚弄自己），但随后立即拿起一本书，让她的想象力像无形的云一样随风飘扬。她个性中最深处的是她周围散发的金色光芒。正如黑暗房间里的篝火将浪漫和悲伤投射到边缘安静的面孔上，她也将灯光和阴影投射在容纳她的房间周围，直到她把她那枯燥无味的老叔叔变成了一个古雅而沉思的魅力的男人，把流浪的电报男孩变成了一个像冰球一样具有令人愉快的创意的生物。起初，她的这种品质不知何故激怒了艾默里。他认为自己的独特性就足够了，当她为了其他在场的崇拜者的利益而试图向他解读新的兴趣时，他感到相当尴尬。他觉得好像一个礼貌但坚持不懈的舞台监督试图让他对他多年来欺骗的部分做出新的解释。

But Clara talking, Clara telling a slender tale of a hatpin and an inebriated man and herself.... People tried afterward to repeat her anecdotes but for the life of them they could make them sound like nothing whatever. They gave her a sort of innocent attention and the best smiles many of them had smiled for long; there were few tears in Clara, but people smiled misty-eyed at her.
但克拉拉在说话，克拉拉讲述了一个关于帽子别针、醉汉和她自己的故事……人们后来试图重复她的轶事，但对于他们的生活来说，他们可以让它们听起来像什么都没有。他们给了她一种天真无邪的关注，以及他们中的许多人长久以来一直微笑着的最美好的微笑。克拉拉几乎没有流泪，但人们却泪眼朦胧地对她微笑。

Very occasionally Amory stayed for little half-hours after the rest of the court had gone, and they would have bread and jam and tea late in the afternoon or “maple-sugar lunches,” as she called them, at night.
法庭上的其他人都离开后，艾默里偶尔会留下半个小时，下午晚些时候他们会吃面包、果酱和茶，或者在晚上吃“枫糖午餐”，她称之为“枫糖午餐”。

“You are remarkable, aren’t you!” Amory was becoming trite from where he perched in the centre of the dining-room table one six o’clock.
“你很了不起，不是吗！”六点钟时，艾默里坐在餐桌中央，这让他变得老套了。

“Not a bit,” she answered. She was searching out napkins in the sideboard. “I’m really most humdrum and commonplace. One of those people who have no interest in anything but their children.”
“一点也不，”她回答。她正在餐具柜里寻找餐巾。 “我真的是最单调、最平凡的人。那些除了孩子之外对任何事情都没有兴趣的人之一。”

“Tell that to somebody else,” scoffed Amory. “You know you’re perfectly effulgent.” He asked her the one thing that he knew might embarrass her. It was the remark that the first bore made to Adam.
“把这个告诉别人吧，”艾默里嘲笑道。 “你知道你非常光彩夺目。”他问了她一件他知道可能会让她难堪的事。这是第一个孩子对亚当说的。

“Tell me about yourself.” And she gave the answer that Adam must have given.
“说说你自己。”她给出了亚当一定给出的答案。

“There’s nothing to tell.”
“没什么可说的。”

But eventually Adam probably told the bore all the things he thought about at night when the locusts sang in the sandy grass, and he must have remarked patronizingly how different he was from Eve, forgetting how different she was from him... at any rate, Clara told Amory much about herself that evening. She had had a harried life from sixteen on, and her education had stopped sharply with her leisure. Browsing in her library, Amory found a tattered gray book out of which fell a yellow sheet that he impudently opened. It was a poem that she had written at school about a gray convent wall on a gray day, and a girl with her cloak blown by the wind sitting atop of it and thinking about the many-colored world. As a rule such sentiment bored him, but this was done with so much simplicity and atmosphere, that it brought a picture of Clara to his mind, of Clara on such a cool, gray day with her keen blue eyes staring out, trying to see her tragedies come marching over the gardens outside. He envied that poem. How he would have loved to have come along and seen her on the wall and talked nonsense or romance to her, perched above him in the air. He began to be frightfully jealous of everything about Clara: of her past, of her babies, of the men and women who flocked to drink deep of her cool kindness and rest their tired minds as at an absorbing play.
但最终亚当可能告诉了无聊的人他在晚上蝗虫在沙草中唱歌时想到的所有事情，他一定居高临下地评论说他与夏娃有多么不同，忘记了她与他有多么不同……无论如何那天晚上，克拉拉向艾默里讲述了很多关于她自己的事情。她从十六岁起就过着忙碌的生活，随着闲暇，她的教育也急剧停止。艾默里在她的图书馆里翻阅着，发现了一本破烂的灰色书，其中有一张黄色的书页，他无礼地打开了。这是她在学校写的一首诗，内容是在灰蒙蒙的日子里，修道院的灰色墙壁上，一个披风被风吹起的女孩坐在墙上，思考着这个五彩斑斓的世界。一般来说，这种情绪让他感到厌烦，但这样做的方式是如此简单和大气，以至于他的脑海中浮现出克拉拉的画面，克拉拉在如此凉爽、灰暗的天气里，用她敏锐的蓝眼睛盯着外面，试图看到她的悲剧发生在外面的花园里。他很羡慕那首诗。他多么希望能够过来，看到她站在墙上，对她说些废话或浪漫的话，坐在他上方的空中。他开始对克拉拉的一切产生了可怕的嫉妒：她的过去，她的孩子，以及那些蜂拥而至的男人和女人们，他们蜂拥而至，深深地沉浸在她冷静的仁慈中，让疲惫的心灵得到休息，就像在一场引人入胜的戏剧中一样。

“Nobody seems to bore you,” he objected.
“似乎没有人让你感到厌烦，”他反对道。

“About half the world do,” she admitted, “but I think that’s a pretty good average, don’t you?” and she turned to find something in Browning that bore on the subject. She was the only person he ever met who could look up passages and quotations to show him in the middle of the conversation, and yet not be irritating to distraction. She did it constantly, with such a serious enthusiasm that he grew fond of watching her golden hair bent over a book, brow wrinkled ever so little at hunting her sentence.
“世界上大约有一半的人都是这样，”她承认，“但我认为这是一个相当不错的平均数，你觉得呢？”她转身在勃朗宁的著作中发现了一些与这个主题有关的东西。她是他见过的唯一一个能够在谈话中查找段落和引文给他看的人，但又不会让他分心。她不断地这样做，带着如此认真的热情，他越来越喜欢看她金色的头发低垂在一本书上，在寻找她的句子时眉头皱得很少。

Through early March he took to going to Philadelphia for week-ends. Almost always there was some one else there and she seemed not anxious to see him alone, for many occasions presented themselves when a word from her would have given him another delicious half-hour of adoration. But he fell gradually in love and began to speculate wildly on marriage. Though this design flowed through his brain even to his lips, still he knew afterward that the desire had not been deeply rooted.
