Once he dreamt that it had come true and woke up in a cold panic, for in his dream she had been a silly, flaxen Clara, with the gold gone out of her hair and platitudes falling insipidly from her changeling tongue. But she was the first fine woman he ever knew and one of the few good people who ever interested him. She made her goodness such an asset. Amory had decided that most good people either dragged theirs after them as a liability, or else distorted it to artificial geniality, and of course there were the ever-present prig and Pharisee—(but Amory never included them as being among the saved).
整个三月初，他开始去费城度周末。几乎总是有其他人在那里，而她似乎并不急于单独见到他，因为很多时候，她的一句话就会给他带来又一个美妙的半个小时的崇拜。但他渐渐陷入了爱情，并开始疯狂地憧憬婚姻。虽然这个想法在他的大脑中流淌，甚至流到了嘴边，但事后他仍然知道，这个愿望并没有根深蒂固。有一次他梦见这件事成真了，然后在寒冷的恐慌中醒来，因为在他的梦里，她是一个愚蠢的、淡黄色的克拉拉，金色的头发从她的头发上消失了，陈词滥调从她那变形的舌头上掉了下来。但她是他认识的第一个优秀的女人，也是为数不多的令他感兴趣的好人之一。她把自己的善良变成了一种财富。艾默里认为，大多数好人要么把自己的责任当作一种负担，要么将其扭曲为人为的友善，当然，还有永远存在的假正经者和法利赛人——（但艾默里从未将他们列为得救者之一）。

ST. CECILIA 

   “Over her gray and velvet dress,
      Under her molten, beaten hair,
    Color of rose in mock distress
      Flushes and fades and makes her fair;
    Fills the air from her to him
      With light and languor and little sighs,
    Just so subtly he scarcely knows...
      Laughing lightning, color of rose.”

“Do you like me?”
“你喜欢我吗？”

“Of course I do,” said Clara seriously.
“我当然知道，”克拉拉认真地说。

“Why?”
“为什么？”

“Well, we have some qualities in common. Things that are spontaneous in each of us—or were originally.”
“嗯，我们有一些共同点。我们每个人身上都有的东西是自发的——或者说本来就是。”

“You’re implying that I haven’t used myself very well?”
“你的意思是我没有好好利用自己？”

Clara hesitated.
克拉拉犹豫了。

“Well, I can’t judge. A man, of course, has to go through a lot more, and I’ve been sheltered.”
“好吧，我无法判断。当然，一个人要经历更多的事情，而我却得到了庇护。”

“Oh, don’t stall, please, Clara,” Amory interrupted; “but do talk about me a little, won’t you?”
“噢，请别拖延，克拉拉，”艾默里打断道。 “但是请谈谈我，好吗？”

“Surely, I’d adore to.” She didn’t smile.
“当然，我很乐意。”她没有笑。

“That’s sweet of you. First answer some questions. Am I painfully conceited?”
“你真是太好了。首先回答一些问题。我是不是太自负了？”

“Well—no, you have tremendous vanity, but it’ll amuse the people who notice its preponderance.”
“嗯——不，你有极大的虚荣心，但它会让那些注意到它的优势的人感到高兴。”

“I see.”
“我懂了。”

“You’re really humble at heart. You sink to the third hell of depression when you think you’ve been slighted. In fact, you haven’t much self-respect.”
“你的内心还真是谦虚啊。当你认为自己受到轻视时，你就会陷入抑郁的第三个地狱。事实上，你没有多少自尊心。”

“Centre of target twice, Clara. How do you do it? You never let me say a word.”
“两次达到目标中心，克拉拉。你怎么做呢？你从来不让我说一句话。”

“Of course not—I can never judge a man while he’s talking. But I’m not through; the reason you have so little real self-confidence, even though you gravely announce to the occasional philistine that you think you’re a genius, is that you’ve attributed all sorts of atrocious faults to yourself and are trying to live up to them. For instance, you’re always saying that you are a slave to high-balls.”
“当然不是——我永远无法在一个人说话的时候对其进行评判。但我还没有结束；你之所以缺乏真正的自信，即使你偶尔郑重地向庸人宣布你认为自己是个天才，是因为你把各种严重的错误归咎于自己，并试图不辜负它们。例如，你总是说你是高酒杯的奴隶。”

“But I am, potentially.”
“但我可能是。”

“And you say you’re a weak character, that you’ve no will.”
“你还说你性格软弱，没有意志。”

“Not a bit of will—I’m a slave to my emotions, to my likes, to my hatred of boredom, to most of my desires—”
“没有一点意志——我是我的情感、我的喜好、我对无聊的憎恶、我大部分欲望的奴隶——”

“You are not!” She brought one little fist down onto the other. “You’re a slave, a bound helpless slave to one thing in the world, your imagination.”
“你不是！”她将一只小拳头放在另一只拳头上。 “你是一个奴隶，一个被世界上一件事束缚的无助的奴隶，那就是你的想象力。”

“You certainly interest me. If this isn’t boring you, go on.”
“我当然对你感兴趣。如果这不让你感到无聊，那就继续吧。”

“I notice that when you want to stay over an extra day from college you go about it in a sure way. You never decide at first while the merits of going or staying are fairly clear in your mind. You let your imagination shinny on the side of your desires for a few hours, and then you decide. Naturally your imagination, after a little freedom, thinks up a million reasons why you should stay, so your decision when it comes isn’t true. It’s biassed.”
“我注意到，当你想从大学里多呆一天时，你就会以一种确定的方式去做。当去或留的优点在你的脑海中相当清楚时，你永远不会做出决定。你让你的想象力在你的欲望的一边闪耀几个小时，然后你做出决定。自然地，你的想象力，在一点自由之后，会想出一百万个你应该留下来的理由，所以当你的决定到来时，你的决定是不正确的。这是有偏见的。”

“Yes,” objected Amory, “but isn’t it lack of will-power to let my imagination shinny on the wrong side?”
“是的，”艾默里反对道，“但让我的想象力在错误的一面发光，这不是缺乏意志力吗？”

“My dear boy, there’s your big mistake. This has nothing to do with will-power; that’s a crazy, useless word, anyway; you lack judgment—the judgment to decide at once when you know your imagination will play you false, given half a chance.”
“我亲爱的孩子，你犯了一个大错误。这与意志力无关，而是与意志力无关。无论如何，这是一个疯狂的、无用的词；你缺乏判断力——当你知道你的想象力会欺骗你时，只要有一点机会，你就缺乏判断力。”

“Well, I’ll be darned!” exclaimed Amory in surprise, “that’s the last thing I expected.”
“好吧，我就完蛋了！”艾默里惊讶地喊道：“这是我最没想到的事情。”

Clara didn’t gloat. She changed the subject immediately. But she had started him thinking and he believed she was partly right. He felt like a factory-owner who after accusing a clerk of dishonesty finds that his own son, in the office, is changing the books once a week. His poor, mistreated will that he had been holding up to the scorn of himself and his friends, stood before him innocent, and his judgment walked off to prison with the unconfinable imp, imagination, dancing in mocking glee beside him. Clara’s was the only advice he ever asked without dictating the answer himself—except, perhaps, in his talks with Monsignor Darcy.
克拉拉并没有幸灾乐祸。她立即​​改变了话题。但她让他开始思考，他相信她是部分正确的。他觉得自己就像一个工厂主，在指责一名职员不诚实后，发现自己的儿子在办公室里每周更换一次账簿。他那可怜的、被虐待的意志，一直被他自己和他的朋友们所蔑视，现在却无辜地站在他面前，而他的判断力则走向了监狱，而那个不受禁锢的小鬼——想象力，则在他身边欢快地跳舞。克拉拉的建议是他唯一没有亲自给出答案而提出的建议——也许除了他与达西大人的谈话中。

How he loved to do any sort of thing with Clara! Shopping with her was a rare, epicurean dream. In every store where she had ever traded she was whispered about as the beautiful Mrs. Page.
他多么喜欢和克拉拉一起做任何事情啊！和她一起购物是一个罕见的、享乐主义的梦想。在她曾经经营过的每一家商店里，人们都低声议论她是美丽的佩吉夫人。

“I’ll bet she won’t stay single long.”
“我敢打赌她不会单身太久。”

“Well, don’t scream it out. She ain’t lookin’ for no advice.”
“好了，别喊出来了。她不会寻求任何建议。”

“Ain’t she beautiful!”
“她不是很漂亮吗！”

   (Enter a floor-walker—silence till he moves forward, smirking.)

“Society person, ain’t she?”
“社会人士，不是吗？”

“Yeah, but poor now, I guess; so they say.”
“是的，但我想现在很穷；所以他们说。”

“Gee! girls, ain’t she some kid!”
“哎呀！姑娘们，她不是小孩子吗！”

And Clara beamed on all alike. Amory believed that tradespeople gave her discounts, sometimes to her knowledge and sometimes without it. He knew she dressed very well, had always the best of everything in the house, and was inevitably waited upon by the head floor-walker at the very least.
克拉拉也同样对着所有人微笑。艾默里相信商人会给她折扣，有时她是知情的，有时是她不知情的。他知道她穿得很好，总是拥有家里最好的一切，而且至少不可避免地要受到楼层巡视员的接待。

Sometimes they would go to church together on Sunday and he would walk beside her and revel in her cheeks moist from the soft water in the new air. She was very devout, always had been, and God knows what heights she attained and what strength she drew down to herself when she knelt and bent her golden hair into the stained-glass light.
有时他们会在周日一起去教堂，他会走在她身边，陶醉在她因新鲜空气中柔软的水而湿润的脸颊上。她非常虔诚，一直如此，天知道当她跪下，将金色的头发弯曲到彩色玻璃的灯光下时，她达到了多么高的高度，也汲取了多大的力量。

“St. Cecelia,” he cried aloud one day, quite involuntarily, and the people turned and peered, and the priest paused in his sermon and Clara and Amory turned to fiery red.
“英石。有一天，他不由自主地大声喊道，塞西莉亚，人们转过身来凝视着，神父的布道停了下来，克拉拉和艾默里的脸变成了火红色。

That was the last Sunday they had, for he spoiled it all that night. He couldn’t help it.
那是他们度过的最后一个周日，因为那天晚上他把一切都搞砸了。他情不自禁。

They were walking through the March twilight where it was as warm as June, and the joy of youth filled his soul so that he felt he must speak.
他们走在三月的暮色中，那里和六月一样温暖，青春的欢乐充满了他的灵魂，让他觉得他必须说话。

“I think,” he said and his voice trembled, “that if I lost faith in you I’d lose faith in God.”
“我想，”他声音颤抖地说，“如果我对你失去信心，我也会对上帝失去信心。”

She looked at him with such a startled face that he asked her the matter.
她一脸惊讶地看着他，他问她这件事。

“Nothing,” she said slowly, “only this: five men have said that to me before, and it frightens me.”
“没什么，”她慢慢地说，“只是这个：以前有五个男人对我说过这样的话，这让我害怕。”

“Oh, Clara, is that your fate!”
“哦，克拉拉，这就是你的命运！”

She did not answer.
她没有回答。

“I suppose love to you is—” he began.
“我想对你的爱是——”他开始说道。

She turned like a flash.
她转身如闪电。

“I have never been in love.”
“我从来没有谈过恋爱。”

They walked along, and he realized slowly how much she had told him... never in love.... She seemed suddenly a daughter of light alone. His entity dropped out of her plane and he longed only to touch her dress with almost the realization that Joseph must have had of Mary’s eternal significance. But quite mechanically he heard himself saying:
他们一路走着，他慢慢地意识到她告诉了他多少……从来没有恋爱过……她突然就像一个孤独的光之女儿。他的实体从她的飞机上掉了下来，他只想触摸她的衣服，几乎意识到约瑟夫一定知道玛丽的永恒意义。但他听到自己机械地说道：

“And I love you—any latent greatness that I’ve got is... oh, I can’t talk, but Clara, if I come back in two years in a position to marry you—”
“我爱你——我所拥有的任何潜在的伟大之处都是……哦，我不能说话，但是克拉拉，如果我两年后回来能够嫁给你——”

She shook her head.
她摇摇头。

“No,” she said; “I’d never marry again. I’ve got my two children and I want myself for them. I like you—I like all clever men, you more than any—but you know me well enough to know that I’d never marry a clever man—” She broke off suddenly.
“不，”她说。 “我永远不会再结婚了。我有我的两个孩子，我想要为他们服务。我喜欢你——我喜欢所有聪明的男人，尤其是你——但你很了解我，知道我永远不会嫁给一个聪明的男人——”她突然停了下来。

“Amory.”
“艾默里。”

“What?”
“什么？”

“You’re not in love with me. You never wanted to marry me, did you?”
“你不爱我。你从来没想过要嫁给我，是吗？”

“It was the twilight,” he said wonderingly. “I didn’t feel as though I were speaking aloud. But I love you—or adore you—or worship you—”
“那是黄昏，”他惊奇地说。 “我感觉自己没有大声说话。但我爱你——或者崇拜你——或者崇拜你——”

“There you go—running through your catalogue of emotions in five seconds.”
“就是这样——在五秒钟内浏览一下你的情绪目录。”

He smiled unwillingly.
他不情愿地笑了笑。

“Don’t make me out such a light-weight, Clara; you are depressing sometimes.”
“别让我显得那么轻量，克拉拉；你有时很沮丧。”

“You’re not a light-weight, of all things,” she said intently, taking his arm and opening wide her eyes—he could see their kindliness in the fading dusk. “A light-weight is an eternal nay.”
“无论如何，你都不是一个轻量级的人，”她专注地说，握住他的手臂，睁大眼睛——他可以在渐行渐远的暮色中看到他们的友善。 “轻量化就是永恒的否定。”

“There’s so much spring in the air—there’s so much lazy sweetness in your heart.”
“空气中充满了春天的气息——你的心中充满了慵懒的甜蜜。”

She dropped his arm.
她放下了他的手臂。

“You’re all fine now, and I feel glorious. Give me a cigarette. You’ve never seen me smoke, have you? Well, I do, about once a month.”
“你们现在一切都很好，我感到很光荣。给我一支烟。你从来没有见过我抽烟，是吗？嗯，我会的，大约一个月一次。”

And then that wonderful girl and Amory raced to the corner like two mad children gone wild with pale-blue twilight.
然后那个美妙的女孩和艾默里跑到了角落，就像两个在淡蓝色暮色中发疯的孩子。

“I’m going to the country for to-morrow,” she announced, as she stood panting, safe beyond the flare of the corner lamp-post. “These days are too magnificent to miss, though perhaps I feel them more in the city.”
“我明天要去乡下，”她一边气喘吁吁地宣布，一边安全地站在街角灯柱的耀眼光芒之外。 “这些日子太美好了，不容错过，尽管也许我在城市里感受到的更多。”

“Oh, Clara!” Amory said; “what a devil you could have been if the Lord had just bent your soul a little the other way!”
“哦，克拉拉！”艾默里说； “如果主让你的灵魂向另一个方向弯曲一点，你会变成一个多么魔鬼啊！”

“Maybe,” she answered; “but I think not. I’m never really wild and never have been. That little outburst was pure spring.”
“也许吧，”她回答道。 “但我认为不是。我从来没有真正狂野过，也从来没有。那小小的爆发是纯粹的春天。”

“And you are, too,” said he.
“你也是，”他说。

They were walking along now.
他们现在正在走着。

“No—you’re wrong again, how can a person of your own self-reputed brains be so constantly wrong about me? I’m the opposite of everything spring ever stood for. It’s unfortunate, if I happen to look like what pleased some soppy old Greek sculptor, but I assure you that if it weren’t for my face I’d be a quiet nun in the convent without”—then she broke into a run and her raised voice floated back to him as he followed—“my precious babies, which I must go back and see.”
“不——你又错了，你一个自以为有头脑的人怎么能总是对我有这样的误解呢？我与春天所代表的一切相反。不幸的是，如果我碰巧长得像某个多愁善感的老希腊雕塑家所喜欢的那样，但我向你保证，如果不是因为我的脸，我会成为修道院里一个安静的修女。”——然后她拔腿就跑，当他跟在后面时，她提高的声音又飘回了他的耳中——“我亲爱的宝贝们，我必须回去看看。”

She was the only girl he ever knew with whom he could understand how another man might be preferred. Often Amory met wives whom he had known as debutantes, and looking intently at them imagined that he found something in their faces which said:
她是他认识的唯一一个能让他理解另一个男人可能会更喜欢的女孩。艾默里经常遇到那些他认为是初次亮相的妻子，他专心地看着她们，想象着从她们脸上发现了某种东西，上面写着：

“Oh, if I could only have gotten you!” Oh, the enormous conceit of the man!
“哦，如果我能得到你就好了！”哦，这个人的自负之大！

But that night seemed a night of stars and singing and Clara’s bright soul still gleamed on the ways they had trod.
但那天晚上似乎是一个星星和歌声的夜晚，克拉拉明亮的灵魂仍然在他们走过的路上闪闪发光。

“Golden, golden is the air—” he chanted to the little pools of water. ... “Golden is the air, golden notes from golden mandolins, golden frets of golden violins, fair, oh, wearily fair.... Skeins from braided basket, mortals may not hold; oh, what young extravagant God, who would know or ask it?... who could give such gold...”
“金色，金色的是空气——”他对着小水池喊道。 ……空气是金色的，曼陀林的金色音符，小提琴的金色音柱，公平，哦，令人疲倦的公平……编织篮子里的绞线，凡人可能抓不住；哦，多么年轻奢侈的上帝，谁会知道或问它？……谁能给这样的金子……”

AMORY IS RESENTFUL
艾默里很不满

Slowly and inevitably, yet with a sudden surge at the last, while Amory talked and dreamed, war rolled swiftly up the beach and washed the sands where Princeton played. Every night the gymnasium echoed as platoon after platoon swept over the floor and shuffled out the basket-ball markings. When Amory went to Washington the next week-end he caught some of the spirit of crisis which changed to repulsion in the Pullman car coming back, for the berths across from him were occupied by stinking aliens—Greeks, he guessed, or Russians. He thought how much easier patriotism had been to a homogeneous race, how much easier it would have been to fight as the Colonies fought, or as the Confederacy fought. And he did no sleeping that night, but listened to the aliens guffaw and snore while they filled the car with the heavy scent of latest America.
战争缓慢而不可避免地席卷了海滩，冲刷了普林斯顿打球的沙滩。每天晚上，体育馆里都会回响着排又排的扫过地板并拖出篮球标记的声音。当艾默里下周末去华盛顿时，他在回来的普尔曼汽车上感受到了一些危机精神，这种精神转变为排斥，因为他对面的泊位被臭气熏天的外星人占据了——他猜是希腊人，或者是俄罗斯人。他认为爱国主义对于一个同质的种族来说是多么容易，像殖民地或南部邦联那样进行战斗是多么容易。那天晚上他没有睡觉，只是听着外星人的笑声和鼾声，车里充满了最新美国的浓重气味。

In Princeton every one bantered in public and told themselves privately that their deaths at least would be heroic. The literary students read Rupert Brooke passionately; the lounge-lizards worried over whether the government would permit the English-cut uniform for officers; a few of the hopelessly lazy wrote to the obscure branches of the War Department, seeking an easy commission and a soft berth.
在普林斯顿，每个人都在公开场合开玩笑，并私下告诉自己，他们的死至少会是英勇的。文学系的学生们热情地阅读鲁珀特·布鲁克的作品；休息室蜥蜴们担心政府是否会允许军官穿英式制服；一些极其懒惰的人写信给陆军部不起眼的部门，寻求轻松的佣金和软卧。

Then, after a week, Amory saw Burne and knew at once that argument would be futile—Burne had come out as a pacifist. The socialist magazines, a great smattering of Tolstoi, and his own intense longing for a cause that would bring out whatever strength lay in him, had finally decided him to preach peace as a subjective ideal.
一周后，艾默里见到了伯恩，立刻就知道争论是徒劳的——伯恩已经公开表明自己是一名和平主义者。社会主义杂志、托尔斯泰的一小部分著作，以及他自己对一项能够发挥他的全部力量的事业的强烈渴望，最终决定他将和平作为一种主观理想来宣扬。

“When the German army entered Belgium,” he began, “if the inhabitants had gone peaceably about their business, the German army would have been disorganized in—”
“当德国军队进入比利时时，”他开始说道，“如果居民们和平地处理自己的事情，德国军队就会在——”

“I know,” Amory interrupted, “I’ve heard it all. But I’m not going to talk propaganda with you. There’s a chance that you’re right—but even so we’re hundreds of years before the time when non-resistance can touch us as a reality.”
“我知道，”艾默里打断道，“我都听到了。但我不会和你谈论宣传。你有可能是对的——但即便如此，我们距离不抵抗成为现实还差数百年。”

“But, Amory, listen—”
“但是，艾默里，听着——”

“Burne, we’d just argue—”
“伯恩，我们只是争论——”

“Very well.”
“很好。”

“Just one thing—I don’t ask you to think of your family or friends, because I know they don’t count a picayune with you beside your sense of duty—but, Burne, how do you know that the magazines you read and the societies you join and these idealists you meet aren’t just plain German?”
“只有一件事——我不要求你考虑你的家人或朋友，因为我知道除了你的责任感之外，他们对你毫不关心——但是，伯恩，你怎么知道你读的杂志你加入的社团和你遇到的这些理想主义者不只是普通的德国人吗？”

“Some of them are, of course.”
“当然，其中一些是。”

“How do you know they aren’t all pro-German—just a lot of weak ones—with German-Jewish names.”
“你怎么知道他们并不都是亲德的——只是很多软弱的人——有着德国犹太人的名字。”

“That’s the chance, of course,” he said slowly. “How much or how little I’m taking this stand because of propaganda I’ve heard, I don’t know; naturally I think that it’s my most innermost conviction—it seems a path spread before me just now.”
“当然，这是机会。”他缓缓说道。 “我不知道我采取这一立场有多少是因为我听到的宣传；我不知道。我自然认为这是我内心最深处的信念——这似乎是一条刚才铺在我面前的路。”

Amory’s heart sank.
艾默里的心沉了下去。

“But think of the cheapness of it—no one’s really going to martyr you for being a pacifist—it’s just going to throw you in with the worst—”
“但想想它的廉价之处——没有人真的会因为你是一个和平主义者而牺牲你——它只会让你陷入最糟糕的境地——”

“I doubt it,” he interrupted.
“我对此表示怀疑，”他打断道。

“Well, it all smells of Bohemian New York to me.”
“嗯，对我来说，这里充满了波西米亚纽约的味道。”

“I know what you mean, and that’s why I’m not sure I’ll agitate.”
“我明白你的意思，所以我不确定我会激动不已。”

“You’re one man, Burne—going to talk to people who won’t listen—with all God’s given you.”
“伯恩，你是一个人，要与那些不肯听的人交谈——上帝赐予你一切。”

“That’s what Stephen must have thought many years ago. But he preached his sermon and they killed him. He probably thought as he was dying what a waste it all was. But you see, I’ve always felt that Stephen’s death was the thing that occurred to Paul on the road to Damascus, and sent him to preach the word of Christ all over the world.”
“这就是斯蒂芬多年前的想法。但他宣讲了他的布道，他们却杀了他。当他快要死的时候，他可能觉得这一切都是多么浪费。但你看，我一直觉得司提反的死是保罗在去大马士革的路上发生的事情，并派他去全世界传播基督的话语。”

“Go on.”
“继续。”

“That’s all—this is my particular duty. Even if right now I’m just a pawn—just sacrificed. God! Amory—you don’t think I like the Germans!”
“就是这样——这是我的特殊职责。即使现在我只是一颗棋子——只是被牺牲了。上帝！艾默里——你以为我不喜欢德国人！”

“Well, I can’t say anything else—I get to the end of all the logic about non-resistance, and there, like an excluded middle, stands the huge spectre of man as he is and always will be. And this spectre stands right beside the one logical necessity of Tolstoi’s, and the other logical necessity of Nietzsche’s—” Amory broke off suddenly. “When are you going?”
“好吧，我不能再说什么了——我已经讲完了所有关于不抵抗的逻辑，那里就像一个被排斥的中间人，矗立着一个巨大的幽灵，就像他现在和永远一样。这个幽灵就站在托尔斯泰的一种逻辑必然性和尼采的另一种逻辑必然性旁边——”艾默里突然停了下来。 “你什么时候走？”

“I’m going next week.”
“我下周就去。”

“I’ll see you, of course.”
“我当然会见到你。”

As he walked away it seemed to Amory that the look in his face bore a great resemblance to that in Kerry’s when he had said good-by under Blair Arch two years before. Amory wondered unhappily why he could never go into anything with the primal honesty of those two.
当他走开时，艾默里觉得他脸上的表情与两年前克里在布莱尔·阿奇手下告别时的表情非常相似。艾默里不高兴地想知道为什么他永远不能以这两个人的原始诚实去做任何事情。

“Burne’s a fanatic,” he said to Tom, “and he’s dead wrong and, I’m inclined to think, just an unconscious pawn in the hands of anarchistic publishers and German-paid rag wavers—but he haunts me—just leaving everything worth while—”
“伯恩是个狂热分子，”他对汤姆说，“他大错特错了，我倾向于认为，他只是无政府主义出版商和德国收买的破布摇摇欲坠者手中无意识的棋子——但他困扰着我——只是留下了一切值得——”

Burne left in a quietly dramatic manner a week later. He sold all his possessions and came down to the room to say good-by, with a battered old bicycle, on which he intended to ride to his home in Pennsylvania.
一周后，伯恩以一种平静而戏剧性的方式离开。他卖掉了所有财产，骑着一辆破旧的旧自行车来到房间告别，打算骑着这辆自行车回到宾夕法尼亚州的家。

“Peter the Hermit bidding farewell to Cardinal Richelieu,” suggested Alec, who was lounging in the window-seat as Burne and Amory shook hands.
“隐士彼得正在向红衣主教黎塞留告别，”亚历克建议道，伯恩和艾默里握手时，他正懒洋洋地坐在靠窗的座位上。

But Amory was not in a mood for that, and as he saw Burne’s long legs propel his ridiculous bicycle out of sight beyond Alexander Hall, he knew he was going to have a bad week. Not that he doubted the war—Germany stood for everything repugnant to him; for materialism and the direction of tremendous licentious force; it was just that Burne’s face stayed in his memory and he was sick of the hysteria he was beginning to hear.
但艾默里并没有心情这么做，当他看到伯恩的长腿推动着他那辆可笑的自行车离开亚历山大大厅的视线时，他知道他将度过糟糕的一周。并不是说他怀疑战争——德国代表了他所厌恶的一切。为了物质主义和巨大的淫乱力量的方向；只是伯恩的脸留在了他的记忆中，他厌倦了他开始听到的歇斯底里的声音。

“What on earth is the use of suddenly running down Goethe,” he declared to Alec and Tom. “Why write books to prove he started the war—or that that stupid, overestimated Schiller is a demon in disguise?”
“突然摔倒歌德到底有什么用呢？”他向亚历克和汤姆宣称。 “为什么要写书来证明他发动了战争——或者证明那个愚蠢、高估的席勒是一个伪装的恶魔？”

“Have you ever read anything of theirs?” asked Tom shrewdly.
“你读过他们的作品吗？”汤姆精明地问道。

“No,” Amory admitted.
“不，”艾默里承认。

“Neither have I,” he said laughing.
“我也没有，”他笑着说。

“People will shout,” said Alec quietly, “but Goethe’s on his same old shelf in the library—to bore any one that wants to read him!”
“人们会大喊大叫，”亚历克平静地说，“但歌德就在图书馆的同一个旧书架上——让任何想读他的人感到厌烦！”

Amory subsided, and the subject dropped.
艾默里平静下来，话题就放下了。

“What are you going to do, Amory?”
“你打算做什么，艾默里？”

“Infantry or aviation, I can’t make up my mind—I hate mechanics, but then of course aviation’s the thing for me—”
“步兵还是航空，我拿不定主意——我讨厌机械师，但航空当然适合我——”

“I feel as Amory does,” said Tom. “Infantry or aviation—aviation sounds like the romantic side of the war, of course—like cavalry used to be, you know; but like Amory I don’t know a horse-power from a piston-rod.”
“我的感觉和艾默里一样，”汤姆说。 “步兵或航空——当然，航空听起来像是战争中浪漫的一面——就像以前的骑兵一样，你知道；但就像艾默里一样，我不知道活塞杆产生的马力。”

Somehow Amory’s dissatisfaction with his lack of enthusiasm culminated in an attempt to put the blame for the whole war on the ancestors of his generation... all the people who cheered for Germany in 1870.... All the materialists rampant, all the idolizers of German science and efficiency. So he sat one day in an English lecture and heard “Locksley Hall” quoted and fell into a brown study with contempt for Tennyson and all he stood for—for he took him as a representative of the Victorians.
不知何故，艾默里对自己缺乏热情的不满最终达到了顶峰，他试图将整场战争的责任归咎于他那一代人的祖先……所有在1870年为德国欢呼的人们……所有唯物主义者猖獗，所有偶像崇拜者德国的科学和效率。于是有一天，他坐在一场英语讲座中，听到引用了“洛克斯利大厅”，并陷入了对丁尼生及其所代表的蔑视的棕色研究中——因为他把他视为维多利亚时代的代表。

  Victorians, Victorians, who never learned to weep
  Who sowed the bitter harvest that your children go to reap—

scribbled Amory in his note-book. The lecturer was saying something about Tennyson’s solidity and fifty heads were bent to take notes. Amory turned over to a fresh page and began scrawling again.
艾默里在笔记本上潦草地写着。讲师正在谈论丁尼生的坚定性，五十个头低下头做笔记。艾默里翻到新的一页，又开始潦草地写起来。

 “They shuddered when they found what Mr. Darwin was about,
  They shuddered when the waltz came in and Newman hurried out—”

But the waltz came in much earlier; he crossed that out.
但华尔兹出现得更早。他把那句话划掉了。

“And entitled A Song in the Time of Order,” came the professor’s voice, droning far away. “Time of Order”—Good Lord! Everything crammed in the box and the Victorians sitting on the lid smiling serenely.... With Browning in his Italian villa crying bravely: “All’s for the best.” Amory scribbled again.
“题目是《秩序之歌》，”教授的声音从远处传来，嗡嗡作响。 “秩序时刻”——上帝啊！盒子里塞满了所有东西，维多利亚时代的人坐在盖子上平静地微笑……勃朗宁在他的意大利别墅里勇敢地哭泣：“一切都是为了最好。”艾默里又乱写了一遍。

 “You knelt up in the temple and he bent to hear you pray,
  You thanked him for your ‘glorious gains’—reproached him for
    ‘Cathay.’”

Why could he never get more than a couplet at a time? Now he needed something to rhyme with:
为什么他一次只能得到一副对联？现在他需要一些押韵的东西：

 “You would keep Him straight with science, tho He had gone wrong
    before...”

Well, anyway....
好吧，无论如何……

 “You met your children in your home—‘I’ve fixed it up!’ you cried,
  Took your fifty years of Europe, and then virtuously—died.”

“That was to a great extent Tennyson’s idea,” came the lecturer’s voice. “Swinburne’s Song in the Time of Order might well have been Tennyson’s title. He idealized order against chaos, against waste.”
“这在很大程度上是丁尼生的想法，”讲师的声音传来。 “斯威本的《秩序之歌》很可能就是丁尼生的书名。他理想化了秩序，反对混乱、反对浪费。”

At last Amory had it. He turned over another page and scrawled vigorously for the twenty minutes that was left of the hour. Then he walked up to the desk and deposited a page torn out of his note-book.
艾默里终于做到了。他又翻了一页，用力地写下了最后剩下的二十分钟。然后他走到桌子前，把从笔记本上撕下来的一页放在了上面。

“Here’s a poem to the Victorians, sir,” he said coldly.
“这是一首献给维多利亚时代的诗，先生，”他冷冷地说。

The professor picked it up curiously while Amory backed rapidly through the door.
教授好奇地捡起它，而艾默里迅速退到门外。

Here is what he had written:
这是他写的：

   “Songs in the time of order
      You left for us to sing,
        Proofs with excluded middles,
          Answers to life in rhyme,
    Keys of the prison warder
      And ancient bells to ring,
        Time was the end of riddles,
          We were the end of time...

    Here were domestic oceans
      And a sky that we might reach,
        Guns and a guarded border,
          Gantlets—but not to fling,
    Thousands of old emotions
      And a platitude for each,
        Songs in the time of order—
          And tongues, that we might sing.”

THE END OF MANY THINGS
许多事情的终结

Early April slipped by in a haze—a haze of long evenings on the club veranda with the graphophone playing “Poor Butterfly” inside... for “Poor Butterfly” had been the song of that last year. The war seemed scarcely to touch them and it might have been one of the senior springs of the past, except for the drilling every other afternoon, yet Amory realized poignantly that this was the last spring under the old regime.
四月初在薄雾中溜走了——在俱乐部阳台上度过了漫长的夜晚，留声机在里面播放着《可怜的蝴蝶》……因为《可怜的蝴蝶》是去年的歌曲。战争似乎几乎没有影响到他们，这可能是过去的高级春天之一，除了每隔一个下午的演习，但艾默里痛苦地意识到这是旧政权统治下的最后一个春天。

“This is the great protest against the superman,” said Amory.
“这是对超人的伟大抗议，”艾默里说。

“I suppose so,” Alec agreed.
“我想是的，”亚历克同意道。

“He’s absolutely irreconcilable with any Utopia. As long as he occurs, there’s trouble and all the latent evil that makes a crowd list and sway when he talks.”
“他与任何乌托邦都是绝对不可调和的。只要他一出现，就会有麻烦和所有潜在的邪恶，当他讲话时，人群就会排列并摇摆。”

“And of course all that he is is a gifted man without a moral sense.”
“当然，他只是一个有天赋的人，却没有道德感。”

“That’s all. I think the worst thing to contemplate is this—it’s all happened before, how soon will it happen again? Fifty years after Waterloo Napoleon was as much a hero to English school children as Wellington. How do we know our grandchildren won’t idolize Von Hindenburg the same way?”
“就这样。我认为最糟糕的事情是——这一切都发生过，多久才会再次发生？滑铁卢战争五十年后，拿破仑对于英国学童来说就像惠灵顿一样是英雄。我们怎么知道我们的子孙不会以同样的方式崇拜冯·兴登堡？”

“What brings it about?”
“什么引起的？”

“Time, damn it, and the historian. If we could only learn to look on evil as evil, whether it’s clothed in filth or monotony or magnificence.”
“时间，该死的，还有历史学家。如果我们能学会将邪恶视为邪恶就好了，无论它是肮脏的、单调的还是华丽的。”

“God! Haven’t we raked the universe over the coals for four years?”
“上帝！我们不是已经用炭火把宇宙扫了四年了吗？”

Then the night came that was to be the last. Tom and Amory, bound in the morning for different training-camps, paced the shadowy walks as usual and seemed still to see around them the faces of the men they knew.
然后那个夜晚来临了，那是最后一个夜晚。汤姆和艾默里早上要去不同的训练营，像往常一样在阴暗的小路上踱步，似乎仍然能看到周围他们认识的人的脸。

“The grass is full of ghosts to-night.”
“今晚草地上充满了鬼魂。”

“The whole campus is alive with them.”
“整个校园都充满了他们的活力。”

They paused by Little and watched the moon rise, to make silver of the slate roof of Dodd and blue the rustling trees.
他们在利特尔附近停下来，看着月亮升起，把多德的石板屋顶染成银色，把沙沙作响的树木染成蓝色。

“You know,” whispered Tom, “what we feel now is the sense of all the gorgeous youth that has rioted through here in two hundred years.”
“你知道，”汤姆低声说，“我们现在感受到的是两百年来所有在这里骚乱的华丽年轻人的感觉。”

A last burst of singing flooded up from Blair Arch—broken voices for some long parting.
最后一阵歌声从布莱尔拱门传来——那是一段漫长的离别的破碎的声音。

“And what we leave here is more than this class; it’s the whole heritage of youth. We’re just one generation—we’re breaking all the links that seemed to bind us here to top-booted and high-stocked generations. We’ve walked arm and arm with Burr and Light-Horse Harry Lee through half these deep-blue nights.”
“我们在这里留下的不仅仅是这个班级；这是年轻人的全部遗产。我们只是一代人——我们正在打破所有似乎将我们与穿着顶级靴子和高库存的一代人联系在一起的联系。我们与伯尔和轻马哈利·李一起走过了一半的深蓝色夜晚。”

“That’s what they are,” Tom tangented off, “deep blue—a bit of color would spoil them, make them exotic. Spires, against a sky that’s a promise of dawn, and blue light on the slate roofs—it hurts... rather—”
“它们就是这样，”汤姆岔开话题，“深蓝色——一点点颜色就会破坏它们，让它们变得充满异国情调。尖塔，衬托着黎明的天空，石板屋顶上的蓝光——这很伤人……更确切地说——”

“Good-by, Aaron Burr,” Amory called toward deserted Nassau Hall, “you and I knew strange corners of life.”
“再见，亚伦·伯尔，”艾默里朝废弃的拿骚大厅喊道，“你和我都知道生活中奇怪的角落。”

His voice echoed in the stillness.
他的声音在寂静中回响。

“The torches are out,” whispered Tom. “Ah, Messalina, the long shadows are building minarets on the stadium—”
“火把灭了，”汤姆低声说道。 “啊，梅萨琳娜，长长的影子正在体育场上建造尖塔——”

For an instant the voices of freshman year surged around them and then they looked at each other with faint tears in their eyes.
一瞬间，一年级的声音在他们周围响起，然后他们互相看着对方，眼里都含着淡淡的泪水。

“Damn!”

“Damn!”

The last light fades and drifts across the land—the low, long land, the sunny land of spires; the ghosts of evening tune again their lyres and wander singing in a plaintive band down the long corridors of trees; pale fires echo the night from tower top to tower: Oh, sleep that dreams, and dream that never tires, press from the petals of the lotus flower something of this to keep, the essence of an hour.
最后的光芒渐渐消逝，飘过大地——低矮而漫长的土地，阳光明媚的尖顶土地；夜晚的鬼魂再次弹起竖琴，在哀伤的乐队中沿着树木长廊漫步歌唱。苍白的火焰从塔顶到塔楼回响着夜色：哦，睡眠的梦，永不疲倦的梦，从莲花的花瓣中压出一些东西来保留，一个小时的精华。

No more to wait the twilight of the moon in this sequestered vale of star and spire, for one eternal morning of desire passes to time and earthy afternoon. Here, Heraclitus, did you find in fire and shifting things the prophecy you hurled down the dead years; this midnight my desire will see, shadowed among the embers, furled in flame, the splendor and the sadness of the world.
不再需要在这个星辰和尖顶的僻静山谷中等待月光的黄昏，因为一个永恒的欲望早晨会变成时间和朴实的下午。赫拉克利特，在这里，你在火和变化的事物中找到了你在死去的岁月中抛出的预言吗？这个午夜，我的愿望将看到，在余烬的阴影下，在火焰中，看到世界的辉煌和悲伤。





INTERLUDE

May, 1917-February, 1919
1917 年 5 月至 1919 年 2 月

A letter dated January, 1918, written by Monsignor Darcy to Amory, who is a second lieutenant in the 171st Infantry, Port of Embarkation, Camp Mills, Long Island.
达西大人于 1918 年 1 月写给艾默里的一封​​信，艾默里是长岛米尔斯营地登船港第 171 步兵团的少尉。

MY DEAR BOY:
我亲爱的男孩：

All you need tell me of yourself is that you still are; for the rest I merely search back in a restive memory, a thermometer that records only fevers, and match you with what I was at your age. But men will chatter and you and I will still shout our futilities to each other across the stage until the last silly curtain falls plump! upon our bobbing heads. But you are starting the spluttering magic-lantern show of life with much the same array of slides as I had, so I need to write you if only to shriek the colossal stupidity of people....
你只需要告诉我你自己，你仍然是；其余的我只是在不稳定的记忆中搜索，就像一只只记录发烧的温度计，然后将你与我在你这个年纪的情况进行匹配。但人们会喋喋不休，你和我仍然会在舞台上互相喊叫我们的徒劳，直到最后一个愚蠢的帷幕落下！在我们摇摆的头上。但你正在开始用与我几乎相同的幻灯片来开始生命中的神奇灯笼表演，所以我需要写信给你，只是为了尖叫人们的巨大愚蠢......

This is the end of one thing: for better or worse you will never again be quite the Amory Blaine that I knew, never again will we meet as we have met, because your generation is growing hard, much harder than mine ever grew, nourished as they were on the stuff of the nineties.
这是一件事的结束：无论好坏，你再也不会成为我认识的艾默里·布莱恩，我们再也不会像我们见面时那样见面，因为你们这一代正在努力成长，比我的成长更努力，滋养就像他们谈论九十年代的东西一样。

Amory, lately I reread Aeschylus and there in the divine irony of the “Agamemnon” I find the only answer to this bitter age—all the world tumbled about our ears, and the closest parallel ages back in that hopeless resignation. There are times when I think of the men out there as Roman legionaries, miles from their corrupt city, stemming back the hordes... hordes a little more menacing, after all, than the corrupt city... another blind blow at the race, furies that we passed with ovations years ago, over whose corpses we bleated triumphantly all through the Victorian era....
艾默里，最近我重读了埃斯库罗斯，在《阿伽门农》的神圣讽刺中，我找到了这个痛苦时代的唯一答案——整个世界都在我们耳边翻滚，而最接近的平行时代又回到了那个绝望的顺从之中。有时我会想到那些罗马军团的人，距离他们腐败的城市数英里，阻止部落……毕竟，部落比腐败的城市更具威胁性……对种族的又一次盲目打击多年前，我们欢呼雀跃地经历了愤怒，在整个维多利亚时代，我们对着他们的尸体得意洋洋地咩咩叫着......

And afterward an out-and-out materialistic world—and the Catholic Church. I wonder where you’ll fit in. Of one thing I’m sure—Celtic you’ll live and Celtic you’ll die; so if you don’t use heaven as a continual referendum for your ideas you’ll find earth a continual recall to your ambitions.
然后是一个彻头彻尾的唯物主义世界——以及天主教会。我想知道你会融入哪里。我确信一件事——凯尔特人你会活下去，凯尔特人你会死；因此，如果你不使用天堂作为对你的想法的持续公投，你会发现地球不断地回忆起你的野心。

Amory, I’ve discovered suddenly that I’m an old man. Like all old men, I’ve had dreams sometimes and I’m going to tell you of them. I’ve enjoyed imagining that you were my son, that perhaps when I was young I went into a state of coma and begat you, and when I came to, had no recollection of it... it’s the paternal instinct, Amory—celibacy goes deeper than the flesh....
艾默里，我突然发现我已经是个老人了。像所有老人一样，我有时也会做梦，我会把它们告诉你。我很高兴想象你是我的儿子，也许当我年轻的时候，我陷入了昏迷状态，生下了你，当我醒来时，已经不记得了……这是父亲的本能，艾默里——独身比肉体更深入......

Sometimes I think that the explanation of our deep resemblance is some common ancestor, and I find that the only blood that the Darcys and the O’Haras have in common is that of the O’Donahues... Stephen was his name, I think....
有时我认为我们深深的相似性的解释是一些共同的祖先，我发现达西家族和奥哈拉家族唯一的共同血统是奥多纳休家族……我想斯蒂芬是他的名字....

When the lightning strikes one of us it strikes both: you had hardly arrived at the port of embarkation when I got my papers to start for Rome, and I am waiting every moment to be told where to take ship. Even before you get this letter I shall be on the ocean; then will come your turn. You went to war as a gentleman should, just as you went to school and college, because it was the thing to do. It’s better to leave the blustering and tremulo-heroism to the middle classes; they do it so much better.
当闪电击中我们中的一个人时，同时也击中了两个人：当我拿到前往罗马的文件时，你几乎没有到达登船港，而我每时每刻都在等待被告知在哪里乘船。甚至在你收到这封信之前我就已经在海上了；然后就轮到你了。你像一个绅士一样去参战，就像你上学和上大学一样，因为这是你该做的事情。最好把咆哮和颤抖的英雄主义留给中产阶级；他们做得更好。

Do you remember that week-end last March when you brought Burne Holiday from Princeton to see me? What a magnificent boy he is! It gave me a frightful shock afterward when you wrote that he thought me splendid; how could he be so deceived? Splendid is the one thing that neither you nor I are. We are many other things—we’re extraordinary, we’re clever, we could be said, I suppose, to be brilliant. We can attract people, we can make atmosphere, we can almost lose our Celtic souls in Celtic subtleties, we can almost always have our own way; but splendid—rather not!
你还记得去年三月的那个周末，你从普林斯顿带着伯恩·霍利迪来见我吗？他是一个多么出色的男孩啊！当你后来写到他认为我很棒时，我感到非常震惊。他怎么会被这样欺骗呢？辉煌是你我都不是的一件事。我们还有很多其他的特质——我们非凡，我们聪明，我想，我们可以说是才华横溢。我们可以吸引人，我们可以制造气氛，我们几乎可以在凯尔特人的精妙中失去凯尔特人的灵魂，我们几乎可以随心所欲；但精彩——而不是！

I am going to Rome with a wonderful dossier and letters of introduction that cover every capital in Europe, and there will be “no small stir” when I get there. How I wish you were with me! This sounds like a rather cynical paragraph, not at all the sort of thing that a middle-aged clergyman should write to a youth about to depart for the war; the only excuse is that the middle-aged clergyman is talking to himself. There are deep things in us and you know what they are as well as I do. We have great faith, though yours at present is uncrystallized; we have a terrible honesty that all our sophistry cannot destroy and, above all, a childlike simplicity that keeps us from ever being really malicious.
我将带着一份涵盖欧洲每个首都的精彩档案和介绍信前往罗马，当我到达那里时，将会引起“不小的轰动”。我多么希望你能和我在一起啊！这听起来像是一段相当愤世嫉俗的段落，根本不是一个中年牧师应该写给一个即将启程参战的年轻人的东西；唯一的借口就是中年牧师在自言自语。我们身上有一些深刻的东西，你和我一样知道它们是什么。我们有伟大的信念，尽管你们的信念目前还没有具体化；我们有一种可怕的诚实，这是我们所有的诡辩都无法摧毁的，最重要的是，我们有一种孩子般的单纯，使我们永远不会变得真正恶意。

I have written a keen for you which follows. I am sorry your cheeks are not up to the description I have written of them, but you will smoke and read all night—
我为你写了一封热心的信，如下。我很抱歉你的脸颊不符合我所写的描述，但你会抽烟并整夜读书——

At any rate here it is:
无论如何，这里是：

A Lament for a Foster Son, and He going to the War Against the King of Foreign.
对养子的哀悼，以及他去对抗外国国王的战争。

 “Ochone
  He is gone from me the son of my mind
    And he in his golden youth like Angus Oge
  Angus of the bright birds
    And his mind strong and subtle like the mind of Cuchulin on
      Muirtheme.

  Awirra sthrue
  His brow is as white as the milk of the cows of Maeve
    And his cheeks like the cherries of the tree
  And it bending down to Mary and she feeding the Son of God.

  Aveelia Vrone
  His hair is like the golden collar of the Kings at Tara
    And his eyes like the four gray seas of Erin.
  And they swept with the mists of rain.

  Mavrone go Gudyo
  He to be in the joyful and red battle
    Amongst the chieftains and they doing great deeds of valor
  His life to go from him
    It is the chords of my own soul would be loosed.

  A Vich Deelish
  My heart is in the heart of my son
    And my life is in his life surely
  A man can be twice young
    In the life of his sons only.

  Jia du Vaha Alanav
  May the Son of God be above him and beneath him, before him and
      behind him
    May the King of the elements cast a mist over the eyes of the
      King of Foreign,
  May the Queen of the Graces lead him by the hand the way he can
      go through the midst of his enemies and they not seeing him

  May Patrick of the Gael and Collumb of the Churches and the five
      thousand Saints of Erin be better than a shield to him
  And he got into the fight.
    Och Ochone.”

Amory—Amory—I feel, somehow, that this is all; one or both of us is not going to last out this war.... I’ve been trying to tell you how much this reincarnation of myself in you has meant in the last few years... curiously alike we are... curiously unlike. Good-by, dear boy, and God be with you. THAYER DARCY.
艾默里——艾默里——不知何故，我觉得这就是全部了；我们中的一个或两个都无法坚持这场战争……我一直试图告诉你，在过去的几年里，我在你身上的转世意味着什么……奇怪的是，我们很相似……奇怪的是不像。再见，亲爱的孩子，愿上帝与你同在。塞耶·达西。

EMBARKING AT NIGHT
夜间登船

Amory moved forward on the deck until he found a stool under an electric light. He searched in his pocket for note-book and pencil and then began to write, slowly, laboriously:
艾默里在甲板上向前走，直到他在电灯下找到了一张凳子。他在口袋里寻找笔记本和铅笔，然后开始缓慢而费力地写下：

 “We leave to-night...
    Silent, we filled the still, deserted street,
      A column of dim gray,
    And ghosts rose startled at the muffled beat
      Along the moonless way;
    The shadowy shipyards echoed to the feet
      That turned from night and day.

    And so we linger on the windless decks,
      See on the spectre shore
    Shades of a thousand days, poor gray-ribbed wrecks...
      Oh, shall we then deplore
    Those futile years!
                      See how the sea is white!
    The clouds have broken and the heavens burn
      To hollow highways, paved with gravelled light
    The churning of the waves about the stern
      Rises to one voluminous nocturne,
                         ... We leave to-night.”

A letter from Amory, headed “Brest, March 11th, 1919,” to Lieutenant T. P. D’Invilliers, Camp Gordon, Ga.
艾默里写给佐治亚州戈登营 T.P. D’Invilliers 中尉的一封信，抬头为“布雷斯特，1919 年 3 月 11 日”。

DEAR BAUDELAIRE:—
亲爱的波德莱尔：——

We meet in Manhattan on the 30th of this very mo.; we then proceed to take a very sporty apartment, you and I and Alec, who is at me elbow as I write. I don’t know what I’m going to do but I have a vague dream of going into politics. Why is it that the pick of the young Englishmen from Oxford and Cambridge go into politics and in the U. S. A. we leave it to the muckers?—raised in the ward, educated in the assembly and sent to Congress, fat-paunched bundles of corruption, devoid of “both ideas and ideals” as the debaters used to say. Even forty years ago we had good men in politics, but we, we are brought up to pile up a million and “show what we are made of.” Sometimes I wish I’d been an Englishman; American life is so damned dumb and stupid and healthy.
我们于本月 30 日在曼哈顿见面；然后我们就去一间非常运动的公寓，你、我和亚历克，在我写这篇文章的时候，他就在我身边。我不知道自己要做什么，但我有一个模糊的梦想：从政。为什么牛津和剑桥的年轻英国人会从政，而在美国，我们却把它留给了那些混蛋？——在选区长大，在议会受教育，然后被送到国会，大腹便便的腐败分子，正如辩手们常说的那样，缺乏“思想和理想”。即使四十年前，我们在政治上也有好人，但我们，我们从小就被教育要积累一百万，并“展示我们是由什么组成的”。有时我希望自己是一个英国人；美国人的生活真是愚蠢又愚蠢却又健康。

Since poor Beatrice died I’ll probably have a little money, but very darn little. I can forgive mother almost everything except the fact that in a sudden burst of religiosity toward the end, she left half of what remained to be spent in stained-glass windows and seminary endowments. Mr. Barton, my lawyer, writes me that my thousands are mostly in street railways and that the said Street R.R. s are losing money because of the five-cent fares. Imagine a salary list that gives $350 a month to a man that can’t read and write!—yet I believe in it, even though I’ve seen what was once a sizable fortune melt away between speculation, extravagance, the democratic administration, and the income tax—modern, that’s me all over, Mabel.
自从可怜的比阿特丽斯死后，我可能会有一点钱，但非常少。我几乎可以原谅母亲的一切，除了在最后突然爆发的宗教信仰中，她把剩下的一半钱花在了彩色玻璃窗和神学院的捐赠上。我的律师巴顿先生写信给我说，我的数千人大部分都在街道铁路上，而所说的街道 R.R. 由于 5 美分的票价而正在赔钱。想象一下，一份工资清单为一个不会读写的人提供每月 350 美元的工资！——但我相信它，尽管我已经看到曾经相当大的财富在投机、奢侈、民主管理之间消失，还有所得税——现代的，这就是我，梅布尔。

At any rate we’ll have really knock-out rooms—you can get a job on some fashion magazine, and Alec can go into the Zinc Company or whatever it is that his people own—he’s looking over my shoulder and he says it’s a brass company, but I don’t think it matters much, do you? There’s probably as much corruption in zinc-made money as brass-made money. As for the well-known Amory, he would write immortal literature if he were sure enough about anything to risk telling any one else about it. There is no more dangerous gift to posterity than a few cleverly turned platitudes.
无论如何，我们都会有真正令人惊叹的房间——你可以在一些时尚杂志上找到一份工作，亚历克可以进入锌公司或他的人拥有的任何公司——他在我身后看着，他说这是一个黄铜公司，但我认为这并不重要，是吗？锌制货币的腐败现象可能与黄铜制货币一样多。至于著名的艾默里，如果他对任何事情有足够的把握，敢于冒险告诉别人，他就会写出不朽的文学作品。对于子孙后代来说，没有什么比一些巧妙的陈词滥调更危险的礼物了。

Tom, why don’t you become a Catholic? Of course to be a good one you’d have to give up those violent intrigues you used to tell me about, but you’d write better poetry if you were linked up to tall golden candlesticks and long, even chants, and even if the American priests are rather burgeois, as Beatrice used to say, still you need only go to the sporty churches, and I’ll introduce you to Monsignor Darcy who really is a wonder.
汤姆，你为什么不成为天主教徒呢？当然，要成为一名好诗人，你必须放弃你曾经告诉过我的那些暴力阴谋，但如果你与高高的金色烛台和长而均匀的颂歌联系在一起，你会写出更好的诗，即使美国的牧师相当资产阶级，就像比阿特丽斯常说的那样，但你只需要去运动教堂，我会向你介绍达西主教，他确实是一个奇迹。

Kerry’s death was a blow, so was Jesse’s to a certain extent. And I have a great curiosity to know what queer corner of the world has swallowed Burne. Do you suppose he’s in prison under some false name? I confess that the war instead of making me orthodox, which is the correct reaction, has made me a passionate agnostic. The Catholic Church has had its wings clipped so often lately that its part was timidly negligible, and they haven’t any good writers any more. I’m sick of Chesterton.
克里的死是一个打击，杰西的死在一定程度上也是一个打击。我非常想知道世界上哪个奇怪的角落吞噬了伯恩。你认为他以假名入狱吗？我承认，战争并没有让我变得正统（这是正确的反应），而是让我成为一个热情的不可知论者。天主教会最近经常被折断翅膀，以至于它的作用几乎可以忽略不计，而且他们也不再有任何优秀的作家了。我厌倦了切斯特顿。

I’ve only discovered one soldier who passed through the much-advertised spiritual crisis, like this fellow, Donald Hankey, and the one I knew was already studying for the ministry, so he was ripe for it. I honestly think that’s all pretty much rot, though it seemed to give sentimental comfort to those at home; and may make fathers and mothers appreciate their children. This crisis-inspired religion is rather valueless and fleeting at best. I think four men have discovered Paris to one that discovered God.
我只发现一名士兵经历了广为人知的精神危机，就像这个家伙唐纳德·汉基一样，而我认识的那个人已经在为内阁学习，所以他已经做好了准备。老实说，我认为这一切都已经很糟糕了，尽管它似乎给家里的人带来了情感上的安慰。并可能让父母欣赏他们的孩子。这种受危机启发的宗教毫无价值，充其量也是转瞬即逝的。我认为四个人发现了巴黎，一个人发现了上帝。

But us—you and me and Alec—oh, we’ll get a Jap butler and dress for dinner and have wine on the table and lead a contemplative, emotionless life until we decide to use machine-guns with the property owners—or throw bombs with the Bolshevik God! Tom, I hope something happens. I’m restless as the devil and have a horror of getting fat or falling in love and growing domestic.
但我们——你、我和亚历克——哦，我们会找个日本管家，穿好衣服去吃晚饭，桌上放着酒，过着沉思、无感情的生活，直到我们决定对业主使用机枪——或者扔掉布尔什维克上帝的炸弹！汤姆，我希望有事情发生。我像魔鬼一样焦躁不安，害怕变胖、坠入爱河和家庭生活。

The place at Lake Geneva is now for rent but when I land I’m going West to see Mr. Barton and get some details. Write me care of the Blackstone, Chicago.
日内瓦湖的房子现在正在出租，但当我着陆时，我要去西部见巴顿先生并了解一些细节。请写信给我转交芝加哥黑石公司。

              S’ever, dear Boswell,

                                  SAMUEL JOHNSON.





BOOK TWO—The Education of a Personage
第二册——人物的教育





CHAPTER 1. The Debutante
第一章 初出茅庐的人

The time is February. The place is a large, dainty bedroom in the Connage house on Sixty-eighth Street, New York. A girl’s room: pink walls and curtains and a pink bedspread on a cream-colored bed. Pink and cream are the motifs of the room, but the only article of furniture in full view is a luxurious dressing-table with a glass top and a three-sided mirror. On the walls there is an expensive print of “Cherry Ripe,” a few polite dogs by Landseer, and the “King of the Black Isles,” by Maxfield Parrish.
时间是二月。这个地方是纽约六十八街康纳奇别墅的一间宽敞、精致的卧室。女孩的房间：粉色的墙壁和窗帘，米色的床上铺着粉色的床罩。粉色和奶油色是房间的主题，但唯一能看到全景的家具是一张带有玻璃顶和三面镜的豪华梳妆台。墙上挂着一幅昂贵的印刷品：《樱桃熟了》、兰西尔创作的几只礼貌的狗，以及麦克斯菲尔德·帕里什创作的《黑岛之王》。

Great disorder consisting of the following items: (1) seven or eight empty cardboard boxes, with tissue-paper tongues hanging panting from their mouths; (2) an assortment of street dresses mingled with their sisters of the evening, all upon the table, all evidently new; (3) a roll of tulle, which has lost its dignity and wound itself tortuously around everything in sight, and (4) upon the two small chairs, a collection of lingerie that beggars description. One would enjoy seeing the bill called forth by the finery displayed and one is possessed by a desire to see the princess for whose benefit—Look! There’s some one! Disappointment! This is only a maid hunting for something—she lifts a heap from a chair—Not there; another heap, the dressing-table, the chiffonier drawers. She brings to light several beautiful chemises and an amazing pajama but this does not satisfy her—she goes out.
严重混乱，包括以下物品：（一）七八个空纸箱，嘴里挂着薄纸舌头，气喘吁吁； (2) 各种街头服饰与晚间姐妹装混杂在一起，全部摆在桌子上，显然都是新的； （3）一卷薄纱，它失去了尊严，曲折地缠绕在视线中的一切周围，（4）两把小椅子上，有一堆难以描述的内衣。人们会很高兴看到展示的华丽服饰所带来的账单，并且人们会渴望见到公主，看看她是为了谁的利益——看！有一个！失望！这只是一个女仆在寻找什么东西——她从椅子上举起一堆东西——不在那儿；另一堆，梳妆台，抽屉柜。她展示了几件漂亮的衬衣和一件令人惊叹的睡衣，但这并不能让她满意——她出去了。

An indistinguishable mumble from the next room.
与隔壁房间无法区分的咕哝声。

Now, we are getting warm. This is Alec’s mother, Mrs. Connage, ample, dignified, rouged to the dowager point and quite worn out. Her lips move significantly as she looks for IT. Her search is less thorough than the maid’s but there is a touch of fury in it, that quite makes up for its sketchiness. She stumbles on the tulle and her “damn” is quite audible. She retires, empty-handed.
现在，我们正在变暖。这是亚历克的母亲，康纳奇夫人，身材魁梧，端庄，涂着浓浓的胭脂，而且十分疲惫。当她寻找它时，她的嘴唇明显地动动着。她的搜查不如女仆彻底，但其中有一丝愤怒，这足以弥补它的粗略。她被薄纱绊倒了，她的“该死”的声音清晰可闻。她退休了，两手空空。

More chatter outside and a girl’s voice, a very spoiled voice, says: “Of all the stupid people—”
外面更多的闲聊声，一个女孩的声音，一种非常被宠坏的声音说：“在所有愚蠢的人中——”

After a pause a third seeker enters, not she of the spoiled voice, but a younger edition. This is Cecelia Connage, sixteen, pretty, shrewd, and constitutionally good-humored. She is dressed for the evening in a gown the obvious simplicity of which probably bores her. She goes to the nearest pile, selects a small pink garment and holds it up appraisingly.
停顿后，第三位探索者进来了，不是她那个声音被宠坏了的人，而是一个年轻的版本。这是塞西莉亚·康纳奇，十六岁，漂亮、精明、天生幽默。晚上她穿着一件明显简单的礼服，这可能会让她感到厌烦。她走到最近的一堆衣服前，挑选了一件粉红色的小衣服，举起它，评价道。

CECELIA: Pink?

ROSALIND: (Outside) Yes!
罗瑟琳：（外面）是的！

CECELIA: Very snappy?
塞西莉亚：很活泼吗？

ROSALIND: Yes!
罗瑟琳：是的！

CECELIA: I’ve got it!
塞西莉亚：我明白了！

(She sees herself in the mirror of the dressing-table and commences to shimmy enthusiastically.)
（她在梳妆台的镜子里看到了自己，开始热情地摇摆起来。）

ROSALIND: (Outside) What are you doing—trying it on?
罗瑟琳：（外面）你在做什么——试穿？

(CECELIA ceases and goes out carrying the garment at the right shoulder.
（塞西莉亚停下来，拎着右肩的衣服走了出去。

From the other door, enters ALEC CONNAGE. He looks around quickly and in a huge voice shouts: Mama! There is a chorus of protest from next door and encouraged he starts toward it, but is repelled by another chorus.)
亚历克·康纳奇 (ALEC CONNAGE) 从另一扇门进来。他迅速环顾四周，大声喊道：妈妈！隔壁传来一阵抗议声，鼓励他朝那里走去，但又被另一声合唱击退。）

ALEC: So that’s where you all are! Amory Blaine is here.
ALEC：原来你们都在这儿！艾默里·布莱恩来了。

CECELIA: (Quickly) Take him down-stairs.
塞西莉亚：（快步）带他下楼。

ALEC: Oh, he is down-stairs.
亚历克：哦，他在楼下。

MRS. CONNAGE: Well, you can show him where his room is. Tell him I’m sorry that I can’t meet him now.
太太。 CONNAGE：嗯，你可以告诉他他的房间在哪里。告诉他我很抱歉现在不能见他。

ALEC: He’s heard a lot about you all. I wish you’d hurry. Father’s telling him all about the war and he’s restless. He’s sort of temperamental.
ALEC：他听说过很多关于你们的事。我希望你快点。父亲向他讲述了战争的一切，他却焦躁不安。他的脾气有点暴躁。

(This last suffices to draw CECELIA into the room.)
（这足以将塞西莉亚吸引到房间里。）

CECELIA: (Seating herself high upon lingerie) How do you mean—temperamental? You used to say that about him in letters.
塞西莉亚：（高高地坐在内衣上）你是什么意思——喜怒无常？你过去常在信中这样评价他。

ALEC: Oh, he writes stuff.
ALEC：哦，他写东西。

CECELIA: Does he play the piano?
塞西莉亚：他弹钢琴吗？

ALEC: Don’t think so.
亚历克：不这么认为。

CECELIA: (Speculatively) Drink?
塞西莉亚：（若有所思地）喝酒？

ALEC: Yes—nothing queer about him.
亚历克：是的——他没有什么奇怪的。

CECELIA: Money?
塞西莉亚：钱？

ALEC: Good Lord—ask him, he used to have a lot, and he’s got some income now.
ALEC：天啊——你去问他吧，他以前有很多，现在也有一些收入了。

(MRS. CONNAGE appears.)
（康纳吉夫人出现。）

MRS. CONNAGE: Alec, of course we’re glad to have any friend of yours—
太太。 CONNAGE：亚历克，我们当然很高兴有你的朋友——

ALEC: You certainly ought to meet Amory.
ALEC：你当然应该见见艾默里。

MRS. CONNAGE: Of course, I want to. But I think it’s so childish of you to leave a perfectly good home to go and live with two other boys in some impossible apartment. I hope it isn’t in order that you can all drink as much as you want. (She pauses.) He’ll be a little neglected to-night. This is Rosalind’s week, you see. When a girl comes out, she needs all the attention.
太太。康纳吉：当然，我愿意。但我认为你离开一个完美的家去和另外两个男孩住在一个不可能的公寓里真是太幼稚了。我希望这不是为了让大家可以想喝多少就喝多少。 （她停顿了一下）今晚他会有点被忽视。你看，这是罗莎琳德的一周。当一个女孩出来的时候，她需要所有的关注。

ROSALIND: (Outside) Well, then, prove it by coming here and hooking me.
罗瑟琳：（外面）好吧，那么，到这里来勾引我来证明这一点。

(MRS. CONNAGE goes.)
（科纳吉夫人走了。）

ALEC: Rosalind hasn’t changed a bit.
ALEC：罗莎琳德一点也没变。

CECELIA: (In a lower tone) She’s awfully spoiled.
塞西莉亚：（低声）她被宠坏了。

ALEC: She’ll meet her match to-night.
ALEC：她今晚会遇到对手。

CECELIA: Who—Mr. Amory Blaine?
塞西莉亚： 谁——先生。艾默里·布莱恩？

(ALEC nods.)
（亚历克点头。）

CECELIA: Well, Rosalind has still to meet the man she can’t outdistance. Honestly, Alec, she treats men terribly. She abuses them and cuts them and breaks dates with them and yawns in their faces—and they come back for more.
塞西莉亚：好吧，罗莎琳德还要去见那个她无法超越的男人。老实说，亚历克，她对待男人很糟糕。她虐待他们、割伤他们、取消与他们的约会、对着他们打哈欠——而他们又回来索取更多。

ALEC: They love it.
亚历克：他们喜欢它。

CECELIA: They hate it. She’s a—she’s a sort of vampire, I think—and she can make girls do what she wants usually—only she hates girls.
塞西莉亚：他们讨厌它。她是——她是一种吸血鬼，我认为——她通常可以让女孩做她想做的事——只是她讨厌女孩。

ALEC: Personality runs in our family.
ALEC：个性是我们家族的基因。

CECELIA: (Resignedly) I guess it ran out before it got to me.
塞西莉亚：（无奈地）我想在我收到之前它就已经用完了。

ALEC: Does Rosalind behave herself?
ALEC：罗莎琳德表现得好吗？

CECELIA: Not particularly well. Oh, she’s average—smokes sometimes, drinks punch, frequently kissed—Oh, yes—common knowledge—one of the effects of the war, you know.
塞西莉亚：不是特别好。哦，她很普通——有时抽烟，喝潘趣酒，经常接吻——哦，是的——众所周知——这是战争的影响之一，你知道。

(Emerges MRS. CONNAGE.)
（康纳吉夫人出场。）

MRS. CONNAGE: Rosalind’s almost finished so I can go down and meet your friend.
太太。康纳奇：罗莎琳德快完成了，所以我可以下去见见你的朋友。

(ALEC and his mother go out.)
（亚历克和他的母亲出去了。）

ROSALIND: (Outside) Oh, mother—
罗瑟琳：（外面）哦，妈妈——

CECELIA: Mother’s gone down.
塞西莉亚：妈妈去世了。

(And now ROSALIND enters. ROSALIND is—utterly ROSALIND. She is one of those girls who need never make the slightest effort to have men fall in love with them. Two types of men seldom do: dull men are usually afraid of her cleverness and intellectual men are usually afraid of her beauty. All others are hers by natural prerogative.
（现在罗瑟琳进来了。罗瑟琳是——完全是罗瑟琳。她是那种不需要付出任何努力就能让男人爱上她们的女孩之一。有两种类型的男人很少这样做：迟钝的男人通常害怕她的聪明和有知识的男人通常害怕她的美貌。其他人都是她的天然特权。

If ROSALIND could be spoiled the process would have been complete by this time, and as a matter of fact, her disposition is not all it should be; she wants what she wants when she wants it and she is prone to make every one around her pretty miserable when she doesn’t get it—but in the true sense she is not spoiled. Her fresh enthusiasm, her will to grow and learn, her endless faith in the inexhaustibility of romance, her courage and fundamental honesty—these things are not spoiled.
如果罗瑟琳能够被宠坏的话，这个过程早就已经完成了，而事实上，她的性情并不完全应该如此；当她想要的时候，她就想要她想要的；当她得不到的时候，她很容易让周围的每个人都非常痛苦——但从真正意义上来说，她并没有被宠坏。她新鲜的热情，她成长和学习的意愿，她对浪漫的无穷无尽的信念，她的勇气和基本的诚实——这些东西都没有被宠坏。

There are long periods when she cordially loathes her whole family. She is quite unprincipled; her philosophy is carpe diem for herself and laissez faire for others. She loves shocking stories: she has that coarse streak that usually goes with natures that are both fine and big. She wants people to like her, but if they do not it never worries her or changes her. She is by no means a model character.
有很长一段时间，她真诚地厌恶她的整个家庭。她是个很没有原则的人；她的哲学是对自己及时行乐，对他人自由放任。她喜欢令人震惊的故事：她有一种粗俗的性格，通常与精致而伟大的性格相配。她希望人们喜欢她，但如果他们不喜欢她，她也不会担心或改变。她绝不是一个模范人物。

The education of all beautiful women is the knowledge of men. ROSALIND had been disappointed in man after man as individuals, but she had great faith in man as a sex. Women she detested. They represented qualities that she felt and despised in herself—incipient meanness, conceit, cowardice, and petty dishonesty. She once told a roomful of her mother’s friends that the only excuse for women was the necessity for a disturbing element among men. She danced exceptionally well, drew cleverly but hastily, and had a startling facility with words, which she used only in love-letters.
所有美丽女人的教育都是男人的知识。罗莎琳德对一个又一个的男人感到失望，但她对男人作为性别充满信心。她讨厌的女人。它们代表了她所感受到并鄙视的自己的品质——刚开始的卑鄙、自负、怯懦和小小的不诚实。她曾经对一屋子母亲的朋友们说，女性唯一的借口就是男性中存在令人不安的因素。她跳舞跳得特别好，画画巧妙但仓促，语言能力惊人，但她只在情书上使用。

But all criticism of ROSALIND ends in her beauty. There was that shade of glorious yellow hair, the desire to imitate which supports the dye industry. There was the eternal kissable mouth, small, slightly sensual, and utterly disturbing. There were gray eyes and an unimpeachable skin with two spots of vanishing color. She was slender and athletic, without underdevelopment, and it was a delight to watch her move about a room, walk along a street, swing a golf club, or turn a “cartwheel.”
但对罗莎琳德的所有批评都以她的美貌为结束。那种光鲜亮丽的黄色头发，以及对模仿的渴望支撑着染料行业。那是一张永远值得亲吻的嘴，很小，略带性感，完全令人不安。灰色的眼睛和无可挑剔的皮肤上有两处颜色正在消失的斑点。她身材苗条，运动能力强，没有发育不良，看着她在房间里走动、沿着街道行走、挥舞高尔夫球杆或转动“侧手翻”都是一种乐趣。

A last qualification—her vivid, instant personality escaped that conscious, theatrical quality that AMORY had found in ISABELLE. MONSIGNOR DARCY would have been quite up a tree whether to call her a personality or a personage. She was perhaps the delicious, inexpressible, once-in-a-century blend.
最后一个条件是——她生动、即时的个性摆脱了艾莫里在伊莎贝尔身上发现的那种有意识的、戏剧性的品质。达西主教无论是称她为个人还是人物，都非常有道理。她也许是一种美妙的、难以形容的、百年一遇的融合。

On the night of her debut she is, for all her strange, stray wisdom, quite like a happy little girl. Her mother’s maid has just done her hair, but she has decided impatiently that she can do a better job herself. She is too nervous just now to stay in one place. To that we owe her presence in this littered room. She is going to speak. ISABELLE’S alto tones had been like a violin, but if you could hear ROSALIND, you would say her voice was musical as a waterfall.)
在她首次亮相的那天晚上，尽管她有着奇怪的、流浪的智慧，但她却很像一个快乐的小女孩。她母亲的女仆刚刚给她做了头发，但她不耐烦地决定自己可以做得更好。她刚才太紧张了，不敢呆在一处。因此我们才让她出现在这个满是垃圾的房间里。她要讲话了。伊莎贝尔的中音像小提琴，但如果你能听到罗莎琳德的声音，你会说她的声音像瀑布一样音乐。）

ROSALIND: Honestly, there are only two costumes in the world that I really enjoy being in—(Combing her hair at the dressing-table.) One’s a hoop skirt with pantaloons; the other’s a one-piece bathing-suit. I’m quite charming in both of them.
罗莎琳德：老实说，世界上只有两种服装是我真正喜欢的——（在梳妆台上梳理头发。）一种是带马裤的箍裙；另一种是带有马裤的裙子。另一件是连体泳衣。我对他们两个都很有魅力。

CECELIA: Glad you’re coming out?
塞西莉亚：很高兴你能出来？

ROSALIND: Yes; aren’t you?
罗瑟琳：是的；你不是吗？

CECELIA: (Cynically) You’re glad so you can get married and live on Long Island with the fast younger married set. You want life to be a chain of flirtation with a man for every link.
塞西莉亚：（愤世嫉俗地）你很高兴能结婚并与快速年轻的已婚人士一起住在长岛。你希望生活成为每一个环节都与男人调情的链条。

ROSALIND: Want it to be one! You mean I’ve found it one.
罗莎琳德：希望成为其中之一！你的意思是我已经找到了。

CECELIA: Ha!

ROSALIND: Cecelia, darling, you don’t know what a trial it is to be—like me. I’ve got to keep my face like steel in the street to keep men from winking at me. If I laugh hard from a front row in the theatre, the comedian plays to me for the rest of the evening. If I drop my voice, my eyes, my handkerchief at a dance, my partner calls me up on the ’phone every day for a week.
罗瑟琳：塞西莉亚，亲爱的，你不知道这是一个多么大的考验——就像我一样。我必须在街上保持我的脸像钢铁一样，以防止人们对我眨眼。如果我在剧院的前排大笑，喜剧演员就会在整个晚上为我表演。如果我在舞会上放下声音、眼神、手帕，我的伴侣会连续一周每天给我打电话。

CECELIA: It must be an awful strain.
塞西莉亚：这一定是一种可怕的压力。

ROSALIND: The unfortunate part is that the only men who interest me at all are the totally ineligible ones. Now—if I were poor I’d go on the stage.
罗莎琳德：不幸的是，唯一让我感兴趣的人是完全不合格的人。现在——如果我很穷，我就会登上舞台。

CECELIA: Yes, you might as well get paid for the amount of acting you do.
塞西莉亚：是的，你也可以根据你的表演量获得报酬。

ROSALIND: Sometimes when I’ve felt particularly radiant I’ve thought, why should this be wasted on one man?
罗莎琳德：有时候，当我感到特别容光焕发时，我会想，为什么要把这浪费在一个男人身上呢？

CECELIA: Often when you’re particularly sulky, I’ve wondered why it should all be wasted on just one family. (Getting up.) I think I’ll go down and meet Mr. Amory Blaine. I like temperamental men.
塞西莉亚：当你特别生气时，我经常想知道为什么要把这一切都浪费在一个家庭身上。 （站起来）我想我该下去见艾默里·布莱恩先生。我喜欢有气质的男人。

ROSALIND: There aren’t any. Men don’t know how to be really angry or really happy—and the ones that do, go to pieces.
罗瑟琳：没有。男人不知道如何真正生气或真正快乐——而那些知道的人，就会崩溃。

CECELIA: Well, I’m glad I don’t have all your worries. I’m engaged.
塞西莉亚：嗯，我很高兴我没有你的担心。我订婚了。

ROSALIND: (With a scornful smile) Engaged? Why, you little lunatic! If mother heard you talking like that she’d send you off to boarding-school, where you belong.
罗瑟琳：（轻蔑地微笑）订婚了？哎呀，你这个小疯子！如果妈妈听到你这样说话，她会把你送去寄宿学校，那是你所属的地方。

CECELIA: You won’t tell her, though, because I know things I could tell—and you’re too selfish!
塞西莉亚：不过你不会告诉她，因为我知道我可以告诉的事情——而你太自私了！

ROSALIND: (A little annoyed) Run along, little girl! Who are you engaged to, the iceman? the man that keeps the candy-store?
罗瑟琳：（有点生气）快跑吧，小女孩！你和谁订婚了，冰人？经营糖果店的人？

CECELIA: Cheap wit—good-by, darling, I’ll see you later.
塞西莉亚：小聪明——再见，亲爱的，待会儿见。

ROSALIND: Oh, be sure and do that—you’re such a help.
罗莎琳德：噢，一定要这么做——你真是帮了大忙。

(Exit CECELIA. ROSALIND finished her hair and rises, humming. She goes up to the mirror and starts to dance in front of it on the soft carpet. She watches not her feet, but her eyes—never casually but always intently, even when she smiles. The door suddenly opens and then slams behind AMORY, very cool and handsome as usual. He melts into instant confusion.)
（塞西莉亚下。罗莎琳德整理好头发，站起来，哼着歌。她走到镜子前，开始在镜子前的柔软地毯上跳舞。她看的不是她的脚，而是她的眼睛——从不漫不经心，但总是全神贯注，即使在她微笑着。门突然打开，然后关在艾莫里身后，像往常一样非常酷和英俊。他立刻陷入了混乱。）

HE: Oh, I’m sorry. I thought—
他：哦，对不起。我想-

SHE: (Smiling radiantly) Oh, you’re Amory Blaine, aren’t you?
她：（笑容满面）哦，你是艾默里·布莱恩，不是吗？

HE: (Regarding her closely) And you’re Rosalind?
HE：（仔细地看着她）你是罗莎琳德？

SHE: I’m going to call you Amory—oh, come in—it’s all right—mother’ll be right in—(under her breath) unfortunately.
她：我要叫你艾默里——哦，进来吧——没关系——妈妈马上就进来——（小声地）不幸的是。

HE: (Gazing around) This is sort of a new wrinkle for me.
HE：（环顾四周）这对我来说是一种新的困扰。

SHE: This is No Man’s Land.
她：这是无人区。

HE: This is where you—you—(pause)
HE：这就是你——你——（停顿）

SHE: Yes—all those things. (She crosses to the bureau.) See, here’s my rouge—eye pencils.
她：是的——所有这些事情。 （她走到办公桌前。）看，这是我的胭脂——眼线笔。

HE: I didn’t know you were that way.
HE：我不知道你是这样的。

SHE: What did you expect?
她：你期待什么？

HE: I thought you’d be sort of—sort of—sexless, you know, swim and play golf.
HE：我以为你会有点——有点——无性，你知道，游泳和打高尔夫球。

SHE: Oh, I do—but not in business hours.
她：哦，我愿意——但不是在工作时间。

HE: Business?
他：生意？

SHE: Six to two—strictly.
她：严格来说是六比二。

HE: I’d like to have some stock in the corporation.
HE：我想持有该公司的一些股票。

SHE: Oh, it’s not a corporation—it’s just “Rosalind, Unlimited.” Fifty-one shares, name, good-will, and everything goes at $25,000 a year.
她：哦，这不是一家公司——它只是“罗莎琳德，无限”。五十一股股票，名字，商誉，一切都以每年 25,000 美元为代价。

HE: (Disapprovingly) Sort of a chilly proposition.
HE：（不以为然地）这是一个冷酷的提议。

SHE: Well, Amory, you don’t mind—do you? When I meet a man that doesn’t bore me to death after two weeks, perhaps it’ll be different.
她：嗯，艾默里，你不介意——是吗？当我遇到一个两周后还不让我厌烦的男人时，也许一切都会不同。

HE: Odd, you have the same point of view on men that I have on women.
HE：奇怪，你对男人的看法和我对女人的看法是一样的。

SHE: I’m not really feminine, you know—in my mind.
她：你知道，在我看来，我并不是真正的女性化。

HE: (Interested) Go on.
HE：（有兴趣）继续吧。

SHE: No, you—you go on—you’ve made me talk about myself. That’s against the rules.
她：不，你——你继续说——你让我谈论我自己。这是违反规则的。

HE: Rules?
他统治？

SHE: My own rules—but you—Oh, Amory, I hear you’re brilliant. The family expects so much of you.
她：我自己的规则——但是你——哦，艾默里，我听说你很聪明。家人对你寄予厚望。

HE: How encouraging!
他：多么令人鼓舞啊！

SHE: Alec said you’d taught him to think. Did you? I didn’t believe any one could.
她：亚历克说你教他思考。你是否？我不相信有人能做到。

HE: No. I’m really quite dull.
HE：没有，我真的很无聊。

(He evidently doesn’t intend this to be taken seriously.)
（他显然不打算认真对待这件事。）

SHE: Liar.
她：骗子。

HE: I’m—I’m religious—I’m literary. I’ve—I’ve even written poems.
HE：我——我有宗教信仰——我很文学。我——我什至写过诗。

SHE: Vers libre—splendid! (She declaims.)
她：Vers libre——太棒了！ （她朗诵道。）

   “The trees are green,
    The birds are singing in the trees,
    The girl sips her poison
    The bird flies away the girl dies.”

HE: (Laughing) No, not that kind.
HE：（笑）不，不是那种。

SHE: (Suddenly) I like you.
她：（突然）我喜欢你。

HE: Don’t.
他：不。

SHE: Modest too—
她：也很谦虚——

HE: I’m afraid of you. I’m always afraid of a girl—until I’ve kissed her.
他：我怕你。我总是害怕一个女孩——直到我亲吻了她。

SHE: (Emphatically) My dear boy, the war is over.
她：（强调）我亲爱的孩子，战争结束了。

HE: So I’ll always be afraid of you.
HE：所以我会一直害怕你。

SHE: (Rather sadly) I suppose you will.
她：（相当悲伤地）我想你会的。

(A slight hesitation on both their parts.)
（双方都稍稍犹豫了一下。）

HE: (After due consideration) Listen. This is a frightful thing to ask.
HE：（经过深思熟虑）听着。这是一件可怕的事情。

SHE: (Knowing what’s coming) After five minutes.
她：（知道会发生什么）五分钟后。

HE: But will you—kiss me? Or are you afraid?
HE：但是你愿意——吻我吗？或者你害怕吗？

SHE: I’m never afraid—but your reasons are so poor.
她：我从不害怕——但你的理由太站不住脚了。

HE: Rosalind, I really want to kiss you.
HE：罗莎琳德，我真的很想吻你。

SHE: So do I.
她：我也是。

(They kiss—definitely and thoroughly.)
（他们接吻——绝对彻底。）

HE: (After a breathless second) Well, is your curiosity satisfied?
HE：（喘不过气来）那么，你的好奇心满足了吗？

SHE: Is yours?
她：是你的吗？

HE: No, it’s only aroused.
HE：不，只是被唤起。

(He looks it.)
（他看起来是这样。）

SHE: (Dreamily) I’ve kissed dozens of men. I suppose I’ll kiss dozens more.
她：（如梦似幻地）我亲吻过几十个男人。我想我还会再亲几十个。

HE: (Abstractedly) Yes, I suppose you could—like that.
HE：（抽象地）是的，我想你可以——就像那样。

SHE: Most people like the way I kiss.
她：大多数人都喜欢我接吻的方式。

HE: (Remembering himself) Good Lord, yes. Kiss me once more, Rosalind.
HE：（想起自己）上帝啊，是的。再吻我一次，罗莎琳德。

SHE: No—my curiosity is generally satisfied at one.
她：没有——我的好奇心基本上在一次就得到了满足。

HE: (Discouraged) Is that a rule?
HE：（沮丧）这是规定吗？

SHE: I make rules to fit the cases.
她：我会根据具体情况制定规则。

HE: You and I are somewhat alike—except that I’m years older in experience.
HE：你和我有些相似——只是我的经验比你年长一些。

SHE: How old are you?
她：你几岁了？

HE: Almost twenty-three. You?
HE：快二十三岁了。你？

SHE: Nineteen—just.
她：十九——刚刚。

HE: I suppose you’re the product of a fashionable school.
HE：我想你是时尚流派的产物。

SHE: No—I’m fairly raw material. I was expelled from Spence—I’ve forgotten why.
她：不——我还很原始。我被斯彭斯开除——我忘了​​为什么。

HE: What’s your general trend?
HE：你的总体趋势是什么？

SHE: Oh, I’m bright, quite selfish, emotional when aroused, fond of admiration—
她：哦，我很聪明，很自私，被激发时情绪化，喜欢赞美——

HE: (Suddenly) I don’t want to fall in love with you—
HE：（突然）我不想爱上你——

SHE: (Raising her eyebrows) Nobody asked you to.
她：（扬起眉毛）没有人要求你这么做。

HE: (Continuing coldly) But I probably will. I love your mouth.
HE：（冷冷地继续）但我可能会的。我爱你的嘴。

SHE: Hush! Please don’t fall in love with my mouth—hair, eyes, shoulders, slippers—but not my mouth. Everybody falls in love with my mouth.
她：嘘！请不要爱上我的嘴——头发、眼睛、肩膀、拖鞋——但不要爱上我的嘴。每个人都爱上我的嘴。

HE: It’s quite beautiful.
何：相当漂亮。

SHE: It’s too small.
她：太小了。

HE: No it isn’t—let’s see.
HE：不，不是——让我们看看。

(He kisses her again with the same thoroughness.)
（他再次以同样的彻底地吻了她。）

SHE: (Rather moved) Say something sweet.
她：（有点感动）说点甜言蜜语吧。

HE: (Frightened) Lord help me.
他：（害怕）上帝帮助我。

SHE: (Drawing away) Well, don’t—if it’s so hard.
她：（走开）好吧，别这么做——如果这么难的话。

HE: Shall we pretend? So soon?
他：我们假装一下吧？真快？

SHE: We haven’t the same standards of time as other people.
她：我们的时间标准与其他人不同。

HE: Already it’s—other people.
HE：已经是——其他人了。

SHE: Let’s pretend.
她：我们假装一下吧。

HE: No—I can’t—it’s sentiment.
HE：不——我不能——这是情感。

SHE: You’re not sentimental?
她：你不感情用事吗？

HE: No, I’m romantic—a sentimental person thinks things will last—a romantic person hopes against hope that they won’t. Sentiment is emotional.
HE：不，我很浪漫——一个多愁善感的人认为事情会持续下去——一个浪漫的人会希望事情不会持续下去。情绪是情绪化的。

SHE: And you’re not? (With her eyes half-closed.) You probably flatter yourself that that’s a superior attitude.
她：你不是吗？ （半闭着眼睛）你可能会自以为这是一种高人一等的态度。

HE: Well—Rosalind, Rosalind, don’t argue—kiss me again.
HE：好吧——罗莎琳德，罗莎琳德，别争辩——再吻我一次。

SHE: (Quite chilly now) No—I have no desire to kiss you.
她：（现在很冷）不——我不想吻你。

HE: (Openly taken aback) You wanted to kiss me a minute ago.
HE：（公开惊讶）你一分钟前还想吻我。

SHE: This is now.
她：就是现在。

HE: I’d better go.
他：我还是走吧。

SHE: I suppose so.
她：我想是的。

(He goes toward the door.)
（他走向门口。）

SHE: Oh!
她：哦！

(He turns.)
（他转身。）

SHE: (Laughing) Score—Home Team: One hundred—Opponents: Zero.
她：（笑）得分——主队：一百——对手：零。

(He starts back.)
（他向后退去。）

SHE: (Quickly) Rain—no game.
她：（很快）下雨了——不玩了。

(He goes out.)
（他出去了。）

(She goes quietly to the chiffonier, takes out a cigarette-case and hides it in the side drawer of a desk. Her mother enters, note-book in hand.)
（她悄悄走到抽屉前，拿出一个烟盒，藏在桌子旁边的抽屉里。她妈妈进来了，手里拿着笔记本。）

MRS. CONNAGE: Good—I’ve been wanting to speak to you alone before we go down-stairs.
太太。康纳奇：好——我一直想在下楼之前单独和你谈谈。

ROSALIND: Heavens! you frighten me!
罗瑟琳：天啊！你吓到我了！

MRS. CONNAGE: Rosalind, you’ve been a very expensive proposition.
太太。 CONNAGE：罗莎琳德，你是一个非常昂贵的提议。

ROSALIND: (Resignedly) Yes.
罗瑟琳：（无奈地）是的。

MRS. CONNAGE: And you know your father hasn’t what he once had.
太太。康纳奇：你知道你的父亲已经不再拥有他曾经拥有的一切了。

ROSALIND: (Making a wry face) Oh, please don’t talk about money.
罗瑟琳：（苦笑）哦，请不要谈论金钱。

MRS. CONNAGE: You can’t do anything without it. This is our last year in this house—and unless things change Cecelia won’t have the advantages you’ve had.
太太。 CONNAGE：没有它你什么也做不了。这是我们在这所房子里的最后一年——除非事情发生改变，塞西莉亚将不会拥有你所拥有的优势。

ROSALIND: (Impatiently) Well—what is it?
罗瑟琳：（不耐烦地）嗯——什么事？

MRS. CONNAGE: So I ask you to please mind me in several things I’ve put down in my note-book. The first one is: don’t disappear with young men. There may be a time when it’s valuable, but at present I want you on the dance-floor where I can find you. There are certain men I want to have you meet and I don’t like finding you in some corner of the conservatory exchanging silliness with any one—or listening to it.
太太。 CONNAGE：所以我请你注意我记在笔记本上的几件事。第一个是：不要和年轻人一起消失。也许有时候它很有价值，但目前我希望你在舞池里，在那里我可以找到你。我想让你见见某些人，但我不喜欢发现你在音乐学院的某个角落里与任何人交换愚蠢的言论——或者倾听它们。

ROSALIND: (Sarcastically) Yes, listening to it is better.
罗莎琳德：（讽刺地）是的，听一下更好。

MRS. CONNAGE: And don’t waste a lot of time with the college set—little boys nineteen and twenty years old. I don’t mind a prom or a football game, but staying away from advantageous parties to eat in little cafes down-town with Tom, Dick, and Harry—
太太。 CONNAGE：不要在大学场景上浪费太多时间——十九岁和二十岁的小男孩。我不介意参加舞会或足球比赛，但要远离有利可图的聚会，和汤姆、迪克和哈利一起去市中心的小咖啡馆吃饭——

ROSALIND: (Offering her code, which is, in its way, quite as high as her mother’s) Mother, it’s done—you can’t run everything now the way you did in the early nineties.
罗莎琳德：（提供她的代码，就其方式而言，与她母亲的代码相当高）母亲，已经完成了——你现在不能像九十年代初那样运行一切了。

MRS. CONNAGE: (Paying no attention) There are several bachelor friends of your father’s that I want you to meet to-night—youngish men.
太太。康纳奇：（没有理睬）我想让你今晚见见你父亲的几个单身汉朋友——都是年轻人。

ROSALIND: (Nodding wisely) About forty-five?
罗瑟琳：（明智地点点头）大约四十五岁？

MRS. CONNAGE: (Sharply) Why not?
太太。康纳吉：（尖锐地）为什么不呢？

ROSALIND: Oh, quite all right—they know life and are so adorably tired looking (shakes her head)—but they will dance.
罗莎琳德：哦，好吧——他们了解生活，而且看起来很可爱（摇摇头）——但他们会跳舞。

MRS. CONNAGE: I haven’t met Mr. Blaine—but I don’t think you’ll care for him. He doesn’t sound like a money-maker.
太太。康纳奇：我还没见过布莱恩先生，但我认为你不会关心他。他听起来不像一个赚钱的人。

ROSALIND: Mother, I never think about money.
罗莎琳德：妈妈，我从没想过钱。

MRS. CONNAGE: You never keep it long enough to think about it.
太太。 CONNAGE：你永远不会把它留得足够长来思考它。

ROSALIND: (Sighs) Yes, I suppose some day I’ll marry a ton of it—out of sheer boredom.
罗莎琳德：（叹气）是的，我想有一天我会嫁给很多这样的人——纯粹是出于无聊。

MRS. CONNAGE: (Referring to note-book) I had a wire from Hartford. Dawson Ryder is coming up. Now there’s a young man I like, and he’s floating in money. It seems to me that since you seem tired of Howard Gillespie you might give Mr. Ryder some encouragement. This is the third time he’s been up in a month.
太太。 CONNAGE：（指的是笔记本）我收到了一条来自哈特福德的电报。道森·赖德即将登场。现在有一个我喜欢的年轻人，而且他很有钱。在我看来，既然你似乎厌倦了霍华德·吉莱斯皮，你可以给莱德先生一些鼓励。这是他一个月内第三次起床。

ROSALIND: How did you know I was tired of Howard Gillespie?
罗莎琳德：你怎么知道我厌倦了霍华德·吉莱斯皮？

MRS. CONNAGE: The poor boy looks so miserable every time he comes.
太太。康纳奇：这个可怜的男孩每次来都显得那么痛苦。

ROSALIND: That was one of those romantic, pre-battle affairs. They’re all wrong.
罗莎琳德：那是一场浪漫的战前事件。他们都错了。

MRS. CONNAGE: (Her say said) At any rate, make us proud of you to-night.
太太。 CONNAGE：（她说）无论如何，今晚让我们为你感到骄傲。

ROSALIND: Don’t you think I’m beautiful?
罗瑟琳：你不觉得我很漂亮吗？

MRS. CONNAGE: You know you are.
太太。康纳奇：你知道你是。

(From down-stairs is heard the moan of a violin being tuned, the roll of a drum. MRS. CONNAGE turns quickly to her daughter.)
（楼下传来小提琴调音的呻吟声和鼓声。康纳奇太太迅速转向她的女儿。）

MRS. CONNAGE: Come!
太太。康纳吉：来吧！

ROSALIND: One minute!
罗瑟琳：一分钟！

(Her mother leaves. ROSALIND goes to the glass where she gazes at herself with great satisfaction. She kisses her hand and touches her mirrored mouth with it. Then she turns out the lights and leaves the room. Silence for a moment. A few chords from the piano, the discreet patter of faint drums, the rustle of new silk, all blend on the staircase outside and drift in through the partly opened door. Bundled figures pass in the lighted hall. The laughter heard below becomes doubled and multiplied. Then some one comes in, closes the door, and switches on the lights. It is CECELIA. She goes to the chiffonier, looks in the drawers, hesitates—then to the desk whence she takes the cigarette-case and extracts one. She lights it and then, puffing and blowing, walks toward the mirror.)
（她母亲离开了。罗瑟琳走到镜子前，非常满意地看着自己。她亲吻她的手，用它触碰镜子里的嘴。然后她关掉灯，离开房间。沉默了一会儿。几首和弦钢琴声、微弱的鼓声、新丝绸的沙沙声，都在外面的楼梯上融合在一起，从半开的门飘进来。灯光明亮的大厅里，一群群人影经过。下面听到的笑声变得加倍、倍增。然后有人进来，关上门，打开灯。是塞西莉亚。她走到抽屉前，看了看抽屉，犹豫了一下——然后走到书桌前，从那里拿出烟盒，取出一根。她点燃了它然后，气喘吁吁地走向镜子。）

CECELIA: (In tremendously sophisticated accents) Oh, yes, coming out is such a farce nowadays, you know. One really plays around so much before one is seventeen, that it’s positively anticlimax. (Shaking hands with a visionary middle-aged nobleman.) Yes, your grace—I b’lieve I’ve heard my sister speak of you. Have a puff—they’re very good. They’re—they’re Coronas. You don’t smoke? What a pity! The king doesn’t allow it, I suppose. Yes, I’ll dance.
塞西莉亚：（用极其复杂的口音）哦，是的，现在出柜是一场闹剧，你知道。一个人在十七岁之前就玩得太多了，这绝对是虎头蛇尾的。 （与一位有远见的中年贵族握手。）是的，陛下——我相信我听到我姐姐谈起过你。吸一口——它们非常好。他们是——他们是科罗纳斯。你不抽烟吗？真可惜！我想国王不会允许的。是的，我会跳舞。

(So she dances around the room to a tune from down-stairs, her arms outstretched to an imaginary partner, the cigarette waving in her hand.)
（于是她随着楼下的曲调在房间里跳舞，她向想象中的舞伴伸出双臂，手中的香烟挥舞着。）

SEVERAL HOURS LATER
几个小时后

The corner of a den down-stairs, filled by a very comfortable leather lounge. A small light is on each side above, and in the middle, over the couch hangs a painting of a very old, very dignified gentleman, period 1860. Outside the music is heard in a fox-trot.
楼下书房的一角，摆满了非常舒适的皮革休息室。上面两侧各有一盏小灯，中间的沙发上挂着一幅非常古老、非常有尊严的绅士的画，1860 年时期。外面传来狐步舞的音乐声。

ROSALIND is seated on the lounge and on her left is HOWARD GILLESPIE, a vapid youth of about twenty-four. He is obviously very unhappy, and she is quite bored.
罗莎琳德坐在休息室里，坐在她左边的是霍华德·吉勒斯皮，一个二十四岁左右、面无表情的年轻人。他显然很不高兴，而她也很无聊。

GILLESPIE: (Feebly) What do you mean I’ve changed. I feel the same toward you.
GILLESPIE：（无力地）你说我变了是什么意思？我对你也有同样的感觉。

ROSALIND: But you don’t look the same to me.
罗瑟琳：但你在我看来不一样。

GILLESPIE: Three weeks ago you used to say that you liked me because I was so blasé, so indifferent—I still am.
吉莱斯皮：三周前你常说你喜欢我，因为我是如此厌倦，如此冷漠——我仍然如此。

ROSALIND: But not about me. I used to like you because you had brown eyes and thin legs.
罗瑟琳：但不是关于我的。我曾经喜欢你，因为你有棕色的眼睛和细细的腿。

GILLESPIE: (Helplessly) They’re still thin and brown. You’re a vampire, that’s all.
GILLESPIE：（无助地）它们仍然很瘦，呈棕色。你是一个吸血鬼，仅此而已。

ROSALIND: The only thing I know about vamping is what’s on the piano score. What confuses men is that I’m perfectly natural. I used to think you were never jealous. Now you follow me with your eyes wherever I go.
罗莎琳德：我对吸血鬼的唯一了解就是钢琴谱上的内容。让男人感到困惑的是我是完全自然的。我曾经以为你从来不嫉妒。现在无论我走到哪里，你的眼睛都跟着我。

GILLESPIE: I love you.
吉莱斯皮：我爱你。

ROSALIND: (Coldly) I know it.
罗瑟琳：（冷冷地）我知道。

GILLESPIE: And you haven’t kissed me for two weeks. I had an idea that after a girl was kissed she was—was—won.
吉莱斯皮：你已经两周没有吻我了。我有一个想法，当一个女孩被亲吻后，她就被赢得了。

ROSALIND: Those days are over. I have to be won all over again every time you see me.
罗瑟琳：那些日子已经结束了。每次你见到我，我都必须再次被征服。

GILLESPIE: Are you serious?
吉莱斯皮：你是认真的吗？

ROSALIND: About as usual. There used to be two kinds of kisses: First when girls were kissed and deserted; second, when they were engaged. Now there’s a third kind, where the man is kissed and deserted. If Mr. Jones of the nineties bragged he’d kissed a girl, every one knew he was through with her. If Mr. Jones of 1919 brags the same every one knows it’s because he can’t kiss her any more. Given a decent start any girl can beat a man nowadays.
罗瑟琳：和平常一样。过去的接吻有两种：一是女孩子被亲吻而抛弃；二是女孩子被亲吻而被抛弃。第二，当他们订婚的时候。现在还有第三种，即男人被亲吻并被抛弃。如果九十年代的琼斯先生吹嘘他吻了一个女孩，每个人都知道他已经和她分手了。如果 1919 年的琼斯先生也这么吹嘘，那么每个人都知道那是因为他不能再亲吻她了。如今，只要有一个良好的开端，任何女孩都可以击败男人。

GILLESPIE: Then why do you play with men?
GILLESPIE：那你为什么要和男人一起玩？

ROSALIND: (Leaning forward confidentially) For that first moment, when he’s interested. There is a moment—Oh, just before the first kiss, a whispered word—something that makes it worth while.
罗莎琳德：（秘密地向前倾身）在第一时刻，当他感兴趣的时候。有一个时刻——哦，就在初吻之前，一句低声的话——让这一切变得值得。

GILLESPIE: And then?
吉莱斯皮：然后呢？

ROSALIND: Then after that you make him talk about himself. Pretty soon he thinks of nothing but being alone with you—he sulks, he won’t fight, he doesn’t want to play—Victory!
罗瑟琳：然后你让他谈论他自己。很快他就只想和你单独在一起——他生闷气，他不会打架，他不想玩——胜利！

(Enter DAWSON RYDER, twenty-six, handsome, wealthy, faithful to his own, a bore perhaps, but steady and sure of success.)
（道森·瑞德上场，二十六岁，英俊、富有、忠于自己的人，也许有些无聊，但稳重且有成功的把握。）

RYDER: I believe this is my dance, Rosalind.
莱德：我相信这是我的舞蹈，罗莎琳德。

ROSALIND: Well, Dawson, so you recognize me. Now I know I haven’t got too much paint on. Mr. Ryder, this is Mr. Gillespie.
罗瑟琳：嗯，道森，所以你认出了我。现在我知道我还没有涂太多油漆。莱德先生，这是吉莱斯皮先生。

(They shake hands and GILLESPIE leaves, tremendously downcast.)
（他们握手，吉莱斯皮离开，心情极其沮丧。）

RYDER: Your party is certainly a success.
RYDER：你们的聚会确实很成功。

ROSALIND: Is it—I haven’t seen it lately. I’m weary—Do you mind sitting out a minute?
罗瑟琳：是吗——我最近没看到。我累了——你介意坐一会儿吗？

RYDER: Mind—I’m delighted. You know I loathe this “rushing" idea. See a girl yesterday, to-day, to-morrow.
RYDER：注意——我很高兴。你知道我讨厌这种“匆忙”的想法。昨天、今天、明天都见到一个女孩。

ROSALIND: Dawson!
罗瑟琳：道森！

RYDER: What?
瑞德：什么？

ROSALIND: I wonder if you know you love me.
罗瑟琳：我想知道你是否知道你爱我。

RYDER: (Startled) What—Oh—you know you’re remarkable!
RYDER：（吃惊）什么——哦——你知道你很了不起！

ROSALIND: Because you know I’m an awful proposition. Any one who marries me will have his hands full. I’m mean—mighty mean.
罗莎琳德：因为你知道我是一个糟糕的提议。任何一个嫁给我的人都会忙得不可开交。我很卑鄙——非常卑鄙。

RYDER: Oh, I wouldn’t say that.
瑞德：哦，我不会这么说。

ROSALIND: Oh, yes, I am—especially to the people nearest to me. (She rises.) Come, let’s go. I’ve changed my mind and I want to dance. Mother is probably having a fit.
罗莎琳德：哦，是的，我是——尤其是对于离我最近的人。 （她站起来）来吧，我们走吧。我改变了主意，我想跳舞。妈妈可能是发作了。

(Exeunt. Enter ALEC and CECELIA.)
（下。亚历克和塞西莉亚上。）

CECELIA: Just my luck to get my own brother for an intermission.
塞西莉亚：我很幸运能够让我自己的兄弟参加中场休息。

ALEC: (Gloomily) I’ll go if you want me to.
ALEC：（郁郁寡欢）如果你愿意的话我就去。

CECELIA: Good heavens, no—with whom would I begin the next dance? (Sighs.) There’s no color in a dance since the French officers went back.
塞西莉亚：天哪，不——我该和谁开始下一支舞呢？ （叹气）自从法国军官回去后，舞蹈就没有色彩了。

ALEC: (Thoughtfully) I don’t want Amory to fall in love with Rosalind.
ALEC：（若有所思地）我不想让艾默里爱上罗莎琳德。

CECELIA: Why, I had an idea that that was just what you did want.
塞西莉亚：哎呀，我知道这正是你想要的。

ALEC: I did, but since seeing these girls—I don’t know. I’m awfully attached to Amory. He’s sensitive and I don’t want him to break his heart over somebody who doesn’t care about him.
ALEC：我做到了，但是自从看到这些女孩之后——我不知道了。我非常喜欢艾默里。他很敏感，我不想让他因为一个不关心他的人而伤心。

CECELIA: He’s very good looking.
塞西莉亚：他长得很帅。

ALEC: (Still thoughtfully) She won’t marry him, but a girl doesn’t have to marry a man to break his heart.
亚历克：（仍然若有所思）她不会嫁给他，但女孩不必嫁给一个男人才能伤他的心。

CECELIA: What does it? I wish I knew the secret.
塞西莉亚：有什么作用？我希望我知道这个秘密。

ALEC: Why, you cold-blooded little kitty. It’s lucky for some that the Lord gave you a pug nose.
亚历克：哎呀，你这个冷血小猫。对于某些人来说，上帝赐予你一个哈巴狗鼻子是件幸运的事。

(Enter MRS. CONNAGE.)
（康纳吉夫人上。）

MRS. CONNAGE: Where on earth is Rosalind?
太太。 CONNAGE：罗莎琳德到底在哪里？

ALEC: (Brilliantly) Of course you’ve come to the best people to find out. She’d naturally be with us.
ALEC：（出色地）当然，你已经找到了最好的人来找出答案。她自然会和我们在一起。

MRS. CONNAGE: Her father has marshalled eight bachelor millionaires to meet her.
太太。康纳奇：她的父亲召集了八位单身汉百万富翁来见她。

ALEC: You might form a squad and march through the halls.
ALEC：你可以组成一个小队并在大厅里游行。

MRS. CONNAGE: I’m perfectly serious—for all I know she may be at the Cocoanut Grove with some football player on the night of her debut. You look left and I’ll—
太太。 CONNAGE：我是非常认真的——据我所知，她首秀当晚可能和一些足球运动员在椰林。你向左看，我会——

ALEC: (Flippantly) Hadn’t you better send the butler through the cellar?
ALEC：（轻率地）你不是最好让管家去地窖吗？

MRS. CONNAGE: (Perfectly serious) Oh, you don’t think she’d be there?
太太。 CONNAGE：（非常严肃）哦，你认为她不会在那儿吗？

CECELIA: He’s only joking, mother.
塞西莉亚：他只是在开玩笑，妈妈。

ALEC: Mother had a picture of her tapping a keg of beer with some high hurdler.
亚历克：妈妈有一张她和一些跨栏高手敲打一桶啤酒的照片。

MRS. CONNAGE: Let’s look right away.
太太。 CONNAGE：我们马上看看。

(They go out. ROSALIND comes in with GILLESPIE.)
（他们出去了。罗莎琳德和吉莱斯皮进来了。）

GILLESPIE: Rosalind—Once more I ask you. Don’t you care a blessed thing about me?
吉莱斯皮：罗莎琳德——我再问你一次。难道你不关心我的幸福吗？

(AMORY walks in briskly.)
（艾莫里快步走进来。）

AMORY: My dance.
艾默里：我的舞蹈。

ROSALIND: Mr. Gillespie, this is Mr. Blaine.
罗瑟琳：吉莱斯皮先生，这是布莱恩先生。

GILLESPIE: I’ve met Mr. Blaine. From Lake Geneva, aren’t you?
吉莱斯皮：我见过布莱恩先生。你来自日内瓦湖，不是吗？

AMORY: Yes.
艾默里：是的。

GILLESPIE: (Desperately) I’ve been there. It’s in the—the Middle West, isn’t it?
GILLESPIE：（绝望地）我去过那里。它在——中西部，不是吗？

AMORY: (Spicily) Approximately. But I always felt that I’d rather be provincial hot-tamale than soup without seasoning.
艾默里：（尖刻地）大约。但我总觉得我宁愿做乡下的热玉米粉蒸肉，也不愿喝没有调料的汤。

GILLESPIE: What!
吉莱斯皮：什么！

AMORY: Oh, no offense.
艾默里：哦，无意冒犯。

(GILLESPIE bows and leaves.)
（吉莱斯皮鞠躬并离开。）

ROSALIND: He’s too much people.
罗瑟琳：他太多人了。

AMORY: I was in love with a people once.
艾默里：我曾经爱过一个人。

ROSALIND: So?
罗瑟琳：所以呢？

AMORY: Oh, yes—her name was Isabelle—nothing at all to her except what I read into her.
艾默里：哦，是的——她的名字叫伊莎贝尔——除了我对她的解读之外，她什么都没有。

ROSALIND: What happened?
罗瑟琳：发生了什么事？

AMORY: Finally I convinced her that she was smarter than I was—then she threw me over. Said I was critical and impractical, you know.
艾默里：最后我让她相信她比我聪明——然后她把我扔了下去。你知道，我说我很挑剔而且不切实际。

ROSALIND: What do you mean impractical?
罗瑟琳：不切实际是什么意思？

AMORY: Oh—drive a car, but can’t change a tire.
